story:
The Play

For the girls of Bunk 14, sleep-away camp isn't an eight-week vacation; it's a dog-eat-dog microcosm of the adult world they're so desperate to inhabit. Join Ashley, Zoe, Tracy, Samantha, and Abby on this 90-minute thrill ride into the unexpectedly dark and dangerous world of 12-year-old girls that's hysterically funny as it is brutally disturbing! PINK! is being produced by PortFringe 2012, and will be performed at the St. Lawrence Arts and Community Center in Portland, Maine on June 30th at 4PM.

The Team

PINK! is being produced by the Portland Theater Collaborative as part of Portland's first annual Fringe Festival: PortFringe 2012!

The Cast: Kat Moraros, Natalie Jimenez, Heather Elizabeth Irish, Hannah Daly, and Lorenza Lattanzi.

The Creative Team: Cait Robinson (director, costumes), Emily Dixon (stage manager), Bari Robinson (assistant stage manager, videographer), Kristin McCarthy Parker (dramaturgy), Shannon Stockwell (props, photography), Emily Mahaffey (lights, sound), Nora Casey (marketing), James Hoban (graphic design).

Why We Need Your Help

PortFringe generously provides performance space free of charge to all participating artists. However, we still need to raise money for performance rights, props, costumes, vehicle rentals (to transport our set pieces), marketing and publicity materials, and modest stipends for the cast and crew. Any donations above our goal will be added on to these stipends.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please consider posting this link on Facebook or Twitter! If you live in the Portland area, you may also be able to support this performance by:

  • lending a truck or van to transport set pieces

  • lending or donating a prop (we need twin or cot mattresses! for more information, email Shannon Stockwell at shanstock@gmail.com)

And of course, don't forget to catch our performance at 4PM on June 30th at the St. Lawrence Arts and Community Center in Portland! Ticket info available here: http://www.portfringe.com/buy.htm

story:
Odradek Loves Brigham

Odradek crawled out from under the basement stairs and what did I see? Brigham Mosley and Jon Wikholm and Ashley-Marie Quijano gathered in an excited huddle.

Ever since Executive Director Jon and Artistic Director Ashley-Marie met Brigham, Odradek Theatre Company has been a huge fan of this awesome young artist. In 2011 we produced a succesful run of his Pretty, Smart, Poetic, a saga about three young women. Then, we heard about his solo, autobiographical piece, Mo[u]rnin'. After. We had to present it to Chicago audiences.

At the same time an undergraduate student at Wabash College named Hezekiah asked for some help with a project designed to acquaint undergraduate students with careers in the arts.

It seemed like a match made in heaven.

The Show

Mo[u]rnin'. After. is a mythic autobiography for the queer prodigal son - a journey to the ancestors and back to the homeland through magic, musicals, and time travel. Dream ballets included.

Mo[u]rnin'. After. was created under the Tim Miller Mentorship, a 6 month development process to create new, queer work, made possible by grants from the National Performance Network, Performance Space 122, and Fourth Arts Block. The performance that was created, Oh Whatta Beautiful Mo[u]rnin', premiered at PS122 in June of 2011, it was later produced at La MaMa ETC as part of the FAB Festival.

Mo[u]rnin'. After. is the full-length continuation of Oh ‘Whatta Beautiful Mo[u]rnin’ (video above).

 

The Tour

Did you know that you can get on an Amtrak train in Penn Station, NYC, and get off in Crawfordsville, Indiana. Brigham thought it sounded like a great idea and has this itch to see the United States close up, so we got him a train ticket and arranged to meet him in Crawfordsville, Indiana, home of Wabash College.

At the College Brigham will participate in a couple of panel discussions, present Mo[u]rnin'. After. and present a workshop on the development of an autobiographical solo piece.

Then, on to Mary's Attic in Chicago's Andersonville neighborhood for two weekends of shows, helped along by local businessnes who have generously agreed to help publicize the event.

What We Need

We don't have enough money to pay all the bills yet. We'll make some at the door, and we have our regular Sugar Daddies, but that only covers part of the costs. We still need to send Brigham back home to NYC! If we don't send him home, Brigham's partner Zac will be really upset with us! We have other expenses, too. We wish art were free, but it's not. If we don't pay for things like time and materials, shipping and printing, ticketing and space rental, there won't be any art and we know you don't want that.

Who Cares?

Certainly, Hezekiah at the students at Wabash College care. They get a chance to meet a real artist pretty close to their own age. If fact, they get to meet Brigham and Odradek's leadership team, Jon and Ashley-Marie. This will help them a lot with their career plans and preparation for the [shudder] "real world."

Perhaps most importantly, everyone who gets to see Brigham's fantastic mythic autobiography will get to experience the magic of Brigham's theater, his inspiring reminiscence of what it's like to be a young gay man in Southwest Oklahoma, and what a great future gay men and women everywhere can hope to achieve. It's a message about youth, roots and the bright future that young people have planned for the world even in the face of some pretty tough odds.

Your Reward

We need your cash and aren't offering much in the way of material rewards, just a few trinkets. But you will have the satisfaction of knowing that you have helped Brigham and Odradek spread the message of love and acceptance for everyone. That, alone, should give you some warm fuzzies to sleep with.

Check the list below for perks.

Even if you can't contribute cash, you can help us by publicizing this on your Facebook page, personal website or blog. Check out the Indiegogo tools for more information.

Blog

We're blogging our adventure with Brigham, from Wabash through Chicago. Keep up to date with us HERE.

And Finally...

Thanks from the bottom of Odradek's heart and a great big hug from under Odradek's basement stairs! Thanks to Erik Carter for some great photos.

story:
About me:

I am Nayana Bhat, 26, a professional contemporary dancer from Bangalore. My training is primarily in Bharatnatayam, Kathak and some Ballet. I have been dancing professionally for the last 5 years in which, I have been independently working since 3yrs. In this period, I have been doing some extensive research in body-mind area, where in I make experiments on how the human body moves, what motivates us to move and how do we make choices.

I made some very interesting discoveries in the process, while I also started studying the curious adaptations of Release technique of Modern dance in Bharatnatyam. In order to further this research, I applied to Salzburg Experimental Academy of Dance for their international choreographers exchange program, and got accepted over 400 applicants! 

The school is offering me a 50% fee waiver. But I still need a lot of money for my flight, living and housing in Salzburg for a year long period. 

What I Need

I need about $15000 oveall. When I break down the expenses, I need it for the following things.

  • $2500 for the remaining fee
  • $730 for airfare
  • $12000 for living expenses ($1000/month)

I have managed to put together about $5000 so far. And need about $10000 more to make this happen.

Every penny you contribute will bring me that much nearer to fulfilling this dream.

 

The Impact

This program is super important to my research. My research is valuable for the following reasons:

  • It can give practical data to how human body is very intricately connected with the emotions and vice versa.
  • It can be a powerful tool in physiological and emotional healing.
  • It is aimed at creating powerful dance works that are visceral in nature.

In 2010, I did an apprenticeship program in improvisation studies with a renowned teacher from the Netherlands and that was the beginning point of my research. In the last 2 years, my work has steadily evolved in this direction, has been presented in India and abroad (refer to my website).

My primary breakthrough has been in the field of creativity and healing. I have been successfully using this work in regular movement classes for adults and children. I have been extensively using this knowledge in my association as an instructor with Shiri Dance Company's program for children called Body Talk. This program has been introduced as a curriculum in several schools across the city in the last one year, at The Samhita Academy, Neev, First Steps to name a few. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Money need not be the only way of contribution. you could help me with finding accommodation or sharing this information with you friends who can help.

story:
Welcome to BOBLO! 

The funds raised in this campaign will go towards final production expenses for the Toronto premiere of BOBLO in November 2012 at The Theatre Centre.  Right now, we'd really love to make enough to get a piano for the band.  

Here's the project:

I grew up going to Boblo. We went every year when I was a kid. My parents went, my grandparents went, my aunts and uncles worked there for their summer jobs, and if you grew up in Detroit or Southern Ontario, you know how special Boblo was. Boblo was an amusement park on an island in the Detroit River.  It was in operation from 1893 until September 1993 when it shut down for good.

 

Our project, BOBLO, is a theatre experience that combines a rock concert with a ghost story to explore the evanescent nature of memory. It is a musical collage through the collected memories and history of Boblo Island using a rocking live band, radio transmissions, performers and visual imagery. It is an attempt to recreate the story of the island and the memory of a childhood playground.

Brought to you by Erin Brandenburg (the creator behind Petrichor, Reesor, and Pelee) and Andrew Penner (The Sunparlour Players). Directed by Steven McCarthy, the leader of the theatrical rock extravaganza The ElastoCitizens, and the award winning Bliss, and featuring the talents of Rebecca Picherack (The Golden Dragon, Ruined), Elysha Poirier (Seeds) and Jung-Hye Kim (Middle Place, If We Were Birds.) Our stellar cast of performers includes Andrew Penner, Amy Rutherford, Trent Pardy, Sophia Walker, Gordon Bolan, Anna Atkinson, George Meanwell, Alan Penner and transmission artist Andrew O'Connor.

Behind this project is Kitchenband, a theatre and performance collective based in Toronto. The focus is to tell stories inspired by the Canadian landscape and history, blurring the lines between theatre, music and visual art. Kitchenband has been behind the fringe and indie theatre hits Reesor, Pelee and Petrichor.

BOBLO is a co-production with The Theatre Centre in Toronto. Kitchenband was a company in Residence at The Theatre Centre from 2010 – 2012, experimenting and developing their original work Boblo.

With support from:

story:
Who are we?

Hune Company is a theatrical production company in Houston. We develop expansive productions that explore the inherent poignancy of live performance.

Hune Company is dedicated to making a body of original work that challenges the definition of live performance by investigating basic human interaction.

The Living Room Series is a project that directly speaks to our mission.


What is the Living Room Series?

The Living Room Series is a series of plays performed in a living room. It is an experiment into the ways in which we receive live entertainment. It is a place where new plays are developed and performed. It is maybe one of the smallest theatre spaces you have ever visited.

This series aims to keep budgets low, space small, and imaginations high, providing an exciting challenge for artists. Some of Houston’s most innovative and talented artists are set to be a part of this first season ensuring the quality of this valuable work in a modest space. The closeness of the action on stage enhances the intimacy of the performances and allows audiences the opportunity to experince a play in a new way.

The Living Room also offers audiences a unique experience in that a small group of about 20 people attends each evening’s performance. Free beer, wine, and other beverages are served before and after the shows, gently encouraging people to talk to each other and hang out. The Living Room is more than just a theatre, it’s a place where people connect.


The Shows

NOT MAD -World PremierJuly 30 - Aug 8

GONE -By Charles Mee Sept 3 - Sept 12

BLACKBIRD -By David Harrower Oct 15 - Oct 24

UP CLOSE -Short Plays by Houston Artists Dec 10 - Dec 12


What We Need

All funds made from this campaign go directly to funding the physical transition of the living room into the theatre, such as:

-Drapes (to be hung around the perimeter of the space)

-Platforms

-Seating

-Lights 

The physical transition of the space can be made for a BARE MINIMUM of $1200.

If we are so fortunate to raise more than $1200, the rest of the money will go to funding sets, props, costumes, marketing, and the concessions that will be free for anyone with a ticket, including you!


Why the Living Room?

The aim is to make the performing arts as accessible as possible. In the time of streaming media and entertainment, when we can watch just about anything we want whenever we want in the comfort of our own homes, many of us forgo seeing a play for the next episode of our favorite show on Netflix. Hune Company is interested in the alternative effects of theatre, other than submissive entertainment, because we can sit and watch really amazing shows at home without spending much of anything.

To us, theatre is more about the communal aspect than anything else. There is a magnetic power to a story when the storytellers are live in the room with a group of hungry observers. More than observers - participants. When we watch a live performance in the same small room as the actors, we automatically become active participants in the telling of that particular story on that particular night. Making this all happen in the confined comfort of a living room makes everyone in the room part of the story. It makes it accessible. 

Theatre is a communal practice. At its core is the definition of “local.”  It brings people together in one location to share experiences that inspire a community to relate with each other and grow. We aim to make the Living Room Series a place where artists and audiences express themselves and explore their identity as a community. We hope for it to serve as a tiny town hall; a place in which people can gather and debate current issues through great art. And also a place where people can gather and have a great time.

CORE BELIEFS:

COLLABORATION – We seek to collaborate with artists of different mediums to devise interdisciplinary work that is for the people.

IMAGINATION –Every performance will pursue to be a highly imaginative experience for all audience members and artists involved. We want to experiment with the way theatre is created and presented so that it will be entertaining in the most profound sense.

DIVERSITY – We are dedicated to creating and nourishing a diverse environment. The shows presented will reflect the diversity and richness of Houston and our nation’s society and history.

QUALITY – In order for our mission and values to succeed, we understand that the quality of our programming must be of the highest caliber.


Can't afford to donate right now?

No worries! You can still help. Share this campaign with as many people as you can to get the word out!


THANK YOU for spending time researching Hune Company and the Living Room Series.

THANK YOU for your generous donation!

story:
Help the cast of Into the Woods rent and build a beautiful set. 

Eighteen high school and middle school students in Morgantown have been hard at work the past month rehearsing for Morgantown Theatre Company’s (MTC) production of Into the Woods. Rehearsals have been going splendidly as these enthusiastic and talented students dive into character work, Sondheim's challenging music, choreography, blocking, and much more. 

However,something is missing...  THE SET! 

We are asking the Morgantown community, family and friends of MTC, theatre lovers, and supporters of children and the arts to help MTC and the cast raise money to rent and build our set. 

Our Goal is to raise $10,000 in the next 60 days. 

Morgantown Theatre Company, a non-profit 501(c) 3 organization, provides theatre arts education for children of all ages. Programs range from once a week drama classes to full scale productions performed at the Metropolitan Theatre on High Street. However, these high quality shows also have high production costs such as rights and licensing, costumes, advertising, and set. 

How can you help Morgantown Theatre Company step INTO THE WOODS?!

You can help our adventure Into the Woods by donating to our project, “Morgantown Theatre Company's Into the Woods". Click the contribute now button in the top right corner. 

Finally, we also invite you to come to the show!  

Performances are May 22-24. All performances are in the Metropolitan Theatre at 369 High Street, Morgantown WV. 

Tickets: Adult $10; Child $8

For more information and tickets please visit www.morgantowntheatrecompany.org.
story_txt: Help the cast of Into the Woods rent and build a beautiful set. Eighteen high school and middle school students in Morgantown have been hard at work the past month rehearsing for Morgantown Theatre Company’s (MTC) production of Into the Woods. Rehearsals have been going splendidly as these enthusiastic and talented students dive into character work, Sondheim's challenging music, choreography, blocking, and much more. However,something is missing...  THE SET! We are asking the Morgantown community, family and friends of MTC, theatre lovers, and supporters of children and the arts to help MTC and the cast raise money to rent and build our set. Our Goal is to raise $10,000 in the next 60 days. Morgantown Theatre Company, a non-profit 501(c) 3 organization, provides theatre arts education for children of all ages. Programs range from once a week drama classes to full scale productions performed at the Metropolitan Theatre on High Street. However, these high quality shows also have high production costs such as rights and licensing, costumes, advertising, and set. How can you help Morgantown Theatre Company step INTO THE WOODS?!You can help our adventure Into the Woods by donating to our project, “Morgantown Theatre Company's Into the Woods". Click the contribute now button in the top right corner. Finally, we also invite you to come to the show!  Performances are May 22-24. All performances are in the Metropolitan Theatre at 369 High Street, Morgantown WV. Tickets: Adult $10; Child $8For more information and tickets please visit www.morgantowntheatrecompany.org.

story:
What is North Canadian River?

Remember summer camp? Adventures, pranks, cabins, snoring bunkmates, stuffy councilors, poison ivy, and camp crushes? But at your camp you probably didn't get swept down a river with a  band of rogues from the rival camp with no way of finding home!

North Canadian River tells the story of two groups of campers who get swept downstream during a prank war gone wrong. It's a fun, nostalgic trip down memory lane the whole family can enjoy. The play is presented in Putnam County Spelling Bee style, where all the characters will be played by adult performers.

Speaking of performers, did you know that in many cases theatre performers are forced to pay costume fees to be a part of shows? Well, we're doing things different. No performer will be charged to be a part of North Canadian River. And they'll get paid for their time, too!

After the Show...

At North Canadian, we believe that no one should be priced out of theatre. So after the first run, North Canadian River will be available to license directly from the playwright, bypassing the traditional method of expensive publishing houses. By donating, you will not only help to bring this production of North Canadian River to life, but many, many more productions after.

What Will it Cost?

We're asking for $15,000 in flexible funding. This will go towards:

  • Theater rental
  • Props and Costumes
  • Lighting
  • Sound
  • Set Construction
  • Crew
  • Performers
  • Other expenses

Need More Convincing?

This is a family-friendly show - Everyone can enjoy the theatre without worry!

Ethical business practices - People will get paid and performers will not be charged to be a part

Growth in the theatre community - NCR's licensing model opens up theatre to people who are otherwise priced out.

Can't Donate Right Now? 

You can still help! Here's a list of things that you can do that are totally free:

  • Share the IndieGoGo Page
  • Like Our Facebook @NorthCanadianRiver
  • Follow us on Twitter @RiverCanadian
  • Tell your friends and family

story:
Togetherness Campaign

We at Unit Souzou are blazing a bold trail at the dawn of this new decade. After more than 3 years of planning, research, development, and community engagement - and decades of creation, vision, and evolution - this year we are thrilled to debut our most ambitious original taiko project to date - Constant State of Otherness. Through a rich creation process, we have been digging deep on our own and with community members to uncover universal stories of otherness, identity, belonging, and displacement. Our intent: encourage empathy and build bridges of understanding and connection in our communities. With that in mind, we are excited to launch our Togetherness Campaign to support this exciting, original new work.

Our goal is to raise $7,000 to support the last stretch to create this debut production. Will you join together with us as one of our friends in 2020 to help us reach our goal?

About Constant State of Otherness: building bridges of empathy through the power of stories

Constant State of Otherness seeks to question, challenge, and disrupt the mainstream narrative of identity and belonging, especially within this current American landscape. We are discovering and revealing the universality of otherness with the hope of deconstructing our increasingly fractured communities. We are using our authentic artistic voices to empower community-driven storytelling, build deeper relationships, and encourage pathways for empathy.

Exploring the feelings of isolation and displacement that come from a sense of not fitting in, we are in the process of conducting community workshops across the country, to support individuals in claiming their identity stories. Using our bodies and rhythm through the powerful beats of taiko, we engage groups with the following questions: “How have I been othered? How have I othered myself? How have I othered others?” Stories, ideas, and material generated in these workshops are informing the creation of the new original performance production, set to premiere in May followed by the debut tour throughout the United States. We have amazing partners who are not only producing these premiere performances, but also have been integral in the development process, allowing us to embed ourselves in residence with their communities: The Myrna Loy in Helena, MT, Asian Arts Initiative in Philadelphia, PA; Dance Place in Washington DC; Caldera Arts in Sisters, OR; and Risk/Reward in Portland, OR.

The full theatrical production will be a rich tapestry of powerful sound and movement, stories and text. Constant State of Otherness will be a unique taiko performance. By building bridges and frameworks of empathy, participants and audiences will witness a show rooted in the art forms of Japanese folk dance, taiko and theatre, and be encouraged to open and deepen connections across diverse perspectives.

It takes a village to make art!

Creating this work has been so meaningful, and we need your help during this last stretch. Ticket sales and grant funding have covered a portion of our costs. Our Indiegogo campaign goal is to enlist 202 friends to raise $7000 so that we can successfully cross the finish line.

Here is what your generous contribution would support:  

  • Rehearsal space rental for our final ensemble residency in April
  • Performance space rental for our March Otherness: Togetherness collaborative show
  • Artistic team and technical collaborators (including our set designer, lighting designer, costume designer, dramaturg, Unit Souzou ensemble)

About Unit Souzou’s journey to Constant State of Otherness

'Souzou' can be written in three ways meaning 'creation' (創造), 'imagination' (想), or 'noisy' (騒々), alluding to a force by which new ideas are born and take shape in the world. Inspired by these words, the mission of Unit Souzou is to build creative, imaginative works while honoring the history and roots of the taiko art form. 

Founded in 2014 by Michelle Fujii and Toru Watanabe, Unit Souzou is committed to devising contemporary, relevant performance works with diverse multidisciplinary influences, while balancing the fragility and nuance of honoring the history of Japanese art forms. Developed over decades of experience, the core of our artistic voice is personal and authentic, sound shaped and inspired by form and by movement, forging new traditions for evolving communities. 

Our work is rooted in our cultural perspectives, and we have been breaking boundaries in the form as we respond to relevant issues and topics we are passionate about exploring. In this case, stories of otherness and loneliness which are at once extremely personal and universal. This project is also a reflection of our deepening exploration of place and community as part of the creative process. These efforts serve to support authentic relationship building and community storytelling through our community engagement activities, making the content and form of the work accessible and relevant to the communities we seek to serve. We strive to make an impact on the communities we engage with to share histories and experiences, building bridges and empathy.

The Otherness Tour

March 21-22, 2020
Portland, OR  Otherness: Togetherness
New Expressive Works
Tickets on sale!
Otherness: Togetherness will feature our collaborative work with Horatio Law, a Chinese American visual installation artist and Joe Kye, a Korean American violinist-looper coming together to share stories of experiences grappling with ideas of identity, home, otherness. 

May 1, 2020
Helena, MT Constant State of Otherness Debut
The Myrna Loy
Lead commissioner, The Myrna Loy, will present the premiere of the full-length theatrical production, Constant State of Otherness.

May 9-10, 2020
Washington, DC Constant State of Otherness
Dance Place (NPN Co-commisioner)

May 12, 2020 
Philadelphia, PA Constant State of Otherness
Asian Arts initiative (NPN Co-commissioner)
Tickets on sale soon!

tbd - May 2020
Minneapolis, MN Constant State of Otherness
Taiko Arts Midwest 
Tickets on sale soon!

June 6-7, 2020
Sisters, OR Constant State of Otherness/Hearth Festival
Caldera (NPN Co-commisioner) 
Tickets on sale soon!
2-day festival with site-specific performances of Constant State of Otherness performed throughout the Caldera space. 

October 24-25, 2020
Portland, OR 
Risk Reward (NPN Co-commissioner)
Tickets on sale soon!

    Can't contribute at this time? Here are other ways to help:

    • Buy a ticket and come to the Otherness: Togetherness show
    • Bring a friend to the show!
    • Share this campaign with your social networks
    • Bloggers: write about us!
    • Take a Unit Souzou taiko class

story:
'Blunted'

Human life is worth more than £32 and a mobile phone

Stupid acts of violence are in the news every day, but we often don’t hear about what happens to those who are left to cope long after the media has disappeared. Alice Brockway is a Manchester based actress who has written a play about this very subject for Manchester’s prestigious 24:7 Theatre Festival.

The play is called ‘Blunted’ and Alice has managed to attract a high-quality director and excellent professional actors to help her stage seven performances in July this year. Director Helen Parry has a long history of producing wonderful pieces throughout the North West and she is being joined by former Brookside actor Andrew Fillis.

 

Project aims

First and foremost the project aims to raise awareness about the plight of those left behind after a tragedy and to raise the questions about why they happen. The festival as a whole engages widely with the local community and in the long-run we would hope to develop 'Blunted' and take it further afield.

For the people involved this is a major industry showcase. Previous plays have been developed and toured, published and even produced in the West End. Actors and directors have been picked up for all kinds of projects regionally and nationally.

We will also be collecting for the charity Victim Support throughout the festival.

 

What we need

With everything pared back to the bone the absolute minimum cost will be £859, but this sum does not include payment or even expenses for the director, actors and production staff. £1659 will allow us to offer the team a very minimal fee to cover individual costs (see below).

 

We are asking for contributions of ANY size to help towards this project.

story:
My Story:

Hello friends (I'm a firm believer there are no strangers but only friends you haven’t met yet), I'm sure you've heard the terms starving student and starving actor..... What do you call it when you're both? I wonder what you call it when you're both?

I am a Newfie turned bluenoser who has been living in Halifax, NS Canada for the last ten years. While in Halifax I completed my theatre degree in Acting at Dalhousie University. Last year I enrolled in the East 15 International Acting School in the two year MFA program that is located in Loughton, Essex England and I just completed my first year. The program challenged me and helped me hone my skills in my craft as well innately changed me as a person.

As I'm sure you can imagine this is an expensive endeavor. I have taken on student loans, have worked and saved and bleed my poor parents dry. It is now time to get creative. With one year of school left I refuse to give up now. I am asking for contributions of any amount to help me with my final year of school. No amount is too small and no amount is too large. (LOL!). If you choose to contribute not only will it be greatly appreciated it will contribute directly to my tuition costs and therefore my future.  

 

What your contributions will help with:

My tuition for the year is a little over $20,000 Canadian. Living expenses in the UK is roughtly $15,000-$20,000 a year Canadian. Your contributions will go directly towards my tuition.

story:
Short Summary

Margarita and Max will be presented at the Midtown International Theatre Festival July 23rd, 27th and 28th. A fairy tale for the 21st century about a lonely young woman  a windy day and a very special plastic bag.  When the Brothers Grimm wrote their story, frogs were everywhere. Some were princes, some were not. Now plastic bags are everywhere and a kiss is still a kiss. It was just a matter of time....

What We Need & What You Get

The largest fiscal needs for this production are, funds to pay submission fees, union fees, rehearsal space fees and to pay the creative team and actors. We also need a little extra dough to make some onstage magic happen. 

Your perks for donating (see below) will be individualized and specific to this show! One of the many advantages to creating new material is that you can intimately include your audience.

All donations made to the Margarita and Max campaign, no matter how large or small, are 100% tax-deducitble.

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you think this project sounds awesome but you just don't have the cash to donate?  Good news!  You can still help!  

Share this campaign on Facebook or Twitter! Getting the word out is half the battle! 

Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us promote this project!  

 

Margarita and Max, a new play by Manuel Igrejas Starring Kim McKean and Craig Fox. Directed by David Hilder

A Co-Production with the Midtown International Theatre Festival

Three perfs: Tuesday, July 23rd, Saturday, July 27th 

and Sunday, July 28th. 

At the Dorothy Strelsin Theater, 312 West 36th St.   

Margarita is having a rough time.  She’s unemployed, broke and newly unattached.  She’s on her way to catch a bus to New York City to interview for a menial job she probably won’t get. She could use a miracle. A strong spring breeze blows one of those ubiquitous black plastic bags into her path…and into her life. This is no ordinary bag and this is no ordinary day.

 Manuel Igrejas’ previous plays include Shrinkage, Kitty and Lina, Miss Mary Dugan and Hassan and Sylvia (both Fresh Fruit Festival Best Play winners.) Margarita and Max is directed by David Hilder who won the 2009 Best Director Award at the Fresh Fruit Festival and directed Hassan and Sylvia. His other NYC credits include Blogologues and Daddy.           

Margarita and Max stars Kim McKean and Craig Fox. A recent transplant to New York, Kim McKean has extensive theater credits in Chicago and California and has appeared on HBO’s “True Blood” and ABC’s “Private Practice.” Craig Fox has performed with the Texas Shakespeare Festival, the Lark Theatre and NY Stage and Film. He won the Best Actor Award in the Fresh Fruit Festival for Miss Mary Dugan in 2009 and reprised the role of Kevin Pecinka in 2012. He can be seen at HA! Comedy Club and clubs all over NYC. 

The Midtown International Theatre Festival’s 2013 Season runs from July 15 – August 4, 2013.  John Chatterton created the MITF in 2000, a Midtown alternative to other theatre festivals, as a way to present the finest Off-Off Broadway talent in convenience, comfort, and safety.  The MITF’s artistic emphasis is on the script itself, and therefore the Festival focuses on effective but minimal production values. For more information, visit www.midtownfestival.org.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Margarita and Maxby Manuel Igrejas, part of the Midtown International Theatre Festival

Starring Kim McKean and Craig Fox. Directed by David Hilder

Schedule: Tuesday, July 23rd at 7:30pm, Saturday, July 27th at 6pm, Sunday, July 28th at 8:30pm

Dorothy Strelsin Theater, 312 West 36th St. (1st floor) Running time: 60 minutes

Admission: $15. For tickets: www.midtownfestival.org. Or call: 866 811 4111.

story:
The Nomad Theater Project

The Nomad Theater was built in Boulder, CO in 1951 and is one of Colorado's oldest theaters. Once a cultural hub, this theater in North Boulder has seen its share of wear and tear over the years.

So, a local group of citizens, students, and musicians have taken it upon themselves to organize this fundraising campaign. The vision is to turn the theater into a modern, independent movie theater and music room. A place to get a bottle of wine and relax with friends over a film or watch a professional recording session.

On April 6th, there will be a benefit concert held at the 2,000 seat Macky Auditorium on the CU-Boulder campus. 

The money raised will go to state of the art

  • Audio Equipment
  • Projector
  • A New Screen
  • A Complete Renovation of the lobby, seats, and stage
  • A New Website

 

What We Need and What You Get

Or goal is to raise at least $20,000 to get this project under way. This is a very small budget for a project of this scale. A local group of citizens have already put in much of their own money and volunteered their time to get production for the benefit concert underway.

Any contribution, big or small, is greatly appreciated! If we surpass our goal of $20,000, the renovation will be that much better. 100% of the proceeds from the fundraising campaign go to the renovation of the theater.

We are offering a number of benefits for your generous donations, including

  • A limited edition event poster
  • An "I Support The Nomad" sticker
  • "Meet & Greet" passes for the benefit concert
  • Private Luxury Box at the Macky Auditorium
  • An entire balcony section for you and your friends/coworkers

Songs for The Nomad

 

Meet & Greet 5:00-5:45 (pass and ticket must be purchased)

"Songs for The Nomad: A Benefit for the Nomad Theater" will take place Saturday, April 6th at Macky Auditorium in Boulder, Colorado. The event will feature special performances by members of:

  • Yonder Mountain String Band
  • The Head & The Heart
  • The Infamous Stringdusters
  • Rose Hill Drive

Along With...

  • West Water Outlaws
  • Reed Foehl
  • The Boulder School of Rock
  • A Special Beatles Tribute Set featuring Dr. Robert
  • Many Surprise Guests...

Tickets are just $15 for students and $20 for the general public. Tickets can be purchased at Macky.Colorado.Edu .

Many other bands that can't attend, also wanted to help. So, we're holding a special on-site silent auction featuring signed memorabilia from:

  • Widespread Panic
  • Wilco
  • Michael Franti
  • Pretty Lights
  • Blind Pilot
  • Andrew Bird
  • Ani DiFranco
  • The String Cheese Incident
  • Keller Williams
  • Churchill
  • Infamous Stringdusters
  • Josh Ritter
  • Wood Brothers
  • Gregory Alan Isakov
  • Ingrid Michaelson
  • Ben Sollee
  • Brandi Carlile
  • Pickwick

And many more are signing on each day...

 

Other Ways to Help

We understand that some of you may not be able to contribute financially. So, please tell your friends about us and "like" us at www.Facebook.com/TheNomadTheater for more info. 

Thanks so much! 

*Artists subject to change
story_txt:
The Nomad Theater Project
The Nomad Theater was built in Boulder, CO in 1951 and is one of Colorado's oldest theaters. Once a cultural hub, this theater in North Boulder has seen its share of wear and tear over the years.
So, a local group of citizens, students, and musicians have taken it upon themselves to organize this fundraising campaign. The vision is to turn the theater into a modern, independent movie theater and music room. A place to get a bottle of wine and relax with friends over a film or watch a professional recording session.
On April 6th, there will be a benefit concert held at the 2,000 seat Macky Auditorium on the CU-Boulder campus. 
The money raised will go to state of the art

Audio Equipment
Projector
A New Screen
A Complete Renovation of the lobby, seats, and stage
A New Website

 


What We Need and What You Get

story:
Hey everyone -- as many of you know I have been hoping and waiting to meet the love of my life, Justin Drew Bieber, for many years now, and my chance has FINALLY come!!! Justin has signed up for Virgin Galactic's Trip to Space & I NEED to be on that shuttle with him. I cannot express what this would mean to me to be able to spend this time with him, in such a close environment. Plus, I have never been to space and that would just be such an experience for me and the love of my life to have together!
 
The cost to sign up & have the opportunity to join my future husband in space is $200,000 and sadly, I just don't have that money right now. I can donate close to $173 to my fund, and will need the help of friends, family, and all you beliebers out there to make this happen, so please donate!
 
Also, if anyone out there knows Mr. Bieber personally, please feel free to have him contact me directly to organize our romantic getaway. Thank you all and remember, #NEVERSAYNEVER!!

story:
Magis is headed to the New York International Fringe Festival!!!

For over a year and a half, we have been developing our original adaptation of Plutus, god of Wealth by the great comedian Aristophanes.  And now the time has come for the world to see it as Occupy Olympus, with original music from internationally acclaimed, award-winning composer Elizabeth Swados, and directed by Artistic Director George Drance.

For nearly ten years, Magis has produced a variety of actor-driven, physically-based theatre productions that explore the human condition. Deemed "long on theatrical skill" and "thought provoking," our original adaptation of C.S. Lewis' novel The Great Divorce has now been produced close to a dozen times at theaters and institutions all over the world.  The New York Times has declared us "...daring to be different" and also praised our most recent production of Shakuntala and the Ring of Recognition in 2010 as "imaginatively staged...[with] visually appealing use of elemental stagecraft..."

With a mission that is built on training, teaching and acting, we focus on presenting neglected classics that inspire possibilites in the both the actor and the audience. In this light, staying true to our identity, we honed in on Plutus, a positively prophetic comedy about wealth, greed, and the disparity between rich and poor. Sound familiar? That's right, over 2400 years before Wall Street was occupied, Aristophanes was doing his best to expose the system, too.

Unfortunately, the inequality of wealth in society continues to be an overwhelming issue.  Bail-outs are merely bandages; so it's up to artists like Aristophanes and Magis Theatre Company to continue to tell stories, ask questions and challenge audiences about a seemingly endless financial inequality that affects people throughout the world. 

And so it is with a touch of irony that we ask for your financial support.  Not only will this be a HUGE support in helping us to get this story to the Fringe and to all the people that will attend, but you will be supporting all the artists who dedicated their time, energy, and days off to building this original, world-premiere production - actors, musicians, composers, directors, dramaturgs, stage managers and interns.

Taking on the Olympian 1%

Our goal is $9000.  Not that insurmountable, right?  Just like the Occupy movements all over the world, all it takes is a little word of mouth.  By spreading the word and sharing this campaign with your friends and family and their friends and family, what starts as a concentrated community of audience spreads and expands and becomes a unified movement.  Every dollar helps and goes right back into the production.  With a little diligence, we will take on Zeus with nothing standing in our way!

Make sure you have a look at our perks.  The more you donate, the more you receive, including our unique Magis training, beneficial for everyone, even if you have never set foot on stage.  Whether you donate as a Choregoi or as an Olympian, we are grateful for all your contributions, and every cent will help us mount our charge.

Join the Movement

Some people just are not able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help! Remember this is Occupy Olympus, and Occupy means action.  We chose this story not because we want to give you solutions to a problem, but because we want to promote awareness and encourage change.  And that is where you come in. 
 
By supporting us you will be supporting action and investigation and possibility. Please, make some noise, make some signs, make some friends and tell them all about our original world premiere production that is headed to the New York City International Fringe Festival!  Share this campaign everywhere - it's really easy to do with Indiegogo's share tools.

And that’s all there is to it.  Oh, and to get a closer look into our process, make sure you have a look at the video above.  It will give you a tangible idea of how we have gone about our process and where we are headed with our story.

Thank you for your support from all of us at the Magis Theatre Company!

story:
News broke in August that the Sears Festivals lost their main source of funding, thus putting an end to festivals that are part of Canadian theatre's DNA. The reaction from students, parents, teachers, and their local communities was swift and devastating.

Here is your chance to make a difference!

In September, the Stratford Festival pledged to make a contribution. We are pleased to announce their support in the form of a $5,000 matching gift if we make our campaign goal!"

These beloved local Drama Festivals are essential to drama programs in Ontario, BC and the Atlantic provinces. They provide opportunities for thousands of high school students to convene every year to share ideas, attend training workshops and, most of all, create new friendships and solidify artistic bonds.

While the National Theatre School of Canada (NTS) and the IATSE have joined forces to help secure the presentation of the 2018 edition of the Drama Festival, this edition cannot happen without you. Kids around the country are already hard at work putting on compelling plays, and right now, each community needs to step up.

Your donations will help fund:

  • Travel subsidies for students to participate.
  • Bursaries/prizes to young artists
  • Showcase costs
  • Adjudication and workshops for young artists

For any donation over $250, please contact Jean Stutsman at NTS Development office: jeanstutsman@ent-nts.ca or by phone at 514 842-7954, ext. 141. To give online: www.ent-nts.ca/en/support-nts.

Link to the press release: https://ent-nts.ca/en/iatse-and-nts-help-secure...

 

Q&A

1) What is the Sears Drama Festival?

The Sears Drama Festival showcases high school theatre productions in their respective provinces and convenes thousands of students to perform and compete in a friendly atmosphere. Founded in 1946, it is Canada’s oldest theatre festival. It helped launch the careers of numerous actors, directors and production professionals, including actors Margot Kidder, Rachel McAdams, Yanna McIntosh and R.H. Thomson, as well as movie director David Cronenberg.

2) Why can’t NTS provide 100% of the funding?

Alone, NTS does not have the means to fund single-handedly such a big festival. As a non-profit organisation, we operate on a tight budget: thus, we must rely on donations from communities and generous partners to ensure the future of the Festival.

3) What if I want a tax receipt?

It will be our pleasure to issue you a tax receipt for your donation. Please contact Claudine Jacques at NTS Development office: claudinejacques@ent-nts.ca or by phone at 514 842-7954, ext. 149. To give online: www.ent-nts.ca/en/support-nts.

4) But won’t the Festival cost much more than $10,000?

Indeed! The total budget for the Festival is roughly $200,000. The crowdfunding campaign is set at $10,000. The NTS will provide administrative and some financial support. The IATSE and Stratford Festival have just confirmed support: however, additional sources of income must urgently be found.

5) What are the dates of the 2018 edition?

Executive Director Wayne Fairhead is currently coordinating the dates of the 2018 edition. They will be posted on the various Festival websites as they become available. Stay tuned!

For Ontario: http://www.searsdramafestival.com

For British Columbia: http://www.searsbcdramafest.com/

For Atlantic provinces: http://watermarktheatre.com/programs/sears-dram...

6) How can I help, if I have no money?

We still need your voice even if you cannot currently contribute financially. Take part in this exciting opportunity to promote theatre Canada-wide by sharing this campaign with your family and friends using the power of social media. Tell them why the Festival’s survival matters to you!

_________________________

En août dernier, la nouvelle s’est répandue que les festivals de théâtre Sears de l’Ontario, de la Colombie-Britannique et de l’Atlantique avaient perdu leur principale source de financement, menaçant ainsi la survie de ces festivals qui font partie de l’ADN du théâtre canadien. Les étudiants, les parents, les professeurs, les communautés locales ainsi que la communauté théâtrale ont été secoués en apprenant la nouvelle, et plusieurs ont exprimé leur désarroi.

Voici maintenant votre chance de faire une différence!

En septembre, le célèbre Festival Stratford a annoncé qu’il apporterait sa contribution. Nous sommes heureux d'annoncer son soutien de 5,000$ à notre campagne si nous atteignons notre objectif financier de 10,000$.

Ces festivals de théâtre sont essentiels aux programmes d’art dramatique de l’Ontario, de la Colombie-Britannique et des provinces de l’Atlantique. Ils donnent l’opportunité à des milliers de jeunes du niveau secondaire de se réunir chaque année afin de partager leurs idées, de participer à des ateliers, et de manière encore plus importante, de créer de nouvelles amitiés et de solidifier des liens artistiques.

Bien que l’IATSE et l’École nationale de théâtre du Canada (ÉNT) aient uni leurs forces afin d’assurer la présentation de l’édition 2018 des festivals, cette édition ne peut avoir lieu sans vous! Les jeunes partout au pays sont déjà à élaborer des pièces de théâtre captivantes, et c’est maintenant que chaque communauté doit faire preuve de solidarité.

Vos dons aideront à financer :

  • Les frais de déplacement pour les participants
  • Les bourses et prix pour les jeunes artistes
  • Les coûts de représentation
  • La rémunération des juges et les ateliers pour les jeunes artistes

Pour tout don de 250$ et plus, veuillez communiquer avec Jean Stutsman au bureau du développement de l’ÉNT: jeanstutsman@ent-nts.ca ou par téléphone au 514 842-7954, ext. 141. Pour donner en ligne: www.ent-nts.ca/fr/soutenez-ent.

Lien vers le communiqué de presse: https://ent-nts.ca/fr/l-iatse-et-l-ent-assurent...

story:
As one of the largest Music societies at King’s College London, King’s Opera is increasingly looking to expand its repertoire and the performance opportunities offered to students of the University of London colleges. King’s Opera stages between two to four productions a year as well as embarking, this year, on a Musical collaboration with King’s College London Symphony Orchestra.  The society aims to maintain a professional, high standard whilst experimenting in its settings of more traditional productions such as Mozart’s Marriage of Figaro and Bizet’s Le docteur Miracle.

This  group includes cast members from King’s College London and conservatoires such as the Royal Academy of Music and the Guildhall School of Music and Drama. We also have a fantastic team of professional mentors, including early music specialist, O-J Ruthven (English Touring Opera, Musica Poetica, Royal Opera); Designer, Sunny Smith (National Theatre, Opera Holland Park); Stage Manager, Rosie Cassell (Silent Opera, Royal Opera); and Director, Ruth Knight (Opera Holland Park, Garsington Opera, Royal Opera).

The production is Handel’s Julius Caesar, featuring a brand new translation by Ruth Knight. The opera explores Julius Caesar’s burgeoning relationship with Cleopatra, his rivalry with her brother Tolomeo, and the ensuing battle of the Nile. We are setting the production in 1920s Egypt, 200 years after Handel finished his original score. In 1922, Egypt officially became independent from Britain, and Tutankhamun’s tomb was discovered by Howard Carter and Lord Carnarvon. This led to a sudden rush of Egyptophilia in Western culture, which persisted until the 1930s and heavily influenced the art deco movement. Our Caesar will be presented as a young, starched British Emperor, with the Egyptians as licentious, martini-swilling fashionistas (rather than the ‘barbarians’ described in the original libretto).

Sadly, the arts budget at King’s has been brutally slashed over the past few years, meaning that we have received a very small budget of £1,000 for the production. All artists and production team members have donated their fees, and have sucessfully fundraised an additional £1,300 (with particular thanks to the Bernarr Rainbow Trust, Mr Leslie Macleod-Miller, The Lord Knight of Weymouth, Mr and Mrs Jonathan Renfrew-Knight, and Mr and Mrs Maxwell Howlett). However, we are still £700 away from our target! For this reason, we need to reach out to our friends for their help! This extra money will help us to ensure adequate production values and the best possible platform for these talented young artists.

story:
**Important** - some contributors have been encountering difficulties when trying to input their card details. This is because it is unclear that a post code needs to be added to the box after you input your security code. Please persevere, or drop us an email on unsungplay@gmail.com if you've been trying to contribute but aren't managing to get through! Thank you!

​Unsung: The Story So Far

‘Unsung’ is a project that began development in March 2017, supported by Arts Council England. Producer Alice Barber, Director Elvi Piper, four fantastic actresses and a Technical Director came together with two key aims:

  • To devise a piece of theatre that interrogated in a lively and playful way the underrepresentation of women in history, the theatre, and society at large.
  • To create four complex and interesting protagonists for the ensemble to get their teeth into.

We performed our research to an audience of arts professionals and community members to gather feedback. Ultimately, throughout 2018 we will tour the finished piece around Yorkshire, the North West, and beyond, sharing the incredible stories we’ve uncovered.

Our Unsung Heroes: Who Were They?

Ada Lovelace (1815-1852), a talented mathematician who composed the first algorithm for the Analytical Engine. She is hailed as the world’s first computer programmer, and was a visionary by today's standards. 

Sophia Jex-Blake (1840 – 1912), a medic and the first woman to be permitted to study at a UK university; her pioneering persistence to fight for her right to education paved the way for women today. 

Lilian Bailey (1918 – 2015), one of the first black women to serve in the British Armed Forces. Despite facing racial prejudice, she enlisted with the Women’s Auxiliary Air Force and soon gained the rank of Acting Corporal. (Please note: in the initial presentation of ideas, Dorothy Lawrence was the third woman we focussed on. However, our audience feedback concluded that Lilian's story was one to which more people could relate). 

Andrea Dunbar (1961 – 1990), the Bradford born author of Rita, Sue and Bob Too and The Arbor. Acclaimed as ‘a genius straight from the slums’, she wrote The Arbor as an assignment for GCE English at the age of only 15.

What’s Next?

The next phase of the show’s development is comprised of two key strands:

  • The development of a full script in collaboration with writer Lisa Holdsworth (Midsomer Murders, New Tricks)
  • Two weeks’ rehearsal and development activity in October and November hosted by Square Chapel Centre for the Arts in Halifax, culminating in an informal performance to venue programmers from across the region. All contributors to our campaign, no matter much much or little they donate, will also receive an invitation to this performance, and to all future work-in-progress performances.

Why We Need Your Support

The first stage of Unsung’s development was successfully funded by Arts Council England.  We are confident we can make another strong funding bid for this stage, however the project cannot be funded by the Arts Council alone – we need your help, too.

The rehearsal period and creation of the script will go ahead no matter how much we manage to raise. So even if we don’t reach our entire goal, you can be sure that whatever you pledge will go towards paying the creative team fairly for the fantastic work they do.

The Impact: How We’re Going To Change The World

We want to raise public awareness of our four protagonists’ incredible achievements, and question why figures like these are so absent from what we, as a nation, are taught of our history. We hope this work will take small but meaningful steps towards altering the narrow perspectives that govern the way in which women are regarded today.

Risks and Challenges

Trying to create new and original theatre in a tough economic climate is always going to be a challenge; however, we are a group of gutsy, passionate and experienced women who are determined to make this happen. We have had the backing of brilliant cultural institutions like Square Chapel, and Slung Low in Leeds, and have already captured the interest of several other theatre venues – and now we need your support!

Ways You Can Help Aside from Donating

We totally understand if you can’t make a donation right now, but we’d be SO grateful if you could support us in any way at all! If you’d like to see this show up and running, you can help by:

  • Following us on Twitter (@unsung_women) and liking us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/unsungwomen/)
  • Sharing this campaign on social media
  • Encouraging anyone you know to head over to our website (https://unsung2017.wixsite.com/unsungplay) and sign up to our mailing list - they’ll be the first to know about any exciting perks we bring out exclusively for our most devoted supporters!
  • Using your influence! Do you have a blog? Are you Insta-famous? Queen of snapchat?! Then please talk about us!
  • Talking to us: do you reckon there's a perk we could be offering, but haven't? Let us know, and we might be able to create it!

Thank you!

And huge thanks to Helen Griffiths Videography for our Trailer (check her out!).

story:
“No man is an island entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main,”

-John Donne

Our name reflects our belief that everyone, no matter their gender, is a crucial piece of the continent. We therefore strive to make them “a part of the main.”

As a company, our mission is threefold:

1. To establish spaces where women theatre artists can come together and create

2. To produce work that reveals the inner lives of women characters

3. To forge a new canon of theatre works by women playwrights.

Part of the Main was started by us, Olivia Munk and Jessica Bickel-Barlow, two emerging theatre makers frustrated by the low percentages of women on creative teams. We decided to address this imbalance by performing work by women, with women technical teams, and majority women casts.

Jessica, who is directing The Squirrel Plays, first came across the piece when she took a screenwriting course with Mia McCullough at Northwestern University. She immediately knew that the witty and darkly comedic tale, which Mia has been adding to since 2005, needed to reach more people. 

We first performed Infestation, the first part of The Squirrel Plays, at the Space Theatre in May 2017. We received overwhelmingly positive audience feedback, which inspired us to pursue producing Infestation alongside its companion play, Compensation. When Olivia received her Tier 1 Graduate Entrepreneur Visa in September of 2018 for the formal creation of Part of the Main, the wheels were set in motion: We wanted to bring The Squirrel Plays to the Fringe. 

Nearly 10 months later, we've not only secured a venue for The Squirrel Plays on  Edinburgh's famed Royal Mile for the whole month of August, but we've also previewed the piece at the Wandsworth Arts Fringe, where we had sell-out shows and excellent reviews (on the weekend of the Royal Wedding, no less!). Soon, we will tour our piece to Theatre503 for two more previews before bringing our company to the largest arts festival in the world. 

We feel honored to have the chance to present a work that deals frankly yet sensitively with reproduction, motherhood, healthcare, and race. Particularly in today's political climate, we believe it is important that we not shy away from social and political issues, but rather address them head on through writing, performance, and production. We're proud that our creative team and the majority of our cast are women, reflecting our ethos of improving the representation of women on stages and in production teams across the UK. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your support will help us in funding:

  • The cost of renting our venue for one month (24 performances) 
  • Travel and accommodation for the cast and crew for the month of August 
  • Marketing materials such as posters and flyers (and, if we're lucky, a full-size squirrel costume for flyering flair on the Royal Mile!) to help us reach as many audience members as possible.

Here's what we're excited to share with our supporters:

  • Shoutouts on our social media pages and website
  • Access to “The Squirrel Stash,” a private portal on our website with exclusive videos, pictures, and other content about the production and the company
  • A video of the production for those who can't make it to Scotland! 

 

Our Impact

After the opening night of our show at the Wandsworth Fringe, Olivia moderated a talkback with Mia, who generously flew into London to attend the final week of rehearsals, and Rosie Peck, a representative from the British Pregnancy Advisory Service. As the performance occurred one week before Ireland voted to strike down the 8th Amendment criminalizing abortion, our conversation focused on the ways in which women around the world - even here in the UK, as well as back at our homes in America - face significant barriers towards managing their own reproduction. 

Far from a theatrical production that exists in a vacuum, The Squirrel Plays is a dynamic text that directly responds to contemporary sociopolitical issues. Our feedback forms from audience members of the Wandsworth performances are striking examples of how this 60-minute piece affects viewers' perspectives:

  • “It brought me much closer to the issue than I’ve ever felt before"
  • “It’s a balanced/ nuanced dissection and it made me consider the other side of the debate and the difficulties of the issue.” 
  • “Made me think about the connection between reproductive justice and racial equality”
  • “Opened up the discussion and displayed a range of views”
  • “Very thought provoking and balanced in addressing varying points of views”
  • “Helped me understand types of discourse/reasons, and why people avoid discourse"
  • “It made me think about the complexity of abortion rights”

Producing The Squirrel Plays at the Edinburgh Fringe provides us with the best opportunity to reach more audience members who come from varying backgrounds and perspectives. 

As these audience testimonials show, this production has the power to change the way we think about and discuss reproductive rights.

About the Playwright: Mia McCullough

Mia is an award-winning playwright (ATCA Obsorn Award, Julie Harris Playwriting Competition, Cincinnati Entertainment Award, Jeff Award) based in Chicago.  Her work has been produced at prestigious theatres such as Steppenwolf, San Diego Old Globe, Chicago Dramatists, and Stage Left. She taught playwriting and screenwriting at Northwestern University for ten years, and last year she published a book called Transforming Reality about the creative writing process. She wrote the first of The Squirrel Plays in 2005 and has been adding to it ever since. She has also been producing a web series, The Haven, which she wrote and created, inspired by many years working at a domestic violence shelter.

Standing Out From the Crowd 

The best thing about the Fringe is that it has nearly 4,000 shows; the worst thing about the Fringe is that it has nearly 4,000 shows.

In order to reach as many audience members as possible, we need a robust and strategic approach to marketing.

Your support will help us:

  • Design and print eye-catching and informative flyers and posters
  • Strategically promote The Squirrel Plays on Facebook and Instagram 
  • Design branded apparel for our cast and crew to wear when flyering on the Royal Mile
  • Design and print a banner promoting the show to use on the Royal Mile 
  • A squirrel costume to wear on the Royal Mile: Edinburgh is cold and rainy in August, so a squirrel costume will be warm, and it will be a great photo opportunity for festival goers, to helping us promote our show through intrigue and word of mouth! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Aside from financial support, there are a number of other ways you can help us spread the word about our production and Part of the Main's mission:

  • Share this campaign on your social media pages, and with friends and family (use the Share buttons on this page)
  • Like us on Facebook and leave a review
  • Follow us on Twitter and Instagram and engage with our posts
  • Come see us in London at our Edinburgh Fringe previews at Theatre503
  • Come see us in Edinburgh, and write us a review on our listing! 
  • Keep on supporting women in the arts!

story:
Moving Stories 

movingstoriesfoundation.com 

movingstepsfoundation.org 

 

Moving Stories is an organization that partners with local organizations to create live, full-length performances integrating storytelling with original music and dance. We are currently partnering with Moving Steps Foundation, a dance company of previously incarcerated women and women in recovery. Together, we are producing the show: Moving Stories. 

Through storytelling, the production seeks to address the epidemics of addiction and over-incarceration within our community. Company members share true stories, told live. We use music and dance to enhance the content of stories told. 

Opioid addiction is a national epidemic, and Massachusetts is one of the states struggling most. For the community to work together to address these challenges, it is vital that general audiences see the faces, and hear the stories, of those who have been affected. 

Our production, Moving Stories, will premiere on Dec. 1st and 2nd at the Dance Complex in Central Square. That is only the beginning. We have big plans for the coming year. But to make them happen, we need your help! 

 

Premiere Performance

We think this show is important--it creates a platform for women to share their stories, while also nurturing their creative selves through dance. The performance promotes awareness, inspires conversation within the community, and diminishes stigma.  

Your donations will go directly towards:

  • Renting rehearsal space, and theatre rental for the performance. 
  • Production costs: Lighting/Sound Designer, Stage Manager, Costumes, Marketing
  • Paying our dancers; it is our goal to treat each of them as professionals 
  • Paying our team of directors

 

Performances in 2018

In 2018, we hope to:

  • Tour the production to theatres and dance venues throughout the greater Boston area, in order to bring these stories to as may audiences as possible. 
  • Give free performances at treatment centers, rehabilitation facilities, reentry homes, and prisons. By performing for others who may be struggling, we hope to offer a message of hope, recovery, and community. 

Your donations will allow us to bring Moving Stories to more audiences throughout the greater Boston area, and to perform for other women in recovery, and those who may be struggling with the effects of incarceration. 

 

Developing an Outreach Program 

Along with expanding our performance scope, in 2018 we are determined to develop an outreach program. We want to provide free arts programming for more women whose lives have been effected by incarceration and addiction. Given the necessary funding, we will: 

  • Offer free music, dance, and storytelling workshops at treatment centers, rehabilitation facilities, reentry homes, and prisons throughout the greater Boston area. 
  • Develop more performances with more groups of women. 
  • Create a platform to bring all of these women together. With programming and performance opportunities, we will continue to develop ways for previously incarcerated women, and women in recovery, to connect with themselves and one another on a creative platform.

 

Learn More

  • To learn more about our project, goals, and company, please visit us at: movingstoriesfoundation.com 
  • To learn more about Moving Steps, please visit: movingstepsfoundation.org 

Thank you so much!

story:
We surpassed our $10,000 goal! Please help us reach our stretch goal of $12,500! The extra funds will go towards artist fees and costumes for the project which has a total project budget of $42,000.

There She Danced

Last spring, I got to dance on Arctic sea ice. Yup, for real! I participated in a polar science mission, as choreographer-in-residence aboard the icebreaker USCGC Healy. While the scientists drilled holes in the ice sheet, I did my own research. Dancing in vast frozen expanses, I tasted the wind, traced the horizon, whirled to my heart's content and, sure, wiped out a few times. Now, I'm using my polar research to transport the Arctic to the stage in a dance production at the JCC Manhattan, June 20-21.
I want to give audiences a visceral connection to a disappearing environment. The program will feature the premiere of Ice Cycle (Phase I), a dance expressing the dynamism and fragility of the Arctic icescape, which I'm choreographing in collaboration with a team of 12 amazing artists. Alaskan-born composer Matthew Burtner, who's done field recordings in the Arctic (even sub-ice!), is creating stellar music. My company of five talented dancers, all women, will perform. And our costume, lighting and projection designers will expand and transform the choreography so that the scene evokes the icescape itself. 
Shipboard, I learned that sea ice has the same composition as human bone. Then it struck me that we're both highly endangered creatures. My aim is to use this show to engage audiences around the issue of climate change. So, in conjunction with the performances, I'm programming two climate-themed panel discussions and a kids climate workshop. 

We Need Your Support

"Bringing the Arctic Home" is an ambitious project with a total budget of $42,000. We've received grants from NYC's Department of Cultural Affairs and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, but we still need your support to make the program a success. Our campaign goal is $10,000, with a stretch goal of $12,500. These funds will help pay the five dancers (Jenny Campbell, Sarah Chien, Maya Orchin, Krissy Tate & Chriselle Tidrick), composer Matthew Burtner, dramaturge Pele Bauch, costume designer Mary Jo Mecca, lighting designer David Ferri and projection designer Matthew Haber. 
The funds will also go towards costume production. We use innovative costumes to suggest the ever-morphing topography of ice. Our costumes require dozens of yards of silk and dozens of hours to create. For a $1,500 contribution you will get naming rights to one of these extraordinary silk concoctions. We will sew your name tag into the costume and you can come to rehearsal and try it out. 
We have lots of other perks at all levels of support from $10 and up, so ANY amount you can give and any LOVE (sharing, liking, commenting) you show the campaign is greatly appreciated. Thank you! 

The Impact

What happens in the Arctic affects us all. We've already lost 80% of the volume of Arctic sea ice. Models predict that by 2040, the Arctic will be ice-free during the summer months. As sea water absorbs more of the sun's radiant heat than ice, which reflects most of it back to the atmosphere, the disappearance of the Arctic ice shelf creates a feedback loop accelerating the effects of climate change. 
We need to face the music and dance . . . about the Arctic! I see this program not just as an elegy for Arctic sea ice, but also a celebration of its staggering beauty and a call to action. 

Biography

I'm a native New Yorker and I founded my dance company, Time Lapse Dance (TLD), in 2000. I’ve produced 12 full-evenings of dance in NYC and have worked throughout the US and in Bahrain, Canada, France, India, Ireland, Italy, The Netherlands, Nigeria, Russia, Scotland and on the Arctic ice sheet. Over the years I’ve developed a signature technique that combines movement with  innovative costuming and lighting. The style draws inspiration from Loie Fuller (1892-1962), an early modern dancer, but I give it my own contemporary spin. I’m recognized as the leading interpreter of Loie’s genre and am proud of expanding upon her legacy.

I’ve received commissions from the Vermont Performance Lab & Marlboro College, The University of Wyoming through the NEA American Masterpieces Program and the Streb Lab for Action Mechanics (S.L.A.M.). My dances have been in the repertory of Holland’s Introdans ensemble. I’ve performed, taught and/or residencies at colleges and universities including Vassar College, UMass Amherst, Hofstra University, De Sales University, Muhlenberg College, Wilson College, University of Nebraska, Hobart & William Smith Colleges, University of Wyoming, Marlboro College, Florida State University and others.

I studied at the Joffrey Ballet School, attended Stuyvesant HS and Wesleyan University (where I majored in Dance and Italian). Then went to NYU, earning an M.A. in Performance Studies. Since then, I danced professionally (with choreographers including Sarah Michelson and Yvonne Rainer) and choreographed my own work. I've also written about dance for Dance Magazine, The Village Voice, The SDHS Conference Proceedings, The International Encyclopedia of Dance and the book Birds of Paradise: Costume as Cinematic Spectacle (British Film Institute, 2014).

Press

ORIGIN MAGAZINE, April 2015 Issue

On the Cover, find my picture next to Robert Redford & Julia Roberts! 

Inside, I'm featured in Top 100 Creatives.

DANCE TEACHER MAGAZINE - MAY 2015 ISSUE

Great article about my experience in the Arctic and the project.


The Time Lapse Dance Team

Artistic Director: Jody Sperling

Administrator (& Company Dancer): Krissy Tate

Intern: Micheala Macauley

Dancers: Jenny Campbell, Sarah Chien, Maya Orchin, Krissy Tate & Chriselle Tidrick

Composer: Matthew Burtner

Lighting: David Ferri | Projection Designer: Matthew Haber

Dramaturge: Pele Bauch

Costume Designer: Mary Jo Mecca | Textile Artist: Mary Jo Mecca

Time Lapse Dance Board of Directors: Meeta Anand, Ginnine Cocuzza, Iris Fodor, Gail Papp, Janet Wolfe

Special Thanks to: Dr. Robert Pickart of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution for inviting me on the Healy 1401 cruise; the entire 1401 crew, outreach and science party who opened my eyes up to a whole world and helped me immensely with the project; Larry Pratt for helping to set this project in motion.

Jody Sperling/Time Lapse Dance, Inc. is a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation.
story_txt:
We surpassed our $10,000 goal! Please help us reach our stretch goal of $12,500! The extra funds will go towards artist fees and costumes for the project which has a total project budget of $42,000.
There She Danced

Last spring, I got to dance on Arctic sea ice. Yup, for real! I participated in a polar science mission, as choreographer-in-residence aboard the icebreaker USCGC Healy. While the scientists drilled holes in the ice sheet, I did my own research. Dancing in vast frozen expanses, I tasted the wind, traced the horizon, whirled to my heart's content and, sure, wiped out a few times. Now, I'm using my polar research to transport the Arctic to the stage in a dance production at the JCC Manhattan, June 20-21.
I want to give audiences a visceral connection to a disappearing environment. The program will feature the premiere of Ice Cycle (Phase I), a dance expressing the dynamism and fragility of the Arctic icescape, which I'm choreographing in collaboration with a team of 12 amazing artists. Alaskan-born composer Matthew Burtner, who's done field recordings in the Arctic (even sub-ice!), is creating stellar music. My company of five talented dancers, all women, will perform. And our costume, lighting and projection designers will expand and transform the choreography so that the scene evokes the icescape itself. 
Shipboard, I learned that sea ice has the same composition as human bone. Then it struck me that we're both highly endangered creatures. My aim is to use this show to engage audiences around the issue of climate change. So, in conjunction with the performances, I'm programming two climate-themed panel discussions and a kids climate workshop. 



We Need Your Support

"Bringing the Arctic Home" is an ambitious project with a total budget of $42,000. We've received grants from NYC's Department of Cultural Affairs and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, but we still need your support to make the program a success. Our campaign goal is $10,000, with a stretch goal of $12,500. These funds will help pay the five dancers (Jenny Campbell, Sarah Chien, Maya Orchin, Krissy Tate & Chriselle Tidrick), composer Matthew Burtner, dramaturge Pele Bauch, costume designer Mary Jo Mecca, lighting designer David Ferri and projection designer Matthew Haber. 
The funds will also go towards costume production. We use innovative costumes to suggest the ever-morphing topography of ice. Our costumes require dozens of yards of silk and dozens of hours to create. For a $1,500 contribution you will get naming rights to one of these extraordinary silk concoctions. We will sew your name tag into the costume and you can come to rehearsal and try it out. 
We have lots of other perks at all levels of support from $10 and up, so ANY amount you can give and any LOVE (sharing, liking, commenting) you show the campaign is greatly appreciated. Thank you! 
The Impact
What happens in the Arctic affects us all. We've already lost 80% of the volume of Arctic sea ice. Models predict that by 2040, the Arctic will be ice-free during the summer months. As sea water absorbs more of the sun's radiant heat than ice, which reflects most of it back to the atmosphere, the disappearance of the Arctic ice shelf creates a feedback loop accelerating the effects of climate change. 
We need to face the music and dance . . . about the Arctic! I see this program not just as an elegy for Arctic sea ice, but also a celebration of its staggering beauty and a call to action.

Over the years I’ve developed a signature technique that combines movement with  innovative costuming and lighting. The style draws inspiration from Loie Fuller (1892-1962), an early modern dancer, but I give it my own contemporary spin. I’m recognized as the leading interpreter of Loie’s genre and am proud of expanding upon her legacy.I’ve received commissions from the Vermont Performance Lab & Marlboro College, The University of Wyoming through the NEA American Masterpieces Program and the Streb Lab for Action Mechanics (S.L.A.M.). My dances have been in the repertory of Holland’s Introdans ensemble. I’ve performed, taught and/or residencies at colleges and universities including Vassar College, UMass Amherst, Hofstra University, De Sales University, Muhlenberg College, Wilson College, University of Nebraska, Hobart & William Smith Colleges, University of Wyoming, Marlboro College, Florida State University and others. I studied at the Joffrey Ballet School, attended Stuyvesant HS and Wesleyan University (where I majored in Dance and Italian). Then went to NYU, earning an M.A. in Performance Studies. Since then, I danced professionally (with choreographers including Sarah Michelson and Yvonne Rainer) and choreographed my own work. I've also written about dance for Dance Magazine, The Village Voice, The SDHS Conference Proceedings, The International Encyclopedia of Dance and the book Birds of Paradise: Costume as Cinematic Spectacle (British Film Institute, 2014).Press
