story:
What is Vijana Up?

-  Vijana Up is a dance project run by RINHA Dance crew which helps homeless children reintegrate into society, based in Goma, a city in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

-  The children helped by the project are all aged between 7 and 16 years old with the majority suffering from trauma resulting from the countries long running war. As a result of their circumstances most do not attend school.

-  The dance classes run by RINHA Dance Crew provide a safe environment for the children to exchange, to share and to express themselves during a structured activity.

-  Through dance, RINHA Dance Crew aims to reintroduce the children to a structured environment. The classes provide the children with a safe environment in which they can learn and be supported in their progression towards reintegration to mainstream society. The classes offer these children an opportunity to think about their future rather than only their day to day existence.

-  For now, most of the activities are hosted by the “Kivu Youth Entertainment” centre.


What is the Kivu Youth Entertainment centre?

-  A creative centre with resources to allow for the promotion and production of local art and artists.

-  The team at Kivu Youth Entertainment work with local youth artists on their professional development, providing consultation, training and advice and legal advice.

What are the issues according to the RINHA Dance Crew?

-  Currently the children rehearse and learn in a space that does not meet the required standards to learn properly.

-  RINHA Dance Crew lacks the funds to feed or clothe the children, meaning many dances without shoes and leave hungry.

-  After rehearsals the children go back to sleep in the streets.

-  Without being able to offer the children a meal or a safe space to sleep, the children helped by RINHA Dance Crew are still lacking the structure they so desperately need.

Dieumerci Bahati, 11 years old: “When I dance, I feel loved. I enjoy a lot learning to dance”


How could a donation help these children?

You can allow them to have:

-  A safe and secure rehearsal space, with a separate space for the children to sleep.

-  A healthy and nutritious meal after rehearsals. 

-  Provision of clothes and shoes for the children.

-  Donations will allow for the provision of improved educational support, with the long term aim of reintroducing the children into mainstream education and to pay any associated school fees.


What are the future projects of Vijana Up?

-  To expand the project, allowing them to help even more children.

-  To expand the number of qualified support staff to address and work with the diverse and difficult range of issues faced by the children.

-  To partner with local voluntary schools to provide a framework for reintegrate these children into mainstream education.

-  To gain attention and support from specialized reintegration centres, as Don Bosco or Inuka Centres,

-  To have the support of many young volunteers that will join the RINHA Crew to allow the creation of other centres.




VERSION FRANÇAISE


VIJANA UP, c’est quoi?

-  Un projet de danse qui aide des enfants qui vivent sans encadrement à s’intégrer dans la société. Ces enfants ont entre 7 et 16 ans et vivent dans la rue. La plupart d’entre eux sont victimes du traumatisme de la guerre, ne sont pas scolarisés.

-  Vijana Up est une initiative du RINHA Dance Crew, un groupe de jeunes danseurs hip-hop qui est composé de membres de 17 à 20 ans. Ils organisent des cours et animations deux fois par semaine pour les enfants qui vivent dans la rue.

-  Ces cours de danse permettent aux enfants d’échanger, de partager et de s'exprimer dans le cadre d’une activité structurée.

-  À travers ces activités, le RINHA Dance Crew tente de les rapprocher d’un environnement plus structurant, où ils pourront se concentrer sur leur avenir. Cela leur permettra d’intégrer des cercles scolaires et familiaux et les inciterait aussi à s’intéresser à l’éducation professionnelle.

-  Pour le moment, la plupart des activités sont accueillies par le centre « Kivu Youth Entertainment ».

Kivu Youth Entertainment, c’est quoi ?

-  Un centre créatif de promotion et de production multimédia et artistique.

-  Son objectif est de permettre aux jeunes de la République Démocratique du Congo de promouvoir leurs talents, afin d’en faire un métier.

-  Kivu Youth Entertainment contribue aussi à leur formation professionnelle et fait en sorte qu’ils connaissent leurs droits et devoirs ainsi que les valeurs de la démocratie.

Quels sont les problèmes pour le RINHA Dance Crew ?

-  Les enfants répètent dans un endroit qui ne remplit pas les normes pour apprendre correctement et qui n’est pas adapté pour un rassemblement.

-  Les enfants retournent dormir dans la rue.

-  Ils n’ont pas de fonds pour leur fournir de la nourriture.

-  Les enfants dansent pieds nus, avec des habits en mauvais état.

-  Les enfants n’ont aucune structure.

Comment un don peut aider ces enfants ?

Vous pourrez leur permettre d’obtenir :

-  Un endroit plus adapté pour se rassembler,

-  Des chaussures et des habits pour se vêtir,

-  Un encadrement pédagogique plus poussé,

-  De quoi leur offrir à manger,

-  Un endroit où les enfants peuvent dormir,

-  De quoi payer la scolarité des enfants.

Quels sont les projets futurs de Vijana Up ?

-  Pouvoir offrir à ce projet une plus grande ampleur,

-  Etre soutenus par différents partenaires œuvrant pour le bien-être de l’enfant,

-  Trouver des écoles volontaires pour intégrer ces enfants,

-  Retenir l’attention de centres d’encadrement spécialisés, comme les centres Donbosco ou Inuka,

-  Trouver des familles désireuses de participer au projet d’accueil des enfants,

-  Avoir le soutien de nombreux jeunes volontaires qui rejoindront RINHA Crew pour permettre l’existence d’autres centres.

story:
Anthem Theatre Company presents

Season 2016: FAVORITES!

This season marks an exciting new adventure for Anthem Theatre Company. We have been chosen as a Boston Center for the Arts' new Resident Performing Arts Company, or "ResCo"! This wonderful opportunity provides us with mentorship from established Boston companies and artists, help with marketing, and discounted performance space for the next three years! We are honored to be a part of such a prestigious group, and have worked hard in and out of the theatre for the last few years to get here. 

In order to make our mark as a ResCo, Anthem Theatre Company has decided Season 2016 should be spent sharing some of our favorite works with Boston, in our aptly titled SEASON 2016: FAVORITES! 

THE DARE PROJECT: BOSTON, September 15-17, 2016--Anthem introduces New York's "The Dare Project" to Boston Center for the Arts. This ten-minute play festival, co-created by Bryn Boice with taxdeductible theatre company in 2006, is a unique way to engage our growing Boston audience; seven playwrights are DARED to write plays based on audience suggestions. Beloved companies Zeitgeist Stage Company, Office of War Information (Bureau of Theatre) and Moonbox Productions, among others, will participate.

12TH NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD by Brian MacInnis Smallwood, October 27-November 5, 2016--Anthem presents a campy, bloody, gory, romantic Shakespearean comedy just in time for Halloween. This trip to Illyria follows the plot of Twelfth Night until, quite literally, all hell breaks loose. Bryn and Mike are still laughing about the production they saw in the East Village nine years ago, so it definitely belongs in our season of FAVORITES. Featuring a cast of 15 Boston artists, including Johnny Kinsman as Sir Toby Belch, and Bryn Boice as our fearless, blood-soaked director, this twist on a classic is bound to go down in Boston history as the best Halloween adventure ever.

What We Need & What You Get

Anthem Theatre Company's last fundraising campaign in 2013 had incredible impact. We got creative and stretched your generous funding for three years; your support helped us to produce FOUR plays and to win this residency! We believe that with your renewed investment in us, we will launch to a new level in 2016. 

  • We are seeking $6,500 to offset our costs for rehearsal and performance space, artists' fees, promotional costs, insurance, and technical & design elements. Although we get a discount and help with exposure from the BCA, this is a bigger venture than we've ever undertaken, and we need a boost to help us put on these HITS. 
  • Where does the money go? A look inside--> Performance Space (rental and season deposit): $3839; Rehearsal Space: $750-1200; Actor, Designer, Tech, and Playwright Fees: $6275; Sets, lights, costumes, props (and fake blood and guts): $3000; Insurance: $330;  Promotions, PR and advertising: $1560. These are the things we are saving for and fundraising for, and any amount of support you can give will help us to fulfill our mission: to do excellent work that compels our audiences to seek out more theatrical experiences and to make theatre a part of their lives. Support the art form of theatre by supporting us!
  • Perks include: tickets to our Season 2016: FAVORITES!; official Anthem rain ponchos for 12NOTLD front row Splash-Zone supporters; walk-on zombie roles; official Anthem baseball shirts (as seen in Romeo VS. Juliet last summer); Anthem ringer tees; and Anthem grocery totes! Also, if prizes aren't your thing, we are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501 (c)(3) company, so your donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The Impact

Your contribution will make a valuable difference in our first season at Boston Center for the Arts. It's an impact that will be felt for years to come:

  • THE DARE PROJECT is a community builder. People who are new-to-theatre or theatre-skeptics absolutely love this project because it's fresh, it's new, and you have the chance to commission a play based on an idea in your head! Audiences from each of the ResCos will join us, and we will introduce ourselves to each others' fans, creating a larger web of art seekers and an expanded audience. This new venture is in tune with our mission and can have an impact on all seven small companies. This kind of good will is priceless, as we believe theatre is not a competitive sport, but an art form to be shared.
  • 12TH NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD is more than a catchy title, it's a holiday show. Halloween is a time for adult fun, too, and we want to put on this theatrical comedy event to draw new, curious audiences to Anthem Theatre Company. This piece showcases our strengths: physical comedy, word play, and showing off Shakespeare's limitless possibilities to a modern, fun-seeking audience. 12NOTLD also has many technical elements that we are excited about building, inventing and exploring, the cost of which your donations will help to offset.
Your donations go a LONG way with Anthem Theatre Company. We use donations wisely and with care, and for the love of this craft. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand this campaign may meet you at a time when you are unable to give. If that is the case, we would sincerely appreciate you sharing this page on social media: make some noise using the Indiegogo share tools! 

If your company does corporate matching, or if your company would like to be a season sponsor, we are always looking for creative ways to partner. Help us help you, and vice versa. We are anxious to make connections and form relationships with sponsors who share our goals!

We'd also love to see you at our shows. There is truly nothing better than your friendly faces in the house. 

Anthem Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Anthem Theatre Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Support the art form of theatre by supporting us!
Perks include: tickets to our Season 2016: FAVORITES!; official Anthem rain ponchos for 12NOTLD front row Splash-Zone supporters; walk-on zombie roles; official Anthem baseball shirts (as seen in Romeo VS. Juliet last summer); Anthem ringer tees; and Anthem grocery totes! Also, if prizes aren't your thing, we are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501 (c)(3) company, so your donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The ImpactYour contribution will make a valuable difference in our first season at Boston Center for the Arts. It's an impact that will be felt for years to come:
THE DARE PROJECT is a community builder. People who are new-to-theatre or theatre-skeptics absolutely love this project because it's fresh, it's new, and you have the chance to commission a play based on an idea in your head! Audiences from each of the ResCos will join us, and we will introduce ourselves to each others' fans, creating a larger web of art seekers and an expanded audience. This new venture is in tune with our mission and can have an impact on all seven small companies. This kind of good will is priceless, as we believe theatre is not a competitive sport, but an art form to be shared.
12TH NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD is more than a catchy title, it's a holiday show. Halloween is a time for adult fun, too, and we want to put on this theatrical comedy event to draw new, curious audiences to Anthem Theatre Company. This piece showcases our strengths: physical comedy, word play, and showing off Shakespeare's limitless possibilities to a modern, fun-seeking audience. 12NOTLD also has many technical elements that we are excited about building, inventing and exploring, the cost of which your donations will help to offset.
Your donations go a LONG way with Anthem Theatre Company. We use donations wisely and with care, and for the love of this craft. 
Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand this campaign may meet you at a time when you are unable to give. If that is the case, we would sincerely appreciate you sharing this page on social media: make some noise using the Indiegogo share tools! If your company does corporate matching, or if your company would like to be a season sponsor, we are always looking for creative ways to partner. Help us help you, and vice versa. We are anxious to make connections and form relationships with sponsors who share our goals!We'd also love to see you at our shows. There is truly nothing better than your friendly faces in the house. Anthem Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Anthem Theatre Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Theatrefullstop have teamed up with both the Etcetera Theatre and Lion and Unicorn Theatre to present the first Pub Theatre Festival set to be staged in April 2017.

The aim is to encourage current drama school and university students, as well as graduates to stage their works to a paying audience. The festival will take place over 2 weekends in April (Friday and Saturday) and will allow for groups with a max of 3 performers to showcase 30minutes of work.

A reward system will also be introduced, whereby if the audience pay for 3 tickets, they’ll receive a complimentary ticket to a future show.

A student or graduate making their first steps into staging their own works after higher education can be a tough task. There’s plenty to think about as they're not only creating and devising their own works but their having to bear in mind the marketing and financial aspects of a show. What the Pub Theatre Festival looks to do is to create a launchpad for the voices of tomorrow. Everyone has to start from somewhere, and with a little support, possibilities can be endless.

Having hosted theatre events at a fringe venue and pub theatre venue, the need to celebrate these institutions is a must. These venues provide opportunities for both emerging and established artists to showcase their works in an encouraging and friendly environment. Pub Theatres are not just a place where careers begin, they are apart of the UK theatre experience and are a must to visit for any theatre lover.

The purpose of the funding is to contribute to the costs of hiring out the 2 venues. Your contribution, no matter how small will help to bring this festival to life and support the new voices of tomorrow.

For those looking to take part, submissions are now open and will close on Friday 28th October. Submissions are to be made to Lucy Basaba at theatrefullstop@gmail.com.

To find out more about the Etcetera Theatre, visit here…

To find out more about the Lion and Unicorn Theatre, visit here…

story:
Short Summary

Let The Devil Take The Hindmost

  • My name is Maya Contreras, and I am the playwright of "Let The Devil Take The Hindmost" which will have it's world premiere at the Off-Broadway Theatre Soho Playhouse for FringeNYC's 20th Anniversary.
  • Producing small independent theatre can be expensive! While we are close to getting all of our production costs covered, we are reaching out to all of you to help us cross the finish line! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • By contributing to this show - you are being an 'angel' to small independent theatre in NYC. With your help, we get to produce the kind of show we can be proud of; the kind of show you can be proud to be apart of!  

The Impact

Why your contribution will make a difference:

  • This project speaks upon subjects that are very much on the minds of many Americans and those around the world: civil rights, privilege, the cycles of gun violence and prejudice in our country. We feel that this is a conversation we want to contribute to through the theatre. 
  • Our last Indiegogo campaign help fund our last small theatre offering to great success, and we are grateful to contributors like you.
  • We would of course prefer you support us by seeing the show in person, and if you can't, we would love for you to support us in this way. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Listen we know that even contributing a dollar can be tough! If you can't financially contribute feel free to just share our campaign through social media. That means the world to us!!!
  • And that's all there is to it. Thank you!

story:
Make Our 'Orchestra' Grow

We at Savoyards Musical Theatre Ltd. have launched this campaign to fund our upcoming production of Leonard Bernstein's Candide, September 16-18 2016, at the Hangar Theatre in Ithaca, New York. We strive to raise $3,000 by closing night to offset the cost of paying the players in the show’s thirteen-piece orchestra.

Candide marks a big step forward for our company and a return to our presenting fully staged and fully scored comic operas and musicals in public venues outside Cornell University. For the past five years, all of our Gilbert & Sullivan performances at the Cornell Schwartz Center have been only with piano accompaniment.

Hiring an orchestra has improved the quality of our production, but also has increased our budget tremendously. This additional expense, however, is necessary. We could not do justice to Leonard Bernstein's beautiful and intricate score without a full orchestra. We continue to strive to entertain, challenge and move our audiences.

About Our Show

Based on Voltaire’s satire on mindless optimism, Leonard Bernstein’s Candide is one of the most beautiful and energetic musicals ever composed for Broadway, a frothy blend of the American popular and European classical traditions.

“There can be no doubt about the brilliance of Bernstein’s score,” says conductor Marin Alsop, “which he conceived as a Valentine’s card to European music. Few composers could construct a score where European dance forms like the gavotte, waltz and polka are interwoven seamlessly with bel canto arias, Gilbert and Sullivan-style comedy, allusions to Strauss and Offenbach, flashes of grand opera, and Bernstein’s own ‘Jewish tango.’”

This effect is possible because of Bernstein’s rich orchestration. Our version of Candide (the 1974 Chelsea edition) calls for violin, viola, cello, bass, flute, recorder, oboe, regular and bass clarinets, bassoon, trumpet, trombone, flugelhorn, soprano sax, piano, electric keyboard, and percussion.

Our Musicians

Fortunately, we have hired talented young musicians to bring Bernstein’s score to life. Many are Ithaca College students looking toward full-time careers. Your sponsorship will provide them with invaluable professional experience and will allow them to give back to the Ithaca community.

Leading this group is Keehun Nam, who has come from Vanderbilt University to join Ithaca College’s master’s program in orchestral conducting. He and music director Katrina Kuka, a graduate of Ithaca College School of Music, are featured on this campaign’s promotional video, which also includes footage from a music rehearsal.

For Tickets

Please click here to come see the show!
http://www.hangartheatre.org/events/candide.html

About Our Company

Savoyards Musical Theatre, Ltd., formerly the Cornell Savoyards, has performed Gilbert and Sullivan as well as European light opera and classic American musicals since 1953. Recently incorporated, our group is now a 501(c) (3) nonprofit organization, so all donations are tax deductible.

Even if you cannot contribute to this campaign, please help us in other ways:

·  Spread the word about this fundraiser (Indiegogo provides share tools!) 

·  Volunteer to help build sets, construct costumes, crew, or usher for the show

·  Attend and bring family and friends to our performances

·  Audition for future productions

To learn more, visit our website at: www.savoyardsithaca.org

story:
Summary

Black and Brown Theatre is a grassroots project that will kick off in October 2016 to introduce new works by people of color. The showcase is produced by director and playwright Emilio Rodriguez, and producer and director Sam White.

Contributions to this campaign support the actors and playwrights participating in the fall showcase. 

The showcase includes six (6) ten-minute plays at The Charles H. Wright Museum in the General Motors Theatre. 

Showcase itinerary:

2:30 p.m. to 3 p.m. -- VIP reception

3 p.m. to 4 p.m. -- presentation of six plays

4 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. -- Talback (Q and A with audience, cast and crew)

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2000 to provide our artists with a stipend. 

The remainder of the budget will be used to support a workshop, following the showcase in early November 2016, taught by Emilio Rodriguez and Sam White. An additional workshop will take place at Denby High School in Detroit, led by Emilio Rodriguez and Morgan Breon. 

The Impact

The showcase will highlight stories written by playwrights of color as well as give black and brown artists in the area a chance to gain experience and share their talents with the support of their community and its allies. The hope is to create a more level playing field this season with more representation in theatre. 

Risks & Challenges

Our goal is to fail. We are hoping that this is the beginning of work by Black and Brown Theatre that will lead to more equitable theatre in our area. 

We hope that we will be able to give more artists a platform to be seen, cast and supported in other theatres around the state. This will eventually lead to more equitable casting and B and B will no longer be needed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please like us on Facebook and Twitter, support the showcase and if you are interested in learning more about the theatre company, email us directly at blackandbrowntheatre@gmail.com

story:
The Great & Terrible Doctor Faustus

Concept and direction by Alex Benjamin. Choreography by Katherine Scott.

(above: Zachary Nicol & original cast)

Striding Lion Performance Group and the Athenaeum Theatre are proud to co-present The Great and Terrible Doctor Faustus, an immersive dance-theatre adaptation of Christopher Marlowe's canonical play. Faustus sets the story in a turn-of-the-century vaudeville theatre, where renowned illusionist Doctor Faustus is about to attempt his most mind-bending magic act yet, and seal a pact with the Devil himself to secure his status as the most powerful magician in the world. Along with his friends, enemies, and lovers, Faustus sets out on a journey for fame and knowledge. Little do these characters know that they will come into close contact with all of the seven deadly sins along the way.

Faustus allows audience members to follow Faustus and his cohorts through the darkest corners of the Athenaeum Theatre, a century-old Chicago landmark. In the process, they will experience the story and connect with the characters at close range in intimate, non-traditional performance spaces. They will see backstage like never before.

(above: Zachary Nicol & Collin Quinn Rice)

The Great & Terrible Doctor Faustus was workshopped and produced on the campus of Northwestern University in Fall 2014. Photos featured here are from that production, by Justin Barbin. Video featured here are from that production, directed and produced by Shae Spence & Sean Magner. Drawings by Gina Marie Hayes.

Performances will be held from February 19-29 at the historic Athenaeum Theatre, 2936 N. Southport Avenue, Chicago, IL. Book tickets by phone at 773-935-6875 or online at www.AthenaeumTheatre.org

What Is Immersive Theatre?

While there are many ways to define immersive theatre, for Faustus it means three basic things:

1. The actors and audience occupy the same space, and the performance occurs on the stage as well as backstage, in the house, and all around the landmark Athenaeum Theatre.

2. Design elements work together to "immerse" the audience in the world of the play. There will be a constant soundscape throughout the building to communicate the tone; the costumes will be crafted with a level of rich detail better enjoyed up close; the dance sequences will move in and out of audience space seamlessly, giving you a unique viewpoint on the narrative.

3. The audience is not a passive spectator, but rather an active participant. Because the scenes happen across the entire building, audience members must literally move from place to place in order to experience a full story, and it is likely that one viewing will not be enough to see all of the material built for the show.

Why Immersive Theatre?

For Faustus, it's simple. We think up-close-and-personal is the most visceral, intimate, unique way to experience this story. The Faust legend has been around for a long time, and immersive theatre brings a new vitality and urgency to an old story.

About Striding Lion Performance Group

Under the artistic direction of Amanda Exley Lower (featured in the Faustus cast), Striding Lion Performance Group is a company of dance theater artists and collaborators dedicated to bringing innovative and thought provoking performance programming to diverse audiences. Through the collision of live performance and new media, a stalwart commitment to original music, and the inventive use of both traditional and non-traditional performance spaces, our performance and education work challenges audiences to move beyond the limitations of a passive "viewing" experience and engage more immediately and kinesthetically with the content and material presented. On the stage, in the studio, and in the classroom, Striding Lion endeavors to expand the dialogue between artist and audience—breaking down barriers to make dance theater performance both accessible and meaningful.

Faustus is our most ambitious undertaking thus far.

About the Athenaeum Theatre

ATP is Chicago’s premiere performance arts service organization, providing our Chicago and Illinois’s vibrant and diverse non-profit arts community with below cost performance and rehearsal spaces, and affordable office space supported by a staff of theatre professionals encouraging the community to incubate new projects and collaborations.

(above: Kelly Engler & Shae Spence)

How Your Support Makes Our Magic Happen

Your tax-deductible donation will help bring this new work to life, giving audiences a unique experience interacting with an old story in an intimate, new way. Because we strive to fully immerse our audiences in the world of Faustus and the seven deadly sins, our design elements must be highly detailed.

  • Set & Props: While the historic Athenaeum Theatre is a beautiful backdrop for the telling of Faustus's story, we need to build, purchase, and rent items to flesh out the turn-of-the-century vaudeville world of the characters.

  • Costumes: Our costume designer Veronica is designing period-appropriate, dance-friendly costumes for each of our actors. The intricacy of their design will lend an authenticity and beauty to up-close interactions.

  • Lights: Because our show travels all over the Athenaeum Theatre building, we require the rental and placement of non-traditional theatre lighting elements like floor lamps to illuminate the dark corners of our space. We also need to manipulate existing lighting elements to make them appear period-appropriate (purchasing vintage bulbs, dimming light sources, and replacing modern appliances).

  • Sound: We will be renting sound equipment to put ambient sound in every room of the Athenaeum. This will be essential in creating a totally immersive world for the audience to experience. Additionally, there are various instances of live music performance before and throughout the show, for which instruments must be maintained and musicians hired.

How else will your contribution help bring the magic of Faustus to life?

  • Stipends & Labor: It is important to us to pay all of the artists working on this production. A portion of the budget is allocated for stipends for designers and actors, and we will also be paying everyone who works with us as an electrician, carpenter, or costume constructor.

  • Marketing: Our marketing director Matt Silverman and graphic designer Arnel Sancianco are strategizing and creating graphics to be used on posters, online advertisements, and postcards.

Other Ways You Can Connect

  • Visit Striding Lion's website at StridingLion.org

  • Like us on Facebook for frequent updates and special offers.

  • Email the creators at Alex@StridingLion.org with any questions or concerns. We would love to talk to you!

  • Share our campaign with anyone you know who is passionate about new work, canonical stories, immersive theatre, and Chicago nonprofit performing arts!

  • Experience the magic for yourself this February. Visit AthenaeumTheatre.org to purchase tickets.

story:
WHY INVEST OUT LOUD?

1) Your support will go a long way

Your support will make OUT LOUD Theatre's 6th Season possible. From rental fees to design elements - your contribution goes a long way. As a small ensemble with an even smaller budget, ANY amount makes a difference.

2) We have a dedicated and expansive ensemble

With a full staff of leadership, advocates, and performance ensemble members - OUT LOUD has continued to grow. With your support we can continue to reach out into the community, fostering a laboratory environment for young and up and coming artists looking for a collaborative place to create. From actors, to designers, to managers, to visual artists - your contribution helps support the work of everyone involved with OUT LOUD Theatre.

3) Our 3-part series is breaking new ground

Focused on fantasy & unreality - OUT LOUD's 6th season is striving to break new ground. From art installations, to wholly original material, to imaginative adaptations - our ensemble is ready to stretch our creativity and innovation to new heights. Your contribution makes this possible.  

 

LEARN MORE

OUT LOUD Theatre Announces their 6th Season: "Seeing Is Believing: An Exploration of Fantasy and Unreality" kicking off in 2018.

In this landmark year, OUT LOUD prepares to expand upon their current structure by devising 2 original adaptions and their first World Premiere over the course of a 6 month period. This interconnected 3-Part Series will both rehearse and perform in rep, emphasizing a focus on their core ensemble of artists who will be building and collaborating together over the course of 2018. Their upcoming 3-part series focuses on the nature and the potential of fantastical themes and how they can exist within ourselves, within our given circumstances, and within our overall perception of the world around us.

​This 3-part series consists of WONDER (an original adaptation of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland), ESCAPE (a world premiere exploring the nature and specificity of one woman's journey through grief), and DREAM (an original adaptation based on William Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream). This 3-part series will rehearse in rep January - May 2018 and perform in rep throughout June 2018.

 

WONDER

WONDER is unlike anything OUT LOUD Theatre has created in the past. Part art installation, part performance - this piece is truly a unique and fully immersive experience based on Lewis Carroll's Alice in Wonderland. "You quite literally are offered an experience to step into and through this world," says Artistic Director, Kira Hawkridge. "No matter your relationship with the source material and its many interpretations and adaptations that are readily on hand to explore, we encourage audiences to be prepared to expect the unexpected. WONDER is OUT LOUD Theatre's authentic meditation on what it means to make the ordinary extraordinary, to engage with our imaginations, and to push our own creative and artistic boundaries beyond what we thought was possible. We are taking our definition of immersive experience to the next level and inviting our audiences to challenge any preconceived notions they might have of what live theater "should" and ultimately can be."

WONDER is OUT LOUD's first installment in their upcoming 3-Part Series premiering this June, all part of OUT LOUD's Season 6: Seeing is Believing (An Exploration of Fantasy & Unreality).

ESCAPE

ESCAPE explores a journey of great personal loss and the places that indescribable grief can take us, both in our tangible reality and in the depths of our own imagination.

OUT LOUD Theatre and the 5 person ensemble of ESCAPE are in the process of devising this entirely original piece that will act as OUT LOUD's first official 'World Premiere' this June.  ESCAPE explores one woman's experience interfacing first hand with her personal form of grief (played by Natasha Cole) through the loss of her twin brother (played by Justin Fortin). Haunted by the pain of losing her twin, we experience how grief creates a ripple effect throughout her life while simultaneously examining how each character processes grief on their own terms. Erika Rethorn portrays the woman's 'Partner', Patricia Hawkridge portrays the woman's 'Mother', and Siobhan LaPorte-Cauley portrays the woman's 'Therapist', each exploring how this particular loss effects these dynamic and interpersonal relationships.

The ESCAPE ensemble have collectively taken the time to delve into these characters authentic voices, creating piece by piece the aspects of their lives that feel important to express their individual truths. "We have found that it is a very different process devising from a theme or concept verses jumping off of a specific source material that we are working to adapt or re-imagine," says Artistic Director, Kira Hawkridge. "This story and its characters are all our own. It was important to us as a collaborative ensemble to give this piece room to breathe, grow, and evolve authentically and organically. As our first true 'World Premiere', ESCAPE called upon an expansive time frame to allow it to truly thrive, and Season 6 was the perfect opportunity to make that a reality."

So where does a piece focused on grief and loss fit within a Season of "unreality"? "What feels more surreal than the loss of a loved one? What changes our reality more than experiencing grief? This piece strives to offer a window into one woman's experience, creating a safe space to engage with the difficult subject matter this piece presents."

ESCAPE is OUT LOUD's second installment in their upcoming 3-Part Series premiering this June, all part of OUT LOUD's Season 6: Seeing is Believing (An Exploration of Fantasy & Unreality).

DREAM

DREAM is a wild & immersive experience through a fantastical dreamscape full of magic, mischief, and love - based on William Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream. "All 3 productions this Season begin with establishing a sense of 'reality' as we know it," says Artistic Director, Kira Hawkridge, "And from that 'reality' all 3 productions tip into a sense of 'unreality' in which we experience vastly different interpretations of these fantastical realms. These adventures and raw experiences somehow find their way back to the beginning - allowing for a shift in what we originally felt or were aware of. 'Unreality' has the ability to create a change in 'reality' and vice versa.

DREAM begins its journey in Athens - in a state of hyper realism. Our Royals, Lovers, and Mechanicals exist in Athen's very "real" world - with hard edges that seem to glimmer with possibilities just beyond their reach. As each individual enters the "the forest", we collectively unveil, and in turn fully experience, the array of possibilities 'unreality' has to offer, and how this fantastical dreamscape reveals truths within ourselves and within our perception of the world around us. 

Season 6 is an opportunity for our ensemble to give over completely to the essence of these expansive themes - "WONDER", "ESCAPE", and "DREAM" - and to explore these worlds with open minds and open hearts - reality and unreality alike. Seeing is Believing, and with Season 6, there is a whole lot to see." ​

DREAM is OUT LOUD's third and final installment in their upcoming 3-Part Series premiering this June, all part of OUT LOUD's Season 6: Seeing is Believing (An Exploration of Fantasy & Unreality).

 

"Season 6: Seeing is Believing (An Exploration of Fantasy & Unreality) begins a new chapter for OUT LOUD Theatre," says Artistic Director, Kira Hawkridge. "We have evolved and continued to learn throughout our first 5 years in existence and Season 6 is a culmination of the fundamental themes that make OUT LOUD unique. Rooted in imagination and exploration, Season 6 is a celebration of each OUT LOUD ensemble member's authentic vision and voice as we take this leap into a brand new adventure together. With a heavy emphasis on core ensemble work, devised material, and community engagement, Season 6 is sure to be one of our most exciting Seasons to date." 

LIKE US ON FACEBOOK

FOLLOW US ON INSTAGRAM

CHECK OUT OUR WEBSITE

story:
PWR Presents: Ghost Mall


Party World Rasslin' is Austin, Texas's radiant jewel of Party Excess. It is a unique and miraculous spectacle celebrating friendship, beer, and wrestling. At our last party, we stood aghast as a cowboy from Dallas blitzed our tiny, puppet-like champion and claimed the Partyweight belt. But we're not ready for the story to end...we're ready for MAXIMUM PARTY VENGEANCE!

SLAMHAIN VI




Fall is approaching, and that means just one thing - Halloween. But Halloween's not until October, what are we gonna do in the mean time? I'll tell you what, we're going to get spooky at PWR's annual Fall wrestling party: SLAMHAIN And what could be a better and spookier place for a  party than a GHOSTLY MALL - a GHOST MALL? I'll answer that for you...nothin'.

We'll be transforming 4th Tap Brewing Co-op into haunted mall -- complete with abandoned, colorful storefronts, escalators and elevators, and the unmistakably bedazzled cyclopean walls of America's most abandoned gathering zones. Here, PWR's epic PARTY COMBAT will be waged once more. Who will claim the SOUL OF THE MALL? This crucial spectacle will be illuminated with a full professional lighting system, shout with a clear and juicy sound system, and broadcast on 3 screens and beyond with a sweet 3-camera video setup!

It wasn't always like this, though. Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—this thing has become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. In 5 years we've gone from a handful of people watching a home-made ring to the glorious spectacle we know today.  We continue to do a DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us. The show remains FREE TO ATTEND, even as we mount mammoth costs.
 

THE STORY SO FAR





At BIOSLAM, in the very body of MOTHER WORM, we witnessed the horror of Dallas tycoon BIG DADDY BOLERO virtually stealing the Partyweight Title. 

The ambitious and towering BDB is now shielded from interference by the Worm, and can pursue his goal of total domination and utter development of the Multiverse. His next target: the Ghost Mall! If he has his way, the spirits will be exersized, and the looming walls broken down - replaced with mixed-use cubes, cramped high-rises and unsightly bronze statues! 

But there's been one person who has stood up to Big Daddy Bolero before. A hero of the downtrodden; a resistor of corrupt authority! She was beaten once, but she's back in contendership, and this time she knows her opponents' tricks! We're speaking, of course, about the radical instigator and baseball-bat wielding champion of the meek: ALEXANDRA CAGE!

Get ready for an explosion between these two diametrically opposed forces! 

Not just that, but FULL MAUL MADNESS awaits: as the usual PARTY ATHLETES continue their storeis: Luigi Primo, Bull DeCroix, The Dumpster Babes, Sweetie Tuff, Dock Master, Pastaman, Bench Horse, The Valkyries Ralph Machiatto, Sprida , Arbitro Obscuro, Hot Dog, and MORE!

 

What is this money used for?

$6000 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR's quarterly Austin shows are free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on one of the largest free events in Texas. Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spend north of $10,000 on each of our shows.

We diligently budget and carefully save so that we can ask for an amount that is sustainable. We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; our rigorous planning -- combined with your support -- have allowed us to do this without our costs ballooning to a hellish degree! It's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than five years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT

Some of the cool things your donations will help us do include:

  • Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a biological wonderland at our last show! This time, we're turning the brewery into an undead, early-2000s shopping plaza! Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

  • Air Conditioning. The huge space we have the ring in isn't air conditioned, so we build our own cooling system for the summer shows! We rent swamp coolers and hoist them onto huge risers that we built. This, combined with about $700 worth of fans we've collected over the years and a clever air-pathing layout keep the ring area comfortable in the Summer!

  • Paying artists. We work hard to make sure everyone who contributes to our production gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our A/V crew.

  • Safer space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

  • Projection and lighting. PWR has some of the most advanced lighting for an independent wrestling show in the country! And we built it ourselves, with your help. We always have tweaks to make to reach towards our goal of TV-quality lighting. If you saw our lights at the last show, you know how shockingly powerful our latest generation is! Also, our projection system allows people to watch the show from 3 different places in the venue, each with different sitting and standing options! Plus, we now STREAM our shows over twitch, and your support helps us improve the quality of it

  • Training: Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  

  • Profit split: after we cover all our costs, we take 20% of our profits and reinvest it in PWR. We split up whatever is left among performers and staff who worked on the show.

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a big chunk of them. Below is our complete operational budget.

Show Expenses: $2862.00:

Art Supplies: $500.00

Equipment Rental and Accessories (AC units, Video/Sound, Generators, etc): $1050.00

Construction Supplies: $100.0

Insurance: $467.58

Performer Assistance Fund: $150.00

Ring Maintenance: $50.00

Office Supplies: $60.00

Props/Costume: $75.00

Security Phone: $60.00

Transportation: $350.00

Service Subscriptions: $70

Operational Expenses: $4370:

Artist and Staff Pay: $3970

New Projects Capital: $400.00

Indiegogo Reward production and fulfillment: $3030.00
Indiegogo and credit card fees: $513.00

 

Extremely Hype Swag

As usual, we've got awesome merch rewards you can get if you contribute to the Indiegogo. This includes are brand new shirt design by Zeke Guadiana! 
}

Or how about a CLOTH TOTE BAG with a print by Nat Bradford? Check this sick design:

Looking for something new? Something INSANE? Something that MELTS?! How about a REAL PWR CANDLE by Tracy Hunt?!


Risks and Challenges

As PWR continues its evolution from backyard party to professional art-collective, we never want to lose the heart of partying and stupidness that makes it good. We aim to balance a relentless work ethic with a light touch and and inviting environment for our attendants, volunteers and staff. It's hard wrangling 80 people to put on a huge free show, but knowing others will join us to reap the rewards makes it worth it one million times. Rest assured we're working tirelessly to have the time of our lives on September 7th! 


Other Ways You Can Help


If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and GHOST MALL!


Here is the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/2153420994786213/

HMW

story:
We are seeking support for a workshop of our upcoming production of The Gap by Makaela Shealy. The production will be directed by Maggie Monahan and produced by Janie Dickerson and Lizzy Jarrett.

 

About The Gap

The Gap follows a cheerleading team in a small town in the South, newly given the opportunity to redeem themselves at State. When the co-captain makes it her mission to get the racist school mascot removed, her peers challenge her commitment to “change.” Biting, heightened realism is punctuated by expressive poetry, dreams, and dialogue with the audience. 


Makaela as a cheerleader at Gilbert High

It is for womxn or genderqueer actors. At Gilbert High, the cheerleaders are not the highest on the food chain. They are athletic misfits. These are not the kids who grow up with schedules, tutors and education laid out for them, but they are hardworking, fast, and scrappy. Most live in trailers and have afterschool jobs to pay for things they actually need or need to survive high school (a phone, rainbow flip flops). Most are operating at or below the poverty line. Most will try to leave this town and fail. They know that.

 

Workshop Budget

We are hoping to develop this play through a week-long workshop in February 2020 so we can be ready for full production in 2021. The workshop will end with a presentation for potential investors and mentors for the artists. Since this will not be a ticketed event, we are relying on the support from our friends and family to make this happen. Here is a breakdown of the costs involved (feel free to email Janie & Lizzy for more details at thegapplay@gmail.com):

  • Presentation Space:  For our presentation, we need a space that is clean, safe, and professional. We anticipate it will cost $2,000 for four hours in such a space.
  • Rehearsal Space: To keep costs low, we will rehearse in a studio. A studio that can accommodate 20 artists will cost $45 per hour.  For 26 hours of rehearsal, this will cost $1,170.
  • Artists: We believe in supporting and compensating our artists fairly for their time.  For 14 actors, a director, a writer, and a stage manager, we are budgeting $1,200.
  • Printing and contingency: $200 for printing scripts and $102 (3% of the budget) for extraneous costs.

TOTAL BUDGET: $4,672

 

About the Artists

MAKAELA SHEALY (Writer) (she/her*) is a writer and performer based in NYC.  In her writing, she seeks out work that challenges form; that creates rules and breaks them in the same breath. She often explores the messy, bloody growing pains of teenage life in her work. Her priority is to create and foster collaborative and community oriented theatre.  Her plays include: The Gap (The Tank), Helena Blavatsky…(Wonder Media Network), and Laces. Her poetry has been featured in Allegory Ridge, Women Who Roar, and Muse Pie Press.  NYU Tisch B.F.A. Ring of Keys Member; Dramatist Guild Member. www.makaelashealy.com IG: @makaelamshealy

MAGGIE MONAHAN (Director) (she/her*). Originally from Washington, D.C. and now based in New York, Maggie Monahan is a theatre artist dedicated to confronting the most difficult questions in the public sphere through art. Maggie's directing ranges from reinventing familiar classics to exploring the stylized and the absurd in new plays. She plays with style and heightened text to explore themes of ethics, gender, violence, and American identity. Her work has been seen in New York at the Tank, Theatre Row, 54 Below and Lucid Body House; in Chicago at Collaboraction, Rivendell Theatre, Victory Gardens, and Clockwise Theatre; and internationally in Bosnia and Herzegovina. She has assisted at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, the National Theater of Sarajevo, Audible Theater at the Minetta Lane, and the first national tours of Escape to Margaritaville and School of Rock.​ BA Northwestern (magna cum laude, Lambda Pi Eta, departmental distinction). Certificate for political science achievement in a foreign language from La Pontificia Universidad Catolica in Chile. SDC Associate.

MAYA CARTER (Script Consultant) (they/she*) is an interdisciplinary performer, teaching artist, and theater-maker based out of Brooklyn. Their work strives to ignite an abiding hunger for equity + justice. Developmental projects include: Period Sisters at HERE Arts Center, Girls Act Out in residence at the Center At West Park, a teaching artist/theatre facilitation with the NYDOC, and The Seven Ravens Project with the New Victory's LabWorks Program. Credits include: for colored girls who have considered suicide when the rainbow is enuf  (Lady In Purple), Twelfth Night (Viola), Grounded (The Pilot), and The  Freedman’s Lit! (Elizabeth Hunter). BFA Theatre Performance: Hofstra University. Feel free to connect on Instagram: @maya_n_carter.

JANIE DICKERSON (Producer) (she/her*) is a theatre professional from Chicago.  Currently she works at Allied Touring and manages marketing and press for the national touring productions of Hello, Dolly!; Bandstand; Hadestown; Tootsie. Producing credits: A Tribute to The Dixie Chicks (Feinstein's/54 Below), Single Rider (Assistant; Player's Theatre), Little Shop of  Horrors (Bosnia & Herzegovina). B.A. in Theatre and Business Institutions from Northwestern University. 

LIZZY JARRETT (Producer) (she/her*) is a NYC-based actor and producer and could not be more excited to join The Gap team.  She is passionate about edgy, risk-taking theatre & film.  As a producer, Lizzy's focus is creating space for female and genderqueer artists.  She is also a team member of Make/Shift where she produces her annual festival SHE Creates. Training: NYU/Tisch. lizzyjarrett.com IG: @dizzymisslizzyjarrett

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in supporting the production through investment, or if you have any questions, please reach out to thegapplay@gmail.com

You can also join our email list to stay up to date on the development of this play here: https://forms.gle/89WZC3wKQZoF9xri7

If you are unable to contribute financially to this campaign, we would be grateful if you could spread the word!

 

Thank you for all your support! Happy holidays!!

Best,
Janie, Lizzy, Maggie, Maya, and Mak

IG: @thegapplay

*https://www.mypronouns.org/

story:
My Story
 
My name is LaKeisha S. Cox and I'm from Madison, Illinois. I am currently a student at Howard University majoring in Theatre Arts (Acting Concentration). Anyone who knows me knows I love to be on the stage, whether it was dancing or acting. There wasn't many opportunites to study dance where I'm from, but that never stopped me. I taught myself Hip Hop by revamping music videos from my favorite dancers, such as Michael & Janet Jackson, Aaliyah, Ciara, etc. I also choreographed my school's pep rally dances because we didn't have a Drama or Dance program. I first fell in love with the story of dance. It always spoke what I couldn't express or was too afraid to explain. Now, since study Theatre and Dance at Howard, I fell in love with the discipline and art of dance.
I have recently been selected to train at the Debbie Allen Dance Academy Summer Intensive 2012. I am so honored to have the opportunity to finally study technical dance at the Debbie Allen Dance Academy.
 
What I Need
 
To cover the cost of Housing and Travel I will need $2000. I hope that I can get 200 people to donate $10 or 80 people to donate $25. However, all donations are appreciated. Reminder: even $5 goes a long way ;) !
 
The Impact 
 
As an performer, I consider myself a griot; a storyteller. Dance has inspired me in a way that I want to share with the world. Dance isn't just about the height of an extension. If executed right it can change lives. I always believed that the people who control the images viewed by the masses controls their self-esteem. I remembering growing up I wanted to be like the people I saw on tv. I wanted to be as confident, as beautiful, as loved, as successful. What was even more motivating was seeing those same artists create a positive image that I could want to emulate. So, I say in confidence, "The Arts has changed my life". I strive to continue to project positive images for the next generation of successful leaders in any endeavors they choose to pursue.

story:
What is the Dolphin Show?

The Dolphin Show at Northwestern University is a non-profit student theatre organization that annually produces the nation's largest student-run musical. It celebrates the diverse talents of the Northwestern undergraduate community by providing opportunities to learn and excel in all artistic and administrative fields. The Dolphin Show presents a professional-caliber production, while involving the community through outreach. This year, The Dolphin Show is proud to present its 72nd production, Shrek the Musical, with over 150 undergraduate Northwestern students in the cast, on the rehearsal, artistic, and business teams, and in the pit orchestra and run crew!

The 72nd Annual Dolphin Show: Shrek the Musical

Shrek the Musical debuted on Broadway in December 2008 and is based on the 2001 Dreamworks film and the 1990 book Shrek! by William Steig. Shrek tells the story of a swamp-living, bug-eating ogre and his journey to save a princess from an isolated tower. Along the way, Shrek encounters characters straight from our favorite fairytales and nursery rhymes while making new friends, experiencing new adventures, and finding true love in the most unexpected of places. Shrek reminds audiences that it is who you are and what you make of it that matters most in our lives, not what you appear to be.

We Need Your Help!

Because we are a non-profit student group at Northwestern, we receive little to no money from the University. With a fundraising goal of $25,000 to meet our production budget of $60,000, Shrek the Musical needs your help to achieve our theatrical dreams, including:
  • SET, LIGHTS & COSTUMES: Shrek is set in a vast, fairytale land with many scenic locations. And with a cast of 35 to costume as individual fairytale characters, we need as much help as possible to make each one unique.
  • DRAGON & PUPPETRY: This show features characters voiced by actors and portrayed by puppets, including a hand-held gingerbread man and a 20-foot-long dragon operated by five students!
  • ADVERTISING & PR: In order to fill a 1000-seat auditorium every night, our advertising team has achieved new heights by placing ads on posters, postcards, shuttle buses, campus televisions, dining halls, and online.
  • SPECIAL EVENTS & ALUMNI RELATIONS: Every year, we continue the traditions from Dolphin Show's past in order to foster a community among current Northwestern students and Dolphin alumni, including AlumNite, the Freshman Cabaret, Splashback, and more.

Come See the Show

Interested in supporting the Dolphin Show in other ways? Come see Shrek the Musical, opening January 24! Show dates and times are:

Friday, January 24, 2014 at 8 PM
Saturday, January 25, 2014 at 8 PM
Sunday, January 26, 2014 at 2 PM
Friday, January 31, 2014 at 8 PM
Saturday, February 1, 2014 at 8 PM

All performances will take place in Cahn Auditorium: 600 Emerson Street, Evanston, IL. Go to NUDolphinShow.org/Tickets to buy your tickets now!

Thanks so much for your support of the Dolphin Show and Northwestern student theatre, and we hope to see you at the show!

story:
We're a Company of Boston Playwrights Taking Control 

We've built an organization, launched our presence in Boston, announced a season, and secured venues. We've gone as far as we can go without serious financial backing.  We can't take Boston Public Works any further without your help. 

Everyone Should Be Heard

You. Me. Well, maybe not that guy ranting on the B train. 

If you’re a playwright in Boston, it’s almost impossible to get one of your new full-length plays produced. There simply aren’t enough slots for new work in Boston.  And that kind of stinks. Especially if you’re a playwright.

But it doesn’t bode well for Boston, either. 

There is this huge pool of incredibly talented, emerging playwrights in Boston that theater-goers are not being exposed to. With the number of playwrights in Boston, there simply is no reason why Boston shouldn't be nationally recognized as a source of new theatrical work, and Boston audiences aren't treated to more amazing local talent. We're really talking about a neglected resource. 

What We’re Gonnadoaboutit

Playwrights write because they have a burning desire to say something and want it heard on stage. In true entrepreneurial fashion, we're not waiting for someone to put on our plays.  We're creating our own opportunities, leading by example, and have banded together to: 

  • Produce one play by each of the members of Boston Public Works, thereby creating new slots for new work
  • Learn self-production as part of the journey
  • Learn how to form more groups like Boston Public Works to continue promoting new work
  • Employ Boston theater artists of all stripes for their skills and talents to break new ground
  • Leave a roadmap for other playwrights to follow because it's so much easier once someone else has led the way
  • Make Boston a hotbed for new plays with a nationwide reputation.

Here Are The Numbers

We know: Our Indiegogo goal is a big one. We also will pursue grants and investigate other sources of income.

P7 Jim Dalglish, who was Managing Director of Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater (WHAT) on Cape Cod for a number of years, budgeted everything from postage for our Indiegogo perks to laundry for the costumes. We've done our due diligence and numbers don't lie. 

Each show, on average, will cost approximately $10,000. That's $90,000. Nationally, at best, theaters can raise only about 50 percent of their operating budget through ticket sales and sponsorships. That's how we came to our $45,000 goal. 

Here are just some typical line items from our first season consisting of Turtles by John Greiner-Ferris, From The Deep by Cassie M. Seinuk, and Three by Emily Kaye Lazzaro:

  • Stipends: $12,000.00
  • The combined cost of theater rental: $9,450.00
  • Printing and postage: $1,500.00
  • Insurance: approx. $1,500.00
  • Costumes: $1,500.00
  • Box office set up fees: $450.00

This list doesn't include costs like props, building material for sets, gels for the lights, and additional lights or sound equipment not supplied by the theater. 

While we give our time and expertise freely, there are fixed yearly administrative costs of running Boston Public Works such as:

  • Professional membership to groups like Fractured Atlas and StageSource: $200.00
  • Website, including hosting, email, & domain: $200.00

We Will Pay Our Artists

And a big, important line item for us will be stipends for all the artists. Non-union theater artists in Boston normally work for a pittance, or even nothing at all. So, along with paying for all the necessities of theater, it's important to us to add one major expense: A generous stipend for every artist who works on our productions. It will attract serious talent to our company. While it won't be a livable wage, it will be a step in that direction. It's time the era of free artistic labor goes by the wayside. It's the right and fair thing to do.

We Don't Have A Plan B

Failure is not an option. Playwriting is what we live and die for. Each playwright will act as her or his own artistic director, making Boston Public Works the only theater in Boston where your experience will consist of a multitude of voices. Think of Forrest Gump's box of chocolates, only with Boston Public Works, you'll know what to expect. 

Just in our first season you will see:

  • John's passion for defending the little guy and bringing parity and diversity to Boston stages with Turtles
  • Cassie's dedication to explore untold stories of captive people in the From The Deep, including Israeli issues and questions of identity
  • Emily's interest in the value of women on stage and of young womens' stories, and finding humor in the darkness of human suffering in Three. 

How You Can Help

We've taken up the torch to create more slots for new work and pave the way for other playwrights to do the same in Boston. We're taking on a huge project, but with your help it's very much within reach. You can help us by:

  • Making a donation. Every little bit helps, even a few dollars.
  • Spreading the word. Tell your friends, family, and especially that person you know who drives the Mercedes.
  • Seeing our plays. You'll be part of a movement that's changing the way new theatrical work is done in Boston. 

Thank you. 

All the Ps, at Boston Public Works

(P1 - P9) John Greiner-Ferris, Cassie M. Seinuk, Emily Kaye Lazzaro, Jess Foster, Phil Berman, Kevin Mullins, Jim Dalglish, Barbara Blumenthal-Erhrlich, Laura Neubauer

John's passion for defending the little guy and bringing parity and diversity to Boston stages with Turtles


Cassie's dedication to explore untold stories of captive people in the From The Deep, including Israeli issues and questions of identity


Emily's interest in the value of women on stage and of young womens' stories, and finding humor in the darkness of human suffering in Three. 


How You Can HelpWe've taken up the torch to create more slots for new work and pave the way for other playwrights to do the same in Boston. We're taking on a huge project, but with your help it's very much within reach. You can help us by:
Making a donation. Every little bit helps, even a few dollars.
Spreading the word. Tell your friends, family, and especially that person you know who drives the Mercedes.
Seeing our plays. You'll be part of a movement that's changing the way new theatrical work is done in Boston. 
Thank you. All the Ps, at Boston Public Works(P1 - P9) John Greiner-Ferris, Cassie M. Seinuk, Emily Kaye Lazzaro, Jess Foster, Phil Berman, Kevin Mullins, Jim Dalglish, Barbara Blumenthal-Erhrlich, Laura Neubauer

story:
I'm Asha Thomas, an American choreographer and dancer that has been living and working in Paris for the past seven years. I am creating a new dance work entitled Ghazals, which is a duet inspired by the ancient Persian poetry of the mystic Hafiz.  For this production, I have invited Ronald K. Brown, acclaimed New York-based choreographer, as an artistic collaborator and will be joined onstage by French dancer David Gaulein-Stef. 


“Even after all this time, the Sun never says to the Earth, You Owe Me. Look what happens with a love like that, it lights the whole sky.” This translated poem by Hafiz is what caught my attention and prompted me to explore how the art of this 14th century poet could influence my own. 


Ghazals combines contemporary dance, text and spoken word to find a meeting  place of different cultures and different lifetimes. It is an attempt to join the ancient with the modern, the east with the west, and the earthly with the ethereal.  


Your support would go towards the production costs of this new work which includes:
Costumes                                 150€   /   $207
Lighting                                      50€    /   $69
Sound                                        100€   /  $138
Administrative fees                440€  /  $608
Publicity,photos, video          1040€ / $1436
Salaries                                     6 522€ /  $9007
Social Charges                        3 949€ / $5454
Meals and Lodging                 1 978€  /  $2732
Transportation                          2 307€ / $3187
TOTAL                                       16, 536 €/$22, 837  
                                                  - 11, 000 € /$ 15,195 (co-production funding)
  

To be raised:   5, 536€  / $7, 642

Whether it be by making a financial donation and/or spreading the word, I hope that together we can make this new production a success! Thank you very much.


ASHA THOMAS (Atlanta, Georgia, United States) received her Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from The Juilliard School in New York City in 1999 under the direction of Benjamin Harkarvy and, upon graduating, became a member of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater where she was a principal dancer for eight years. In 2007, Asha relocated to France to work as a freelance artist with several choreographers including, Salia nï Seydou, Raphaëlle Delaunay/ Compagnie Traces, Richard Siegal /The Bakery, Prue Lang/ PLANT, and most recently with Philippe Ménard/ Compagnie pm. Born from a desire to develop her own choreography, Asha Thomas started Compagnie Ima in 2010. That same year she created and performed a solo  "Mi Peñita Negra”, that was presented in Germany, France and Morocco. Asha also works with the Africa Regional Services department of the US State Department in France that sends American artists to Africa to perform, give workshops, and do cultural outreach. For more information, go to www.compagnieima.org

story:
Mercia Entertainment:

Inspired by the past, Celebrating the present,

Driven toward the future

Our Story

On the heels of our first successful reading of Voodoo Macbeth, we bring you one of the greatest Shakespearean love stories, Antony and Cleopatra.


Synopsis

Mark Antony, one of the three rulers of the Roman Empire, spends his time in Egypt, living a life of decadence and conducting an affair with the country's beautiful queen, Cleopatra. When a message arrives informing him that his wife, Fulvia, is dead and that Pompey is raising an army to rebel against the triumvirate, Antony decides to return to Rome. In Antony's absence, Octavius Caesar and Lepidus, his fellow triumvirs, worry about Pompey's increasing strength. Caesar condemns Antony for neglecting his duties as a statesman and military officer in order to live a decadent life by Cleopatra's side.

The news of his wife's death and imminent battle pricks Antony's sense of duty, and he feels compelled to return to Rome. Upon his arrival, he and Caesar quarrel, while Lepidus ineffectually tries to make peace. Realizing that an alliance is necessary to defeat Pompey, Antony and Caesar agree that Antony will marry Caesar's sister, Octavia, who will solidify their loyalty to one another. Enobarbus, Antony's closest friend, predicts to Caesar's men that, despite the marriage, Antony will surely return to Cleopatra.

In Egypt, Cleopatra learns of Antony's marriage and flies into a jealous rage. However, when a messenger delivers word that Octavia is plain and unimpressive, Cleopatra becomes confident that she will win Antony back. The triumvirs meet Pompey and settle their differences without going to battle. Pompey agrees to keep peace in exchange for rule over Sicily and Sardinia. That evening, the four men drink to celebrate their truce. One of Pompey's soldiers discloses to him a plan to assassinate the triumvirs, thereby delivering world power into Pompey's hands, but Pompey dismisses the scheme as an affront to his honor. Meanwhile, one of Antony's -generals wins a victory over the kingdom of Parthia.

Antony and Octavia depart for Athens. Once they are gone, Caesar breaks his truce, wages war against Pompey, and defeats him. After using Lepidus's army to secure a victory, he accuses Lepidus of treason, imprisons him, and confiscates his land and possessions. This news angers Antony, as do the rumors that Caesar has been speaking out against him in public. Octavia pleads with Antony to maintain a peaceful relationship with her brother. Should Antony and Caesar fight, she says, her affections would be painfully divided. Antony dispatches her to Rome on a peace mission, and quickly returns to Egypt and Cleopatra. There, he raises a large army to fight Caesar, and Caesar, incensed over Antony's treatment of his sister, responds in kind. Caesar commands his army and navy to Egypt. Ignoring all advice to the contrary, Antony elects to fight him at sea, allowing Cleopatra to command a ship despite Enobarbus's strong objections. Antony's forces lose the battle when Cleopatra's ship flees and Antony's follows, leaving the rest of the fleet vulnerable.

Antony despairs, condemning Cleopatra for leading him into infamy but quickly forgiving her. He and Cleopatra send requests to their conqueror: Antony asks to be allowed to live in Egypt, while Cleopatra asks that her kingdom be passed down to her rightful heirs. Caesar dismisses Antony's request, but he promises Cleopatra a fair hearing if she betrays her lover. Cleopatra seems to be giving thought to Caesar's message when Antony barges in, curses her for her treachery, and orders the innocent messenger whipped. When, moments later, Antony forgives Cleopatra, Enobarbus decides that his master is finished and defects to Caesar's camp.

Antony meets Caesar's troops in battle and scores an unexpected victory. When he learns of Enobarbus's desertion, Antony laments his own bad fortune, which he believes has corrupted an honorable man. He sends his friend's possessions to Caesar's camp and returns to Cleopatra to celebrate his victory. Enobarbus, undone by shame at his own disloyalty, bows under the weight of his guilt and dies. Another day brings another battle, and once again Antony meets Caesar at sea. As before, the Egyptian fleet proves treacherous; it abandons the fight and leaves Antony to suffer defeat. Convinced that his lover has betrayed him, Antony vows to kill Cleopatra. In order to protect herself, she quarters herself in her monument and sends word that she has committed suicide. Antony, racked with grief, determines to join his queen in the afterlife. He commands one of his attendants to fulfill his promise of unquestioned service and kill him. The attendant kills himself instead. Antony then falls on his own sword, but the wound is not immediately fatal. He is carried to Cleopatra's monument, where the lovers are reunited briefly before Antony's death. Caesar takes the queen prisoner, planning to display her in Rome as a testament to the might of his empire, but she learns of his plan and kills herself with the help of several poisonous snakes. Caesar has her buried beside Antony.

The Impact

To help facilitate the costs of the reading this next spring I'm asking you in this beautiful season of giving, to reach your pocket or purse and help us share this beautiful and seldom produced play.  This reading is slated to be fully produced in our 2012-2013 season and we are excited to get you on board and invested. We simply need $20 a day for the next 60 days to reach our goal!


What We Need & What You Get

Antony & Cleopatra-Staged Reading

by William Shakespeare

Directed by:
Seth Duerr

Wednesday, February 8th 2012
Shetler Studios
244 West 54th Street, Penthouse 1
7:00 p.m

FREE with reservation

(reservations@merciaentertainment.org)

Cast:

Antony- Seth Duerr*

Cleopatra- Mary Riley*
Caesar - Keith Merrill*
Enobarbus - Joseph Hamel
Charmian - Renee Williams
Lepidus - Luis de Amechazurra
Mardian - John Curtis
Eros/Ventidius/Euphronius - Evan Beskin
Menecrates/Scarus - Andrew Broussard

*Denotes member of Actor's Equity


Stage Manager- Michael Zumbrun

Event Assistance- Ben West, Dianna Lora & Susanna Randolph

If you are able to donate to our project, we would like to list your name as one of our supporters on both Mercia's website (www.merciaentertainment.org) and in the program for Voodoo Macbeth. Any remaining monies not used for the reading, will go toward a full production in the 2012-2013 season.


Other Ways You Can Help

"Like" our Facebook Page- http://www.facebook.com/merciaentertainment

Follow us on Twitter- http://www.twitter.com/MerciaEnt

Suggest this campaign to others by using the buttons at the top of the page.

Thanks for your donation and for spreading the word!
