story:
Who are we? And what are we doing?

Hello! We’re Mark Jackson and Megan Trout, two San Francisco Bay Area theater makers.


Though we’ve worked together many times at a variety of theaters, this gig is different. This time we're working for ourselves. 

With fiscal sponsorship from Independent Arts & Media, we’re producing, creating, and performing NOW FOR NOW, an original multimedia physical theater piece currently in development and set to premiere in San Francisco in July 2015, then tour nationally and internationally.

What's the show about?

NOW FOR NOW follows three possible relationships between a woman and man a generation apart—a daughter and father, a student and teacher, a romance—over 40 years. Their stories converge and diverge in dialogues, movement, and real-time texting and Skypes.

  • The show explores uncomfortable, ugly, embarrassing issues about age and gender dynamics with both depth and humor. 
  • It confronts the role technology plays in our relationships—not by the standard kvetching about Facebook but by really digging in. 
  • And it brings together elements of theater, dance, and technology in a unique, ambitious way for a modest-budget production with high standards and aims.

In addition to a variety of physical theater approaches, NOW FOR NOW uses high tech computer, video and Internet technologies. 

Our handheld devices are used live on stage to control the technical aspects of the production (lights, sound, and video) as well as to convey the story—making digital communications tech central to the production both practically and dramatically.

How much are we raising, and for what?

We’re hoping to raise $10,000 with this campaign. That’s just a third of our total budget. Here’s what we’re going to do with it:

Produce a two-week workshop in January 2015: 

  • To further develop the dramatic material of the piece.
  • And to solidify precisely how and by what means we operate the digital and other tech elements on stage in performance.
  • Key expenses include space and equipment rental, and properly paying a video/I.T. designer to work with us.

We’ll then purchase the digital hardware and software we find is needed to make the show happen, premiere it, and tour it—which likely includes:

  • A video projector
  • Portable projection screen
  • Higher capacity laptop video and sound cards
  • And software that allows us to wirelessly mix video, sound, and other tech elements between our handheld devices, laptops, and the video projector.

Most importantly, we’ll pay our collaborators and crew a proper fee!

  • By which we mean one that is neither embarrassing for us to offer, nor for them to accept.
  • Because artists on stage and off should be paid for their work.

Why donate?

Here’s the thing. We don’t have any money. That’s why we’re doing this campaign. And this is theater, so in the end we won’t be making a pile of money either. Theater has another value:

We’re hoping that you will donate to NOW FOR NOW because you believe that passionate, independently produced, fully artist-led theater is important and worth supporting in this grassroots way.

Also, as a live theater production NOW FOR NOW takes a progressive stance vis-a-vis the new Internet era, critiquing the role digital tech now plays in our relationships rather than merely and habitually bemoaning it. With your support we're making theater for and about the 21st Century.

We understand that different dollar amounts mean different things to different people. For some, $50 or $100 is the difference between making rent and not. For others, $500 or $1000 is totally doable. We’re grateful for whatever you can give. Even $10 helps! It all adds up!

And whatever you give is fully tax deductible through our fiscal sponsor, Independent Arts & Media, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit supporting people and projects that use media and the arts to build community and participation.

Risks, Challenges, and Impact!

Making theater is always a risk. What if it tanks? What if it’s brilliant but nobody comes?

That we’re producing NOW FOR NOW ourselves on top of creating and performing it ups the risk and challenge for us as well. But we’re up to it: 

  • Mark has been directing, writing, performing, producing, and otherwise making theater professionally for two decades on two continents. 
  • And though Megan might still be considered “fresh on the scene,” she’s already earned her reputation at a variety of professional Bay Area venues as a fearless artist capable of breaking both hearts and legs. 
  • (You can read our full biographies on our website if you like.) 


Also, NOW FOR NOW is about very personal issues that contemporary women and men are dealing with, so we’re putting ourselves out there on stage in some pretty extreme ways. (Oh just you wait!)

That’s a risk. That’s a challenge. And there WILL be an impact—on you and every audience member who comes to see it, in San Francisco and beyond.

Other ways you can help!

We know times are tight. If you don’t have money to spare at the moment, you might know someone who does. Help us spread the word about our campaign by Tweeting about it, posting a link on Facebook, or emailing particular people you know could help.

And if you know anyone at Apple or Epson, tell them to donate equipment to us! Their stuff is expensive!

If you CAN make a donation, please tell your friends you did. Word of mouth is our best ally!


Thank You!

For taking the time to read this.

For helping to spread the word.

For making the biggest donation you can comfortably afford to make.

And for keeping original, grassroots theater alive.

On and up!

Megan & Mark

can read our full biographies on our website if you like.) 


Also, NOW FOR NOW is about very personal issues that contemporary women and men are dealing with, so we’re putting ourselves out there on stage in some pretty extreme ways. (Oh just you wait!)That’s a risk. That’s a challenge. And there WILL be an impact—on you and every audience member who comes to see it, in San Francisco and beyond.Other ways you can help!We know times are tight. If you don’t have money to spare at
the moment, you might know someone who does. Help us spread the word about our
campaign by Tweeting about it, posting a link on Facebook, or emailing particular
people you know could help.
And if you know anyone at Apple or Epson, tell them to
donate equipment to us! Their stuff is expensive!
If you CAN make a donation, please tell your friends you
did. Word of mouth is our best ally!
Thank You!
For taking the time to read this.
For helping to spread the word.
For making the biggest donation you can comfortably afford
to make.
And for keeping original, grassroots theater alive.
On and up!
Megan & Mark

story:
Short Summary

Olá Amigos!

I've been invited to perform as a guest by Henrique Fontes, the artistic director of Casa da Ribeira, an educational and cultural center in Natal on the Northeast coast of Brazil. The play, called Lamatown, is adapted from Henryk Ibsen's Enemy of the People and will be created with the performers in a three month collaborative process based on elements of Richard Schechner's Environmental Theatre. It is co-directed by Fontes and Michele Minnick, who worked extensively with Schechner to develop rasaboxes, a physical and emotional tool for training actors and creating performance. Check out Minnick and Paula Murray Cole's article about rasaboxes here.

Fontes has secured a grant that covers housing and a modest living stipend for three months while I am working on the project. The only missing piece is the plane ticket to Brazil, which is very expensive and beyond my current budget. The opportunity came together on short notice, and I have to come up with airfare pronto! 

What I Need & What You Get

Pretty straightforward. Airfare to Brazil is hovering at about $1450, and the longer I wait, the more costly it gets. Your donation will go entirely to cover airfare. 

Any funding above and beyond this goal will go towards travel within Brazil to see friends and network with artists in Rio de Janeiro and São Paolo. 

As a thank you for your generosity, I offer the following gifts:

  • $5 - My undying gratitude.
  • $10 - My undying gratitude and a hand written postcard from Brazil.
  • $25 - All of the above + a descriptive and evocative hand written letter sent to you by post.
  • $50 - All of the above + photos of Brazil taken by me sent to you by post.
  • $100 - All of the above + a short documentary video, narrated by me, at least partly in Portuguese, which brings to life the sights and sounds of Brazil.
I am approaching this as an occasion to connect more fully with you, my friends and supporters, in a way that goes beyond the daily snippets and micro interactions of the digital world. Don't get me wrong, I love digital communication, and use it obsessively. But for me this journey is largely about reconnecting with the physical world, with the physical sensations, smells, and sounds of a specific time and place. Through these objects, I hope to share with you a little bit of that physical connectedness to a place that until now I have loved only from afar. 
Abraços a todos!

What This Means for Me

There are a few strands of this project that are equally important to me.

  • The People of Brazil: My first encounter with members of LUME Teatro, nearly 15 years ago, sparked a deep fascination with Brazilian performance and love for the wonderful, kind, intense people of Brazil. Since then I've made many Brazilian friends, and recently completed a stint as a performance facilitator at MoMA in an exhibition on Brazilian artist Lygia Clark, which was a magical experience that deepened my appreciation for the social, spiritual, and sensory nature of art in Brazil. Lamatown will be a valuable opportunity to strengthen these relationships and further develop artistic connections for future collaborations. 
  • The Play: Lamatown, (lama=mud) based on Ibsen's Enemy of the People, is a superb play, and speaks to some key themes in our interconnected contemporary world, including environmentalism, corruption, globalization, and the complicated politics of doing the right thing. This will be a significant opportunity to explore these themes both in theory and practice. As a foreigner living in Brazil I will occupy a rare vantage point from which to observe and contribute to this discussion as it relates to specific challenges in Brazilian society. 
  • The Process: I first worked with a training method that was similar to rasaboxes (although less thoroughly articulated) while a student at the Dell'Arte International School of Physical Theatre. After researching rasaboxes and realizing the potential for building rich expressionistic characters and creating fully committed physical phrases for performance, I incorporated it into the working process for Woyzeck, which I co-directed with Ben Roberts and Ominous Horse Theatre Company in Portland, Oregon a couple years ago. Last summer I had the opportunity to train with Minnick during an intensive three week session at the start of a master's program in Performance Studies at NYU, and recently I assisted Minnick in teaching rasaboxes and contact improvisation to the incoming graduate students at NYU. It is an extraordinary tool for performance, training, and physical and emotional exercise. This project will deepen my engagement with rasaboxes as a tool for devising, which I intend to incorporate into further teaching and performance work. 

    Challenges

    The project begins soon—September 24th! I am limiting this campaign to 10 days because beyond this, airfare is likely to become too costly for me to go. If I can't raise the funds by September 7th, I may have to cancel. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can't contribute, you can still help by sharing my campaign, and encouraging others to contribute. 

    Thank you for your support! 

    Muito obrigado!

story:
UPDATE!  For our final fundraising day we are slashing the prices once again for $5 Friday!  That means for every first time donor your donation will be DOUBLED!  Yahoo!!  Spread the word!

UPDATE!  Thursday, December 4th is officially $10 Thursday!  I know many of you can't afford a $20 donation so we've slashed the prices JUST FOR YOU!  How many $10 donations do you think we can get today!?

Tuesday, December 2nd is the National Day of Giving, also known as #GivingTuesday.  It's the day for putting aside all the gift buying and chaos of this past weekend and think about how YOU can make a difference to a nonprofit organization.  Small nonprofits like Monkeyhouse rely on the generosity and enthusiasm of donors at every level.  

When faced with a day like #GivingTuesday and the decision of who should get your end of year contribution, why donate to an arts nonprofit instead of someone providing hunger relief or clothing for homeless veterans?  What does this small organization offer to make us worthy of your donating dollars?

While we can't compete dollar for dollar with larger nonprofits, we do provide invaluable services to a community that's losing resources left and right.  In 2014 we kicked off one of our most successful seasons to date, and we're only a quarter of the way through it.  We presented the work of two more company choreographers, Sarah Feinberg and Nikki Sao Pedro-Welch in New York City; got a new community partner, Not Your Average Joe's, during our month long birthday celebration in October; partnered with the artistic director of a new local company, Paradise Lost, during ChoreoFest; presented the first full length site specific work created by company member Nikki Sao Pedro-Welch and partnered with the US Dept of State to host our first international residency with the artists of Fleur d'Orange from Morocco.  Still coming this year we are continuing our relationship with Endicott College by setting two works on their students as part of their Rep 10 concert.

We have been able to do all this and much more in the past year.  Think of what we can do next year or the year after that with your help!?

The $20 Challenge.

An incredible donor will donate $1 for every returning donor and $5 for every first time donor!  So your donation will help us raising matching funds!  Here's how you can help:

  • Make a donation!  Your $20 $10 $5 makes a huge difference to a small organization like us!  Looking for a gift for that person who has everything?  Why not make a contribution in their name?! 
  • Take the New Donor Pledge!  It's the holiday season and everyone is looking for the perfect organization to give their year end contributions to.  A generous donor has offered to donate an additional $5 for every first time donor to Monkeyhouse!  Just think, if you get 10 of your friends to each make a $20 $10 $5  donation to Monkeyhouse we will get an additional $50 for the first time donor pledge!  That means your donation doubles!  How many of your friends will take the New Donor Pledge?
  • Spread the word!  The easiest way to meet our goal is through social media!  So get on Facebook, Twitter and email and start spreading the news!  $20 $10 $5  means giving up just a few cups of coffee for a really wonderful cause!

Three Fast Facts About Monkeyhouse!

  • Monkeyhouse's many programs have worked with aspiring artists, art enthusiasts and audience members ranging from children at the the Healy School and the Fuller Craft Museum, teenagers at Impulse Dance Center and Natick High School, families at BOOMTOWN and the Peabody Essex Museum, adults in Dance'n Feet and seniors in nursing homes and senior centers throughout the greater Boston area.
  • Through Against the Odds Monkeyhouse has mentored, supported and presented dozens of artists at all levels of their careers including Ryan Casey, Janelle Gilchrist, Luminarium, Seven's Not Enough, Mariah Steele, Lynn Schwab, students from Impulse Dance Center, Audra Carabetta, Eva Dean Dance, Risher Reddick, Josh Hilberman, TAProject, Dance'n Feet and so many more.
  • Monkeyhouse is THRILLED to be returning to the Multicultural Arts Center in Cambridge in 2015 for a full length concert!

Monkeyhouse is THRILLED to be returning to the Multicultural Arts Center in Cambridge in 2015 for a full length concert!

story:
We are Monster Moon Theatre.

Native to Vancouver, we are a small theatre company interested in exploring the darker side of human kind. Monster Moon was founded in the summer of 2012 with our very first production of Danny and the Deep Blue Sea. It is a script we have watched grow from a movement-based performance into an intimate, naturalistic piece. It's been a dream of ours to take Danny  to the Edinburgh Fringe for many years now and, with your help, it can become a reality! With your support, we will be able to perform our very first international show at the biggest Fringe festival in the world. 

What We Need From You.

Our total goal for this project to get our base funding of $5,000. This campaign is going to attribute for $2,000 of that. This is the bare minimum we need to do the show, and the extra $3,000 will allow us to get our ideal set, costumes, lighting, insurance and all the other fun things (i.e. proper insurance)! This $2,000, along with other fundraisers we have done in the past will help us get:


1) The rights to put on the show

2) Our marketing (such as posters, advertising, and press coverage)

3) Fringe Festival Fee

4) Some of our venue costs


What You Get From Us!

Perks! Perks! Perks! We love our contributors and think that you should get to feel that love! Check out our perks section for all the goodies and appreciation your heart can desire! And if there's a perk you'd like that isn't on our list, give us a shout. We love to personalize things and we love to share: Is it someone's birthday and you need a special video? Would you or someone you know like to have coffee and talk about what it's like to be a start-up theatre company in Vancouver, or how art is affecting our next generation? Do you or your cat need a personalized (a.k.a. matching) christmas sweater? 


Why Help Us?!

To us, this project is invaluable. Danny and the Deep Blue Sea tells a story of two tormented New Yorkers that cross paths in the underbelly of the Bronx and a bar becomes a late night confessional. We love this script because it makes you question your reasons for judging people. You don't know everyone's story, what's shaped them, what's hurt them, and you can't tell why people react certain ways until you talk to them. This story is a beautiful example of what a little compassion can do for a damaged soul.
We have performed Danny numerous times around B.C, from the Director's Festival in Chilliwack, to Renegade Theatre and back to where it began at Douglas College. Each time we have performed Danny, we've donated 100% of the proceeds to charities (including The Vancouver Women's Shelter and Rape Relief and Covenant House). We recently produced our latest show in December, BASH: Latterday Plays  by Neil Labute, as a fundraiser for this production. 

If you'd like anymore info on us and our shows you can check out our website:
monstermoontheatre.com

Risks and Challenges.

The life of theatre is always full of risks and challenges but that's okay! We take every new opportunity and see how it can make us stronger as a company. Of course there is a million things to do and even more that could go wrong but we believe in our show and our work. In the worst case scenario (say a giant frog attacked our venue and we were unable to do the show, oh my!) all of the money collected would go straight into our 2015/16 season with partial donations going towards charity. But lets not think about that, let us focus on the positive and keep our eyes on the prize!

Other Ways You Can Help (Make Some Noise!)

Money isn't the only way that helps us out, just having your support means the world! By spreading the word about this project you are helping us immensely. If you do spread the word though let us know, because we want to thank every single person that helps us reach our goal. You can use the share tool on the left side and start making some noise about supporting small time theatre!


Thank yous.

We just wanted to say a big thank you to everyone who has supported us so far! Jamie-Leigh Gonzales and Tim Latz for the beautiful promo video, our families for the countless amount of rides to drag set around, our audiences, donors and volunteers thus far, and our mentors  who have guided us. We wouldn't be where we are without you all and it means so much to us to have that support.

THANK YOU.

story:
C'est quoi ça, Solos? 

Solos, c'est une présentation de Bloody Underrated et Plein Espace, en collaboration avec le Théâtre MainLine. Ensemble, on veut créer un nouveau festival annuel qui célèbre la création solo, qui aura lieu de 6 au 9 novembre 2013. Pourquoi? Parce que c'est fascinant de voir ce qu'un individu peut créer dans un environnement où il est seul. Parce que la liberté de création solo permet de prendre des risques inhabituels, et d'en être le seul perdant si ça ne marche pas. Bref, parce que des spectacles solos, on adore ça, et on en veut plus.

Ce qu'on a besoin, ce que vous recevez.

Avec cette campagne de financement, on tente d'obtenir 1500$ pour aider avec la mise en marché et la production générale du festival. Cette somme nous permettra d'imprimer nos affiches, programmes, billets, etc. De plus, cette somme nous aidera à couvrir les frais de location de salle et de répétitions techniques des artistes. Avec un don, vous pouvez recevoir :

- Un remerciement dans notre programme;

- Une affiche signée par les artistes;

- Un billet, une paire de billets, ou même une passe valide pour tous les spectacles;

- Une soirée au resto avant votre spectacle;

- Des billets pour des événements de Bloody Underrated pour les 6 prochains mois;

- Notre amour éternel;

- Plus encore!

Ça donne quoi, finalement?

Ça donne qu'on vous remplit tous vos mois de novembre du futur avec plein de spectacles mémorables, et peut-être même inoubliables. Ça nous permet de donner plus de chances aux artistes solos d'expérimenter avec leurs spectacles, et de les présenter à de nouveaux publics. Ça donne à Montréal un nouveau festival de théâtre bilingue qui encourage la collaboration entre les communautés francophones et anglophones, et qui facilite le partage de public, qui peuvent ici s'unir. Ça donne mal au coeur tellement on veut le faire, avec votre aide!

Ouin, mais j'ai pas d'argent moi non plus...

C'est pas grave! Si t'aimes notre projet, on t'encourage à encourager tout le monde que tu connais à contribuer. Aussi, quand viendra le temps du festival, on t'encourage à venir faire du bénévolat avec nous! Un festival, c'est une micro-communauté, et on veut que tu soit dans la nôtre.

Merci!

--

What's this "Solos" thing?

Solos is a co-presentation by Bloody Underrated and Plein Espace, in collaboration with MainLine Theatre. Together, we aim to create a new annual festival that celebrates solo creations, from November 6th to 9th 2013. Why? Because it's fascinating to see what people create when they're working in a solo environment. Because freedom of creation in a solo setting allows performers to take unusual risks, and to be the only person losing if it all fails - while we all stand to win from their efforts. Really, it's because we love solo shows, and we want more of them.

What we need, what you can get:

With this funding campaign, we're trying to raise 1500$ to help with general production and marketing for the festival. This small sum would allow us to print our posters, programs, tickets, etc. Even more, it would help cover the costs of rental and of technical rehearsals. Don't worry, we're a non-profit - any money coming into this campaign is going right back into the festival, not in our pockets. With your contribution, you can get sweet perks like:

- A great big thank you in our program,

- A poster signed by every artists performing in this year's festival,

- One ticket, a pair of tickets, or even a VIP pass to the festival,

- Dinner for two before your show,

- Tickets to Bloody Underrated events for the next six months,

- Our undying love,

- And more!

And what does this accomplish?

It makes it possible for us to fill all of your future Novembers with memorable, maybe even unforgettable shows. It allows us to give solo artists more chances to experiment with and then display their work, and to take it to new audiences. It gives Montreal a new bilingual festival that encourages Franco and Anglo cultures to collaborate, and that facilitates the sharing of audiences between these two communities, that can be united here. It gives us butterflies in our stomachs and endless jitters because we're dying to make this happen.

Sounds great, but I don't have any money either...

That's totally fine! You can help us by spreading the word through all of your networks if you like what we're trying to do. And then, come festival time, you can help us out by volunteering with us! Festivals are basically micro-communities, and we'd like you to join ours.

Thanks!
story_txt:
C'est quoi ça, Solos? 

Solos, c'est une présentation de Bloody Underrated et Plein Espace, en collaboration avec le Théâtre MainLine. Ensemble, on veut créer un nouveau festival annuel qui célèbre la création solo, qui aura lieu de 6 au 9 novembre 2013. Pourquoi? Parce que c'est fascinant de voir ce qu'un individu peut créer dans un environnement où il est seul. Parce que la liberté de création solo permet de prendre des risques inhabituels, et d'en être le seul perdant si ça ne marche pas. Bref, parce que des spectacles solos, on adore ça, et on en veut plus.


Ce qu'on a besoin, ce que vous recevez.
Avec cette campagne de financement, on tente d'obtenir 1500$ pour aider avec la mise en marché et la production générale du festival. Cette somme nous permettra d'imprimer nos affiches, programmes, billets, etc. De plus, cette somme nous aidera à couvrir les frais de location de salle et de répétitions techniques des artistes. Avec un don, vous pouvez recevoir :
- Un remerciement dans notre programme;
- Une affiche signée par les artistes;
- Un billet, une paire de billets, ou même une passe valide pour tous les spectacles;
- Une soirée au resto avant votre spectacle;
- Des billets pour des événements de Bloody Underrated pour les 6 prochains mois;
- Notre amour éternel;
- Plus encore!


Ça donne quoi, finalement?
Ça donne qu'on vous remplit tous vos mois de novembre du futur avec plein de spectacles mémorables, et peut-être même inoubliables. Ça nous permet de donner plus de chances aux artistes solos d'expérimenter avec leurs spectacles, et de les présenter à de nouveaux publics. Ça donne à Montréal un nouveau festival de théâtre bilingue qui encourage la collaboration entre les communautés francophones et anglophones, et qui facilite le partage de public, qui peuvent ici s'unir. Ça donne mal au coeur tellement on veut le faire, avec votre aide!


Ouin, mais j'ai pas d'argent moi non plus...
C'est pas grave! Si t'aimes notre projet, on t'encourage à encourager tout le monde que tu connais à contribuer. Aussi, quand viendra le temps du festival, on t'encourage à venir faire du bénévolat avec nous! Un festival, c'est une micro-communauté, et on veut que tu soit dans la nôtre.
Merci!

--

What's this "Solos" thing?
Solos is a co-presentation by Bloody Underrated and Plein Espace, in collaboration with MainLine Theatre. Together, we aim to create a new annual festival that celebrates solo creations, from November 6th to 9th 2013. Why? Because it's fascinating to see what people create when they're working in a solo environment. Because freedom of creation in a solo setting allows performers to take unusual risks, and to be the only person losing if it all fails - while we all stand to win from their efforts. Really, it's because we love solo shows, and we want more of them.


What we need, what you can get:
With this funding campaign, we're trying to raise 1500$ to help with general production and marketing for the festival. This small sum would allow us to print our posters, programs, tickets, etc. Even more, it would help cover the costs of rental and of technical rehearsals. Don't worry, we're a non-profit - any money coming into this campaign is going right back into the festival, not in our pockets. With your contribution, you can get sweet perks like:
- A great big thank you in our program,
- A poster signed by every artists performing in this year's festival,
- One ticket, a pair of tickets, or even a VIP pass to the festival,
- Dinner for two before your show,
- Tickets to Bloody Underrated events for the next six months,
- Our undying love,
- And more!


And what does this accomplish?
It makes it possible for us to fill all of your future Novembers with memorable, maybe even unforgettable shows. It allows us to give solo artists more chances to experiment with and then display their work, and to take it to new audiences. It gives Montreal a new bilingual festival that encourages Franco and Anglo cultures to collaborate, and that facilitates the sharing of audiences between these two communities, that can be united here. It gives us butterflies in our stomachs and endless jitters because we're dying to make this happen.


Sounds great, but I don't have any money either...
That's totally fine! You can help us by spreading the word through all of your networks if you like what we're trying to do. And then, come festival time, you can help us out by volunteering with us! Festivals are basically micro-communities, and we'd like you to join ours.
Thanks!

story:
Short Summary

Dance on the Lawn is a small, all-volunteer organization dedicated to exposing everyone -- especially folks intimidated by big ticket prices and fancy theaters -- to the glory of dance in all its forms. We present an annual outdoor dance festival, free of charge and open to everyone.  We have also established a mentorship program for young artists, awarding an annual $1000 stipend to an "Emerging Commissioned New Jersey Choreographer."  

Our founder, Charmaine Warren, has performed with several New York dance companies and is a former faculty member at The Ailey School, Fordham University, and the Joffrey Ballet School's Jazz and Contemporary Trainee Program. She curates dance festivals for Harlem Stage and the Wassiac Project. Managing Director Laura Marchese is a dancer, arts educator and co-author of Dance to Learn, a developmental dance curriculum currently in use throughout NJ. Under their enthusiastic guidance, DOTL has grown to include an entire team of volunteers are are working hard to help make DOTL 2018 a success.  

Charmaine and Laura are fiercely committed to the power of dance to move us, to change our perspectives, and to deepen our empathy and compassion. They are passionate about sharing that power, and know that Dance on the Lawn can give everyone a chance to see and feel how a little dance can rock your world.  

What We Need & What You Get

Dance on the Lawn has just one goal -- to present a high-quality, free dance festival on a green lawn. The most important element we need for that is dancers - therefore, the most money we need is for artist stipends. Next, we need a stage and a marley floor for them to dance on, and then, we need the little things like water, refreshments, ice and band-aids. 

We have received support from local community organizations in our home base of Montclair, NJ,  including Toni’s Kitchen, Studio042, Jocelyn Hassenfeld, and TonyTurnerPhotography. Additional support comes from The Wassaic Project,
Adria Rolnik PR, and ﻿Dance New Jersey.  

Dance on the Lawn offers the community direct, free and open access to a range of dance companies and performers. Year after year, we see families, seniors, individuals with disabilities, arts aficionados and dance luminaries join together in a celebration of the pure beauty of bodies in motion.

The Impact

Much of our support is in-kind. The "lawn," for example, is donated.  But pretty much all the rest of it, especially the artist stipends, comes from your contributions. Know that you will have a direct hand in making our festival a reality, and set us on a path to success for the next five years. 

DOTL 2018 Lineup:

2018 NJ Emerging Commissioned Choreographer:
Javier Padilla and The Movement Playground

New Jersey Schools:
Unique Performing Arts Center
Sharron Miller's Academy for the Performing Arts
New Jersey Dance Theatre Ensemble
DanceWorks & Co

​New Jersey Companies:
MeenMoves
Freespace Dance

New Jersey Tap Celebration:
Maurice Chestnut
Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards 

​5th Anniversary Celebration of DOTL's Emerging NJ Choreographers:
Robert Mark Burke (2014)
Kyle Marshall (2015)
Lauren Connolly 2016)

New York Companies: 
Barkha Dance Company
Ayodele Casel

Risks & Challenges

Here's the thing. DOTL is an all-volunteer organization -- no one on our staff is paid. We devote most of our time looking for kind people to donate basics like microphones. We do apply for grants, but most institutions are unwilling to fund an organization as new and as "all-volunteer" as DOTL. Maybe someday we'll be big enough to attract big grants and deep-pocket donors -- but right now, your help is crucial!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation at this time, here are some ways you can help our organization:

Help us get the word out! If you can't donate, maybe someone you know can! Share our Indiegogo campaign with your e-mail list or on your social media platforms. The more people who know about our project, the better! 

Volunteer! DOTL is happy to accept any skill set you'd like to contribute (marketing, development, accounting, outreach, . . . and anyone with enthusiasm for dance)

Come to the event! Even if you can't offer a donation, we would love to see your smiling face on Saturday, Sept. 8th at St. Luke's Episcopal Church (73 South Fullerton Avenue, Montclair NJ)  at 3pm. Children are more than welcome, they're encouraged!

story:
Creatures of Habit


My choreographic practice is centered around an exploration of personal idiosyncrasy taken to physical extremes, combined with a passion for physical humor. Rather than working to develop one unified movement aesthetic, I create dances in which each performer embodies a single, hyper-specific character trait and generates an individual movement vocabulary from this embodiment. The results range from the extremely tragic to the hilariously absurd. Underlying my practice is a fascination with the ways in which personality resonates in physicality.

The new work will feature seven male dancers, with whom I have already begun working. I am fortunate to have an extremely talented, passionate and intelligent cast of movement artists. Each dancer will be taking on a single trait à la the “Seven Dwarves” : happy, sleepy, dopey, grumpy joined by: envy, ambition and apathy. From the one-dimensionality and extreme specificity of these single traits, we will generate a three-dimensional on-stage universe by exploring how these traits move and interact with one another.

This universe is inspired in part by the play “No Exit” by Jean-Paul Sartre, The 1944 existentialist French play that suggests that “hell is other people”. the seven temperaments will be paraded into the enclosed space and be forced to navigate each other's one dimensional personality, body and desires. 


About Jonathan

Jonathan Royse Windham is a native of Colorado and grew up with a musical theater background, always having an affinity for choreographing. He attended SUNY Purchase after high school concentrating in ballet, and spent a season with American Repertory Ballet. After ARB he worked with Gallim Dance touring the continental US as well as Europe, and was named one of Dance Magazines “25 to Watch” for 2013. In addition, He has worked with The Metropolitan Opera, The Santa Fe Opera, Brian Brooks, Brice Mousset (OUI danse), Terra Firma Dance Theater, the Kevin Wynn Collective, Ramon Oller, Alexandre Proia, and the DASH Ensemble.

His choreography has been shown several times at Dixon Place, Dancers Responding to AIDS at the Cedar Lake Theater, the American Repertory Ballet choreography workshop, Philadelphia Fringe Festival, The Staller Center at Stony brook, Center for Performance Research. He is also founding choreographer and former curator at the Current Sessions.


What We Need 

I have generously been commissioned by Dixon Place to make this piece come to fruition, but we still need some help. Here's why:

  • Dancers (rehearsal pay and performance fee) - $4,500
  • Costumes - $400
  • Set - $800
  • Lighting design- $ 400
  • Photo and video (promotional and show documentation) - $600
  • Rehearsal Space - $800

set rendering by Brandon McNeel. 

I am also fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas! This means that all donations are tax deductable. 


The Impact

I have been creating three to seventeen minute dance-theater works which have been featured at venues throughout New York City. This is a landmark opportunity in my choreographic career to develop my work on a larger scale, with full production values. The pieces I have created have all been a form of research for an opportunity like this.


Another exciting aspect of this run is that each show will open with another choreographer's work, featuring a short piece from a different choreographer each night, 


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute just come on down and put your butt in one of the seats! 


    October 3rd, 4th, 10th, 11th, 17th & 18th


    161 Chrystie St, New York, NY 10002
    (212) 219-0736


    www.jonathanroysewindham.com

    www.dixonplace.org


    Photos by Nir Arieli

story:
Who is Vatra?

Vatra is a group of fire performers based in the d

owntown Phoenix arts community. Our amazing and multi-talented little group consists of four main members:     

Amy Jean, Sheri Amour, Crimson Phoenix, and Janey Radiant. (you can see our photos in the gallery above) 

We came together as a group at a little spot called the Firehouse Gallery and have been training and performing together for over two years. Utilizing fire tools such as poi, hoop, batons, fans and a neat little thing called a fire orb, we've done many free performances for the community (and already have plans for more) as well as a few paid gigs here and there.



What We Need & What You Get

We want to kick it up a notch... In order to come up with group choreography and duet routines to knock your socks off, we need some new equipment!

All funds go toward improving our performances for you, but more specifically:

  • Poi sets (4 @ $100 each)
  • Fan sets  (3-4 @ $110 each)
  • Palm torch sets (4 @ $85 each) 
  • Replace a stolen fire hoop ($150-200)
  • Safety equipment, stage props & fuel ($150-200 per person)
  • Insurance ($65-80 per person)
  • Other awesome  fire tools to rock on stage

First and foremost we need matching sets of tools for each member, performers insurance, and safety equipment. Your contribution goes towards strengthening our performances, making us "legal" and adding new and exciting tools to our repertoire so we can burn it up, down and all around!

And what do YOU get? Anything from a great big thanks, to a group performance just for you, and all sorts of goodies in between! I'm personally most hopeful I get to make a video to a song of your choice, however we're all quite excited to do the photo shoot for the posters! Yeeeow!

You'll be able to see our new performances at various events in the future. Plus you'll be able to find all of our photos and videos on our website  www.vatracollective.com and our youtube channel at www.youtube.com/vatraphx


The Impact

Although we've only been called Vatra for about a year, we've been spinning fire together for up to three in some cases, with a combined flow, dance and performance time that is too long to count!  During our time with fire, our tool sets have remained very limited due to lack of funds. This hasn't stopped us however, we're flow addicts and fire fiends that just dont know when to quit!

New tools would make it possible for us to come up with choreography and new act and routines that we'll surely be showing off at our favorite 3rd friday open mic (Firestage at the Firehouse for those that dont know!) and using for all the gigs we'll be pursuing during this year and all those to come!


Risks & Challenges

    Little did we know when we found fire spinning, hooping, dance, and stage performance in general, just how much it would cost! In Arizona performers who use fire in their acts are often required to provide proof of insurance, as well as acquire a permit for every individual event they spin at.


      Other Ways You Can Help

      Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

      • Spread the word on your favorite social networking site
      • Design us a better logo
      • Teach us some of those sweet moves of yours sometime
      • Buy us a beer at Lost leaf. 
      • Tell you friends who's doing that thing that you know a professional fire troupe they could hire
      • Cook us dinner, make it spicy...
      • Chocolate
      • Be our biggest fan
      • Get excited to see us
      • Follow us! www.facebook.com/vatra23

story:
Nikima and Louise are co-choreographers. We moved to New York City in August to continue making work together after graduating from Lewis and Clark College last spring. In the past three months we have shown two distinct works and have recently been given the opportunity to recreate an installation we made in college. This work, Extensory, was created in collaboration with our good friend and admired artist Abigail McNamara. It toes the line between dance, installation and performance art. It is also a collaboration with the “audience”, or anyone who is a part of the space.

This rendition of the installation requires two dancers, an architectural structure, several hooks, and two strips of flesh-colored spandex with sleeves sewn into the ends of each. Previously, the installation took place in a small gallery at Lewis and Clark College as part of Abigail McNamara's installation art class. It came to life in the form of a performance open to the LC community.

Extensory will be reborn in Glasshouse gallery in Brooklyn NY on December 4th. The new site welcomes a larger, wider and more diverse audience, in addition to our friends, colleagues and members of our various communities. We would like this piece to reach its fullest potential, but we cannot afford the fabric we need to do so. We feel that Extensory is a milestone in our budding careers as dance-makers, and we are asking for your support in the creation of this project.

This project is important to us because it's an extension of our lives; it's a way of physically demonstrating the metaphysical fabric of life. We are trying to expose something that happens everyday, it is something that is so obvious that it is regularly overlooked. Our work draws attention to our existence in time and space.The installation is an immersive presentation of phenomenology put into practice.

The spandex is an aesthetic highlight of the relationship between our bodies and the rest of the space, the audience, each other, the walls, the air molecules, and everything around us. Our movements have repercussions that can be observed through the shift and pull of the spandex as it supports our weight, slides, follows us, and turns the gallery into a chamber that echoes our movement.

Spandex costs $8/yard. We need 100 yards. We want the fabric strips to be wider then last time; when the original fabrics were stretched taut they lost their width and became thinner. We would like the installation to have as much fabric as it needs so that we can focus on the play of movement. There are other costs; we would like to give our photographer and videographer an honorarium, costumes are $50 and hooks are $40, then the costs of post-production DVDs, the costs of shipping DVDs and groceries for the dinner we'll cook our $400+ bidders. If we don't reach our final goal then all involved in this project will not be adequately compensated for their dedication and hard work.

Extensory is the beginning of a long journey. Nikima, Abigail, and Louise have been working on it for close to a year and hope to continue elaborating and collaborating on this concept for years to come. Today we need you to get it off the ground.

This project is important to us because it's an extension of our lives; it's a way of physically demonstrating the metaphysical fabric of life. We are trying to expose something that happens everyday, it is something that is so obvious that it is regularly overlooked. Our work draws attention to our existence in time and space.The installation is an immersive presentation of phenomenology put into practice.
The spandex is an aesthetic highlight of the relationship between our bodies and the rest of the space, the audience, each other, the walls, the air molecules, and everything around us. Our movements have repercussions that can be observed through the shift and pull of the spandex as it supports our weight, slides, follows us, and turns the gallery into a chamber that echoes our movement.
Spandex costs $8/yard. We need 100 yards. We want the fabric strips to be wider then last time; when the original fabrics were stretched taut they lost their width and became thinner. We would like the installation to have as much fabric as it needs so that we can focus on the play of movement. There are other costs; we would like to give our photographer and videographer an honorarium, costumes are $50 and hooks are $40, then the costs of post-production DVDs, the costs of shipping DVDs and groceries for the dinner we'll cook our $400+ bidders. If we don't reach our final goal then all involved in this project will not be adequately compensated for their dedication and hard work. 
Extensory is the beginning of a long journey. Nikima, Abigail, and Louise have been working on it for close to a year and hope to continue elaborating and collaborating on this concept for years to come. Today we need you to get it off the ground.

story:
Charlotte-based Triptych Collective is a collaborative, multi-discipline performing arts organization interested in community engagement. We stitch together dance performance, live music, and visual art in captivating, thought-provoking ways and present our creations in unconventional spaces to make our art more widely accessible to the Charlotte and surrounding communities.

We are a project-by-project collection of artists. For our upcoming Fall production, we are four choreographers, four musicians, nine dancers, two visual artists, and a slew of auxiliary contributors.

 

This Fall the Collective presents Sown With the Body: An Evening of Dance and Music Exploring Food and Our Community. 

This evening-length event looks at how we are connecting with the things we consume, with each dance piece exploring a different topic within the scope of food and consumption. We are interested in the shape of our city's farm to fork movement and this event is our visual and kinetic response.


We've partnered with local non-profits Friendship Gardens and Friendship Trays, who put community gardens in urban areas and package the harvests into deliverable trays for shut-ins and homeless families in the area. Through volunteering with these two wonderful organizations, the Collective is gaining creative seeds to inspire SOWN WITH THE BODY. 

 

Well, money, yes. BUT--Firstly, to thank those who have supported us thus far! We've received a matching grant from the Arts and Science Council, which means all of the contributions we hope to receive from friends, families, and fans will be matched dollar for dollar by the Council. How's that for incentive to give?!

 

WHAT GOES INTO PRODUCING AN EVENING LENGTH DANCE AND MUSIC PERFORMANCE YOU ASK?

a LOT.

Basically, our biggest expense is SPACE. 

We are performing in a lovely little gallery space in the heart of NoDa, costing us a whopping $2000 to perform in for two evenings.

Additionally, choreographers are renting space to rehearse in with their dancers for the next three months. 

ALL. ALL. ALL. ALL. ALL of our other expenses will otherwise be coming out of our pockets. Our thin, measley young artist pockets. 

We'd love to have the opportunity to pay our artists for the hours and creative energy they are contributing to this rather large event.

But first, we must cover space expenses. THAT'S EXACTLY WHAT YOUR GENEROUS CONTRIBUTIONS WILL GO TOWARDS.

HERE'S A PEEP AT THAT SPACE: 

YOU (and all your friends, your neighbor, your mother's co-worker's cousin) can help make this evening happen!

LEARN MORE ABOUT THIS CURRENT PROJECT AND SEE PICS OF OUR PAST EVENTS HERE:

www.triptychcollective.com

A FEW CLOSING THOUGHTS:

This project is unique in that we aren't just setting out to make cool art. 

This is a project BY and FOR the community.

We want to bring people together, to the same table even, and have discourse about the way we relate to food.

THE OLDEST HUMAN RITUAL is to gather around a fire, hearth, rock and share the days harvest or hunt, and COMMUNICATE. 

This event will also play host to a variety of local organizations that are doing powerful work, often under the radar, to educate and affect change within our community. We are all collectively entitled to ethical, healthful, sustainable, and affordable FOOOOOOOOOODDDDD!

HEY, IF YOU DON'T HAVE ANY SPARE BONES, THAT'S OK, WE'RE BROKE TOO. WE UNDERSTAND>>>>>> 

YOU CAN MAKE IT UP TO US BY LIKING US ON good ole FB!

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Triptych-Collective/218336528190566

OR

Share our IndieGogo link:

www.indiegogo.com/sownwiththebody

 

THANKS FOR CHECKING US OUT!!!!

 

    Love, Triptych Collective

story:
The Living Room

The Brewing Dept. presents The Living Room by a new play Jenny Vallancourt, directed by Thomas Kapusta

Verna, a new kind of scientist, has learned to endow furniture with the essence of a human being.  But since her discovery, her lover Saul has been feeling… empty.  Tina seeks Verna’s science out in order to finally leave her boyfriend Ikeman – while leaving him with a part of herself, too. When Tina meets Saul, a love triangle emerges… and it isn’t between three people, exactly.  In The Living Room, sometimes it’s easier to love a coffee table than a human being.

The Living Room features Kathryn Maslak as Verna, Brian LaPerche as Saul, Yasmeen Jawhar as Tina, and Yonatan Gebeyehu as Ikeman. It will feature original music by Katie Hathaway, scenic design by Stephen Davan, and lighting design by Camille Simoneau.

The Living Room plays the following schedule as part of the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity:

Saturday 6/8/13 – 4:30pm
Sunday 6/9/13 – 1:30pm
Thursday 6/13/13 – 9:00pm
Wednesday 6/19/13 – 7:00pm
Thursday 6/20/13 – 9:00pm
Saturday 6/22/13 – 4:30pm

Purchase tickets at https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/921750

 

Our Donors, Our Work

The Living Room will be presented as the first production of The Brewing Department's first cycle of projects. And we are inviting you to take part!

In accordance with The Brewing Dept. mission, we are giving our audience members and donors a chance to view and participate in the development process of our works. At every donor level you are given a glimpse into the creation of our work. Whether you are invited to a reading or sent our weekly rehearsal report, you are now actively a part of the creative process of the work you support.

If you wish to sponsor The Living Room and The Brewing Department in a greater capacaty visit our donation page here.

Also, to learn more about our current cycle of shows, visit our website

The Brewing Dept.

The Brewing Dept. (TBD) is a collective of theater artists committed to separating the definition of artistic success from the idea of a final, polished performance. Instead, we encourage a mindset of constant development. We apply the multifaceted vantage point and skills of the collective to the particular goals of the individual artist, aiming to create on a project-by-project basis the unique environment best suited to achieving that artist's goals. We are committed to developing a work in this way before any effort is made to produce it, and we are equally committed to producing work in ways that further its development. At The Brewing Dept., we develop to produce and produce to develop. 

Works of theater require an audience, so we also aim to provide our artists with audiences throughout the creative process. Audiences will be present for the development of a project and, we hope, the production of it. Our goal is to begin conversations between artist and audience at the beginning of a project’s life, and continue it well after that project’s closing performance.

story:
Stage Scene & Song Performing Arts (3sPA) is committed to allowing teens to explore all the creative and practical facets of the theater and performance industry. Here, they can thrive in the discovery and development of their individual talents, build leadership skills, experience the thrill of community achievement, and have the confidence to know that, with respect and collaboration, they can create living theater art from nothing! 

The Summer Youth Theater Collaborative is a thrilling 5-week program that meets 5 days a week, 7 hours a day (9am-4pm), from July 1 through August 4th, 2013. It culminates in a fully realized production of the award-winning musical, Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, by Jeffrey Lane and David Yazbek, at the beautiful Adler Theater at Ramapo College, in New Jersey.

Participants will work with our directors and associates who will mentor them on the different aspects of theater production: set, costume, props, lighting and sound design, performance, directing, and stage management - even producing. We also offer college students who major in the various theater disciplines, as well as professionals in the industry, the opportunity to become mentors and share their knowledge and experience, helping to inspire the next generation of theater writers, performers, designers, and technicians. Each day is made up a combination of rehearsal and production design and development sessions. No group will work in a vacuum - designers will sit in on rehearsals to get a greater understanding of the musical and the roles being developed by the actors, while actors will interact with designers as the physical production grows from preliminary concepts and sketches to a fully staged show.

Campaign Goals

We are a non-profit-pending performing arts company. 3sPA encourages cultural diversity; emphasizes inclusion, respect, and collaboration; and offers top instruction for reduced tuition so that all who want to participate can participate. Your campaign contributions will be used for rehearsal and performance space rentals and production costs that cannot be covered by ticket sales or the modest summer tuition. 

What You Get

All contributors will be acknowledged as sponsors in our program. Check the descriptions on the right to see what each level offers. All contributors will also get the satisfaction of knowing they've helped change a teenager's life this summer.

The Impact

Nothing is more rewarding than witnessing young people explore and pursue their dreams. Without your contributions, funds are limited which could increase tuition costs for future productions. That limits enrollment, which surely limits opportunity.

Stage Scene & Song's founders, Frank Avellino, Argine Safari and Ellyn Essig, have a long history of working with young people who have gone on to successful careers on the stages of New York, Philadelphia and Boston, from regional theaters to Broadway. Their combined talents and dedication provide a perfect playground to inspire individuality and self worth in youngsters while still fostering a mutual respect for peers, a tremendous sense of community and camaraderie, and an appreciation for contribution.

Other Ways You Can Help
  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Who We Are:

This show marks the innagural production of Hard Ticket Theatre; an idea that I have had for some time but lacked the courage to start. Hard Ticket will produce established plays and bring to life new work through the collaborative efforts of some very innovative and creative people. The ultimate goal is to produced plays  from Canadian and international repertoires; to entertain and challenge the West Coast theatrical going community and provide a creative vehicle for local artists, designers, and technicians to participate in creating stories relevant to our place in the world. 

The Play:

Daniel MacIvor's "House" tells the story of Victor, a man in crisis who is eager to confess tales of his sordid history with the hope of achieving a more satisfying future. House blurs the boundaries between actor and audience in an unpredictable ride riddled with black humor and vivid storytelling.

Featuring Mark Bradbury as Victor

Directed by Colin Furlong 

Where and When

LSPU Hall, Victoria Street, St. John's NL

Dec 6th and 7th 8PM
Dec 8th 2pm and 8PM

Tickets are on Sale at The RCA Box Office

What We Need 

For the production of House we would like to raise $1600 This $1600 would go to:

  • General Production Costs- props, costume, set

  • Transportation and Accomodation

 Any amount will be appreciated, no matter how much; we do, however, have perks for certain levels of sponsorship. If you cannot make a monetary donation you can still help us  by spreading the word of our fundraising campaign, and most importantly, come to see the show!!!!!

story:
Polichinelle

Mission

Le Théâtre La Cigogne, situé au Nouveau Brunswick, a pour mission d'appuyer et de promouvoir la relève artistique par la production de textes de création ou de répertoire.

Description

La compagnie du Théâtre La Cigogne à été fondée par 4 finissants du Département d'Art Dramatique de l'Université de Moncton:
  • Isabelle Bartkowiak
  • Ludger Beaulieu
  • Frédéric Melanson
  • Bianca Richard
adresse électronique : TheatreLaCigogne@gmail.com

Le pourquoi

Faire du théâtre n'est pas chose simple, et souvent l'obstacle de l'argent est le premier qui se pose dans le chemin. Le théâtre La Cigogne essaie donc avec cette campagne de ramasser des fonds de base pour commencer à payer notre auteur et les salles. C'est pourquoi n'importe quel don est incrayablement apprécié et certaines récompenses seront remises!

  • 20$ - Votre nom au programme à toutes les représentations de Polichinelle et sur notre page facebook.
  • 40$ - Chaque personne qui donne 40$ ou plus recevra un petit vidéo personnalisé qui dit un gros merci et qui sera publié sur notre facebook et notre youtube.
  • 50$ - Une invitation a une lecture sera donnée aux 20 premières personnes qui donne 50$ ou plus!
  • 70$ - On vous fait un vidéo personnalisé d'environ 2 minutes louant votre bonté, votre générosité, votre magnificence, en disant plein de belles choses a votre sujet que vous pouvez montrez a vos proches quand on vous dit le contraire!
  • 150$ - On vous invite a un souper avec toute la compagnie, vous serez l'invité d'honneur.

Si vous ne pouvez pas donner:

Si vous ne pouvez pas donner, il est quand même possible de nous aider! Progagez le mot! Publiez cette page et notre vidéo sur votre facebook ou votre twitter et parlez-en! Le bouche à oreille est autant important que l'argent pour notre campagne!

story:
Our Story

 I'm Rik Deskin, the Artistic Director of Eclectic Theater Company. I am the Curator of all Theatre, Improv, Stand-Up and Sketch Comedy programming at the Odd Duck Studio, a 49-seat Black-Box theater venue in Seattle, WA that is an artistic home to many theatre artists in the Puget Sound area. We also rent out the theater to itinerant Theatre companies and Improv groups. In July, a theatre company that had planned to rent the theater in August, cancelled and for various reasons, three of our regular Improv groups also cancelled previously scheduled performances. This left us little time to rebook the slots that had been on hold and suddenly without anticipated vital rental and box-office income that was needed to maintain our basic expense of monthly rent. And it put us behind in rent for July.

 The property management company that we pay a monthly rent of $1500 has agreed not to add any more late fees if we can pay this month's rent plus what is still due from last month amounting to $2075.69 by Monday, August 15.


The Impact

It is vital that the Odd Duck Studio remain sustainable as it is a venue utilized by many performers in and around Seattle for shows, rehearsals, classes and more. And it is a regular destination for patrons locally and tourists seeking out unique and interesting entertainment. Currently there are 7 shows playing throughout August that include Zelda, The Comedy Workshop, Brown Bag Comedy, Drop The Root Beer & Run, Closet Monsters Improv, Seattle Monthly Mash-Up and The Big Bully Comedy Show. Every Tuesday night, a Playwrights group called WARP meets to read new plays being developed by local Playwrights. September Skies is a new play by a Seattle Playwright that is currently in rehearsals for a 5 week run that previews September 1. In upcoming months we also offer a number of Free Staged readings of new Plays and Screenplays. We literally have shows playing every week, year-round. We also lease out one of our three studio spaces to Alleged Tattoo, an independent tattoo studio owned by local graphic artist, Lisa Orth. If we are unable to complete this campaign, it may result in being evicted and the loss of a vital space used by and loved by many artists and audience members.


What We Need & What You Get

We need $2075.69 to bring our rent current. All funds are going to rent, pure and simple. We do have 8 performances this weekend that will generate a certain level of revenue towards our goal. If you donate at least $25, you'll receive an ETC Pass that enables you to see any performance produced or co-produced by Eclectic Theater Company at Odd Duck Studio for a whole month: August 12-September 12, 2011. If you give $100, you'll get an ETC Pass plus a pair of Tickets to see September Skies, which runs September 1-October 1, 2011. For $1000 or more you get an ETC Pass, plus a gift certificate that can be used for show tickets or rehearsal space.  plus 1 Performance rental for every $125 you contribute.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word with all of the share tools here at your disposal! You can make a difference!

Currently there are 7 shows playing throughout August that include Zelda, The Comedy Workshop, Brown Bag Comedy, Drop The Root Beer & Run, Closet Monsters Improv, Seattle Monthly Mash-Up and The Big Bully Comedy Show. Every Tuesday night, a Playwrights group called WARP meets to read new plays being developed by local Playwrights. September Skies is a new play by a Seattle Playwright that is currently in rehearsals for a 5 week run that previews September 1. In upcoming months we also offer a number of Free Staged readings of new Plays and Screenplays. We literally have shows playing every week, year-round. We also lease out one of our three studio spaces to Alleged Tattoo, an independent tattoo studio owned by local graphic artist, Lisa Orth. If we are unable to complete this campaign, it may result in being evicted and the loss of a vital space used by and loved by many artists and audience members.


What We Need & What You Get
We need $2075.69 to bring our rent current. All funds are going to rent, pure and simple. We do have 8 performances this weekend that will generate a certain level of revenue towards our goal. If you donate at least $25, you'll receive an ETC Pass that enables you to see any performance produced or co-produced by Eclectic Theater Company at Odd Duck Studio for a whole month: August 12-September 12, 2011. If you give $100, you'll get an ETC Pass plus a pair of Tickets to see September Skies, which runs September 1-October 1, 2011. For $1000 or more you get an ETC Pass, plus a gift certificate that can be used for show tickets or rehearsal space.  plus 1 Performance rental for every $125 you contribute.


Other Ways You Can Help
Please spread the word with all of the share tools here at your disposal! You can make a difference!

story:
Short Summary

What happens when L.A. writers get tired of complaining? The Los Angeles Playwrights Lab is born, co-founded by Robert Gardner and Michael Shaw Fisher. The group’s mission: to produce original works from the writer’s perspective. 

“I listened to countless writers during lunches, walks, jogs, in the middle of movies, at plays complaining about not writing enough,” says L.A. Playwrights Lab co-founder Robert Gardner. “Not really trying to get ‘their’ work in front of the public. Always waiting for ‘someone’ to tell them they will produce it. After years of this, I approached writers and proposed they be their own producers. It took some convincing but here we are and we mean to stay and continue working in Los Angeles.”

The group met every other Sunday for two years, critiquing one another’s work, during which time we created a ‘bank’ of plays. The writing done, each writer became his or her own Producer in the group’s first production:Beginnings. Now we’re on to our second run: 7 Corpses, running Sept 28-Nov 3 at THE COMPLEX in Hollywood. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $3,500, which will go a long way toward helping with our $10,000+ show. Here's what $3,500 gets us:

Tech Week  Rental          340

Stage Manager                850

Lighting Designer             525 

Actors                            1785     

So what do you get in addition to the wonderful feeling of helping live theater happen?  You become a part of the production and our perks range from a thank you on our website to free tickets to executive producer credit!

The Impact

Your donation will have an incredible impact.  Not only will you keep the lights on, you'll be helping talented actors lending their time and talent to a show that asks probing questions.  You'll make good possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps.  Even if you can't contribute money, tell a friend.  We'd love to bring people out and your voice helps!

story:
The Groundlings: Writing Lab!

I've been studying and performing improv and sketch for just about 11 years, almost as long as I've been acting overall. About 2 years ago, I dropped withdrew from Graduate School to fully pursue my acting career. I started classes at The Groundlings immediately after, I commuted from San Diego at least 4 times a week for class and voluntary rehearsals. After passing the first two classes at The Groundlings I was put on a waitlist for a year and a half. I have finally been offered a spot in the Writing Lab Class, which is the 3rd of 4 classes that they offer, prior to Sunday Company. 

I need to raise $650 to pay my tuition for this class, including the fees this site will take. This will fully enable me to focus on the class itself and not the hardship that comes with chasing my own financial tail while the class goes on.

I will appreciate any and ALL help that I recieve to make this happen, including sharing this. 

I know the deadline is imminent, but I think it's possible. Please help me to pursue my dream by studying at one of the most prestigious comedy theaters out there and participating in one of the best communities of performers that I've ever known.

Thank You for reading,

I really look forward to this class!

 

Sincerely,

Michael Minto

story:
We're doing the second episode to a show we premiered two years ago called "You Make Me Physically ILL" about a man involved with his girlfriend's wacky family.

This is a show that we are trying to develop into an ongoing project with new episode coming out on a regular basis. We are using the Hollywood Fringe Festival to stage the second episode, "Love Never Dies".

In this episode, the father of the family, John, writes his own version of Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Love Never Dies" and invests his family's money to stage it. To save money, he casts his daughters Jennifer, Jaclyn, and Sally in the female roles and himself as The Phantom.  The only problem is, he can't find any investors and it is VERY expensive to stage a theatre show. He manages to find a place that will let him do his musical... only it's in a strip club. 

The boyfriend, Will, finds out about this and tries to stop his girlfriend Jennifer from being involved in the show, but she loves her family and will do anything to help them. Will recruits his best friend Eddie to try and stop the show and high jinks ensue.

We are trying to go as low budget as we can on the show but we still have to cover theatre rental space as well as some costumes, props, etc. 

We're looking to raise $2000 to pay for the space.

story:
Short Summary

A small group of Danish performance artists have been accepted into the Midtown International Theatre Festival in Manhattan New york, to perform in July 2013. We will be performing TRAPPED.

  • TRAPPED is a physical abstract portrait of the dehydrated artist through time. Chained to reality and left to die our 5 characters are fighting against the box of Normality, Sexual Frustration, Feminism and Artistic dehydration.
  • The 5 characters of TRAPPED are loosely based on the following artists:       Pablo Picasso & Dora Maar who were involved intimately and Artistically for 9 years. Raoul Hausmann & Hannah Höch, Who were also involved intimately and Artistically. Last but not least Claude Cahun who was a transgender and best known for her self-portrait photographs and poetry.
  • TRAPPED captures the moment in time which every artist experiences at some point in their life. - That exact moment when the Artist must choose to either fight for their ART or SURRENDER into the box that has been created for them by parents, religion, society, government and life. In TRAPPED we go inside the minds of the masters to see what happens when they have to choose - Do they dare to break out of the box of Normality or do they try to fit in?

 

 

As an Artist it is so very important to DARE to get out there - to expose yourself and your ART. With that said - that is the exact reason for The Author of TRAPPED to even seek for a spot in New York City to begin with.

We got that spot- we have been accepted, now we are working hard to make it possible to reach the financial goal. We therefore are asking for your financial support to help us get there - Money is the only thing standing between our dream and reality. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We hope to raise half of the funds needed ($20,863 ) Through our indiegogo campaign. Below you can see our actual budget and the total amount needed to bring TRAPPED to the Midtown International Theatre Festival 2013.

This is what we need to reach our Goal:

Funding:

  • Flight Cost: $14,000  (10 People from Denmark - US)
  • Hotel Cost: $15,000  (10 People standard Hotel)
  • Airport shuttle: $580  (Including tips)
  • Food: $3,000, ($30  per day pr. person.)
  • MetroCard - Subway pass (10 People): $207
  • Group Visa: $1,500
  • Theatre Usage fee (TUF): $2940
  • Production cost: $3,000
  • Promotion material: $1,500  

How much Exactely: $41,727

 

It is funnier to get something in return when you give...

We know that - and our team of creative people has some awesome Perks for you in exchange for your support!

What about getting your picture made into an Artistic mosaic like the TRAPPED poster - Or have your own photoshot with a stylist? - or maybe you are into getting your own piece of Art to be a part of the actual scenography of TRAPPED? - See our Awesome Perks here on the site!

 

 

If we dont reach the final goal, we continue to work for our goal to be fulfilled. We are additionally seeking business sponsors, grants and local funding. We, VAERK9000 are all working locally as a team to raise money for TRAPPED. - You can follow our webpage at www.Vaerk9000.dk to see what we are working with in addition to our fundraising efforts.

 

5. Reasons to support TRAPPED: 

  1. Your helping expose Danish Artists and their ART to the world.
  2. You show that you DARE to support subjects like: Sexual Frustration, Feminism & Art without restrictions.
  3. You mean it when you say that ART is important - and should never be put in a box of NORMALITY.
  4. You dont like the word SURRENDER.
  5. You know what you would do if the fish got sick.

 

For more information on both the Writer/Director: Henriette Rise and the crew behind VAERK9000 please visit our webpage at www.VAERK9000.dk 

For information about the show and the CAST behind TRAPPED, you will find it at: www.TRAPPED9000.com 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

3 ways to help us reach our goal without a financial contribution.

  1. Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  2. Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
  3. Pass on the word to people you know support the arts or maybe have an interest in anything regarding danish/Amarican ART.

We thank you for your time and support.

We thank you for your time and support.

story:
THE SHOW 

In partnership with Mud/Bone Collective, Nettles Artists has created FourLegged Melancholy, an exploration of our melancholic selves - the part of us that lives with the echo of what has been lost. It goes to a place where melancholy is NOT all sadness, but rather a complex state of being, with a full range of emotions.  

 It is the story of two women in different times, in different parts of the world, both searching. One character is ‘La Goulue’, dancer and creator of the French Cancan; an enigmatic and controversial figure who has been inexplicably erased by history.  The other is ‘Saturnina’ a modern woman trying to reconcile the mixed messages of society:  Be independent, but show your man you need him.  Unable to cope, she makes a radical decision to sit in a wheelchair never to get up again. 

Co-produced with Mud/Bone Collective, the piece was developed by Nettles Artists Collective through intense physical and literary research using an original way of working called "Collective Autonomy" where art is stripped of hierarchy and artists work collectively, without a director. The result is a very unique theater event comprised of two 'solo' pieces that circumvent each other.

 

THE COMPANY

Nettles Artists Collective is the only company in New York City led by Latina immigrants doing physical theater.  Artistic directors Debora Balardini and Sandie Luna have been successfully producing original shows and workshops since 2004.  We take special interest in multi-disciplinary work and the cultural diversity of our members.  We premiered FourLegged Melancholy in Brazil last year but it is time to bring it to our artistic home, the place we came to to make our dreams come true! 

  

US + YOU = SUCCESS

Your support would mean making a fusion of voices heard:  Women, Latina, Physical, Risk, Original, Earnest, Global, New York, Creativity.  We cannot do this without you.  Your donation would make this production possible, empowering our community of artists and their diverse voices.  It would also allow us to create strong partnerships with under-served communities.  As part of our mission, we like to bring theater to those who would normally not be exposed to it.  We are also interested in working with women.  To that end, part of our budget has been allocated to provide free tickets to those who cannot afford them and 10% of profits will go to a charity.  (Details below)

 

Our total budget is U$18,000 ... every bit helps. 

Where your money goes:

  • Operating costs Nov 2012 until March 2013  - $300 
  • Printing (Programs, Posters, Postcards): $400 (Dear internet: thank you for your affordability and reach!) 
  • Pay the loveliest motley crew of melancholics ever:

             Claudio Soto Ruiz - Musician, composer of original FourLegged tunes.  $500

             Charlie Jarboe - Lighting Designer & Operator, par excellence.  $500

             Montserrat Hernandez - Technical Director and general assistance.  $500

             Sound Designer/Operator - still seeking...know anyone fabulous? - $500

  • Can can skirts, wheelchair upkeep, wedding dresses and plants that talk (i.e. costumes and props), $250  
  • Administrative costs of linking with civic organizations that will lead to long term partnerships.  In our current business plan we are allocation 10% of proceeds to be donated to the chosen organization. 150 hours of rehearsal X  $15/hr =  $2250 (and a whole lot of physicality!)
  • Provide free admission to those in our community who cannot afford it and who would normally not attend theater.   5 Tickets X 8 Performances X $20 = $800 

 

We are currently hoping to raise 1/3 of our final budget through this campaign.  The remaining $12,000 will be raised independently and will go to theater, insurance, tech crew, actors’ salaries and marketing expenses.   Even if we meet our goal, your donations can further our efforts in making this production a success.  

                                                           ～～～～～～

It is impossible for us to ignore the times we live in as we ask for your support.  We have seen firsthand the impact hurricane Sandy has had in our communities.  We are committed as a company, and as individuals, to volunteer, donate, and be part of the healing process as we transition into a new state of being.  Our work as artists is to capture change and reflect back on it in our work. 

Your monetary donation will have a very direct impact in the production of our show, but there are other ways to help.   If you have any resources, talents or info that may be helpful to us, an emerging and ambitious company, feel free to contact us.  And, if there is any way in which we can help you, let us know.  That is a contribution, too...You are helping us create the kind of community we envision for the world. 

 

 THANK YOU!

 

Please pass this along to your friends and colleagues.
