story:
Hello! we are Shige Moriya and Ximena Garnica. We make creative work ranging from photography, video art, art installations, dance and theater pieces, interdisciplinary collaborations and training projects.

 
 At this time we are about to culminate and officially premiere our piece titled FLOATING POINT WAVES. Rooted in the body, our collaboration work exist at the interconnection of visual, sound, choreographic and dramatic elements. 
 
FLOATING POINT WAVES is scheduled to premier in New York at the OBIE Award-winning downtown theater HERE. We will have 8 performances, from April 6 to April 14. 
 
As we get closer to this much anticipated premier we need YOUR support! 
 
FLOATING POINTS WAVES is fundamentally a performance experience of solo dance, real-time video, live electronic music, water and kinetic sculptures. Floating Point Waves unveils the relationship between the human body and natural elements as movement, water and light connect in an organic causal chain. Every motion of the dance is reflected in the elements that surround it, creating an environment where beauty coexists with darkness.  From a microscopic scale as on the cellular level of the human body, to societal structures and behaviors, to a macroscopic scale such as the laws of physics governing the universe, we are challenged and stimulated toward an awareness of the interconnectedness of life. 
 
FLOATING POINT WAVES is conceived and designed by Ximena Garnica and Shige Moriya and created in collaboration with sound composer Jeremy D. Slater and lighting designer Solomon Weisbard. 
 
Your support will provide the means necessary to partially cover the last intense period of rehearsals and production expenses such as artist’s fees for their time and expertise, acquisition of scenic material, food and transportation fees. 
 
We have prepared great perks for donors, ranging from original screen savers to digital albums to books,  dinners, original art work (a good chance to start your art collection or grow it) and even a custom made installation for your house or garden! Not amount is too small or too large! 
 
Your donation will:
 • Pay the composer-musician and lighting designer (Jeremy Slater and Solomon Weisbard for the long hours of rehearsal!)
 • Feed them when they start to fade out after our 8 hours long rehearsals 
 • Pay our collaborator’s train tickets so that we might all be in the same place for said rehearsals 
 • Pay for the materials use in the construction of the sculptures and pool installation 
 • Allow us to document the performances (still photography and video) so that Floating Point Waves can have a life beyond these performances. And if we are lucky enough to overshoot our goal, your donation will: 
 • Pay for the production cost of the Floating Point Waves process book which will include a CD and DVD of the material generated during the making of the show. 
 
 Thank you so for your interest and support. We could not make this happen without you! 



Do you want to donate but can't do it online?
No problem! You can always send us a check and you will still receive the perks. All checks should be made to CAVE Organization, Inc. Please write in the memo: Floating Point Waves donation. If you find the way to donate online it will be great... It is so fun to see how the donation number grows! Thank you so much!
 
 Links:
 www.HERE.org
www.leimay.org
www.cavearts.org
story_txt:
Hello! we are Shige Moriya and Ximena Garnica. We make creative work ranging from photography, video art, art installations, dance and theater pieces, interdisciplinary collaborations and training projects.
 
 At this time we are about to culminate and officially premiere our piece titled FLOATING POINT WAVES. Rooted in the body, our collaboration work exist at the interconnection of visual, sound, choreographic and dramatic elements. 
 

FLOATING POINT WAVES is scheduled to premier in New York at the OBIE Award-winning downtown theater HERE. We will have 8 performances, from April 6 to April 14. 
 
As we get closer to this much anticipated premier we need YOUR support! 
 

FLOATING POINTS WAVES is fundamentally a performance experience of solo dance, real-time video, live electronic music, water and kinetic sculptures. Floating Point Waves unveils the relationship between the human body and natural elements as movement, water and light connect in an organic causal chain. Every motion of the dance is reflected in the elements that surround it, creating an environment where beauty coexists with darkness.  From a microscopic scale as on the cellular level of the human body, to societal structures and behaviors, to a macroscopic scale such as the laws of physics governing the universe, we are challenged and stimulated toward an awareness of the interconnectedness of life. 
 

FLOATING POINT WAVES is conceived and designed by Ximena Garnica and Shige Moriya and created in collaboration with sound composer Jeremy D. Slater and lighting designer Solomon Weisbard. 
 
Your support will provide the means necessary to partially cover the last intense period of rehearsals and production expenses such as artist’s fees for their time and expertise, acquisition of scenic material, food and transportation fees. 
 
We have prepared great perks for donors, ranging from original screen savers to digital albums to books,  dinners, original art work (a good chance to start your art collection or grow it) and even a custom made installation for your house or garden! Not amount is too small or too large! 
 
Your donation will:
 • Pay the composer-musician and lighting designer (Jeremy Slater and Solomon Weisbard for the long hours of rehearsal!)
 • Feed them when they start to fade out after our 8 hours long rehearsals 
 • Pay our collaborator’s train tickets so that we might all be in the same place for said rehearsals 
 • Pay for the materials use in the construction of the sculptures and pool installation 
 • Allow us to document the performances (still photography and video) so that Floating Point Waves can have a life beyond these performances. And if we are lucky enough to overshoot our goal, your donation will: 
 • Pay for the production cost of the Floating Point Waves process book which will include a CD and DVD of the material generated during the making of the show. 
 
 Thank you so for your interest and support. We could not make this happen without you! 




Do you want to donate but can't do it online?No problem! You can always send us a check and you will still receive the perks. All checks should be made to CAVE Organization, Inc. Please write in the memo: Floating Point Waves donation. If you find the way to donate online it will be great... It is so fun to see how the donation number grows! Thank you so much!

 
 Links: www.HERE.org www.leimay.orgwww.cavearts.org

story:
WE ARE THE UMBRELLA COLLECTIVE:

Monica Dionysiou and Marc Devine

The Umbrella Collective strives to challenge the conventional identity of theater, dance, and visual art; raising the question, “What is possible? With Dance the Orange, we wish to push the boundaries of what performance can be. 

We train together, make art together and perform together in Denver and Boulder, CO. In past lives we lived and worked in the experimental theatre scenes in in Los Angeles (Marc Devine) and in Chicago (Monica Dionysiou.) 

 

What is Dance the Orange?

1 part theatre, 1 part dance, 1 part opera & 1 part installation: performative event. A multimedia extravaganza featuring video projections, installed sculpture and the simple magic of bodies moving in space. 

The inspiring story: On a quest to find his lost love, Orpheus befriends the Child-Queen Persephone as they journey through the three hellish realms of the Underworld.

Your contributions are essential to this piece! You are helping us bring to this exhilarating event to life and in doing so, we aim to bridge the gap between art worlds.

 

DANCE THE ORANGE -  Created by the Umbrella Collective

Produced in association with Control Group Productions and Naropa University.

January 10-13 2013 - Work|Space Denver 

 

How does this work?

If you're not familiar with IndieGogo or crowdfunding in general, here's a brief overview. 

Until December 31, 2012, you'll be able to make pledges to help support this project, ranging from $5 to whatever you can afford without loosing your home. You can select one of the perks on the right, that fits within your budget and you’ll get a piece of the piece sent right to your inbox!  

Keep reading for more information on our exciting project and your exciting perks! 

 

 What We Need & What You Get

Dance the Orange is The Umbrella Collective's most ambitious project to date. Our high production value is, of course, accompanied by high production cost. 60% of your contributions will help us fund our general production costs, including but not limited to rehearsal space rental, set material and artist stipends. 

The other 40% is will help us to spread the word!  We are marketing to a city where we have a small audience base and we need all the help we can get to get the word out about The Umbrella Collective and Dance the Orange. Your contributions will help us to design and purchase visually exciting marketing materials and contract marketing specialists who will spread the word about our work to the Denver Metro area.

Your philanthropy will not go un-noticed! Nor un-rewarded! 

We understand that many of you are not local to the Denver area and may not have an opportunity to see the fruits of our labor. This made us sad, so we decided that with any contribution to Dance the Orange, we will send piece of the piece to you via: World Wide Web. 

 

Choose from the many levels of giving:

 

Under-Dweller - $10-25 

A $10-25 contribution will help us to bring life to the Under-Dwellers, those who dwell in the 1st realm of the Underworld.

***Under-Dwellers are rewarded with:

- A collection of production stills

- And a Big Ol' THANK YOU from the Umbrella Collective

 

Spirit - $26-50

Spirits who inhabit the 2nd realm of the Underworld will be so grateful for your $26-50 contribution that they will give you a big, wet kiss! Virtually, of course. 

***Spirits receive:

- A virtual kiss from the Under-Dwellers and Spirits of the Underworld

- A collection of production stills

- And a Big Ol' THANK YOU from the Umbrella Collective

 

Hero - $51-100

Contribute $51-100 to reserve your spot with the other Heroes in the 3rd realm of the Underworld.

 *** The perks of being a Hero are great:

 - 1 ticket to a performance of DANCE THE ORANGE

 - An inscribed commemorative digital poster with a special, personalized message.

 - A virtual kiss from the Under-Dwellers and Spirits of the Underworld

 - A collection of production stills

 - And a Big Ol' THANK YOU from the Umbrella Collective

 

Gods - $101-500+

Trying to avoid residency in the Underworld all together?  Become an immortal God with a contribution of $100-500.

 ***Gods receive the most exciting gifts of all:

 - A Producer credit (500+)

 - A personalized thank you video featuring the main characters of Dance the Orange

 - 2 tickets to a performance

 - An inscribed commemorative digital poster with a special, personalized message.

 - A virtual kiss from the Under-Dwellers and Spirits of the Underworld

 - A collection of production stills

 - And a Big Ol' THANK YOU from the Umbrella Collective

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? That’s okay, we still love you!  

You can still help us! SPREAD THE WORD!! Share our Indiegogo campaign on your Facebook, twitter and list serves. 

If you are local we are looking for helping hands and work trades. Send us a message if you are interested/willing to contribute your time and labor to Dance the Orange. 

Of course we encourage you to come by Work|Space Denver on January 10-13 @ 8:00 to witness and participate in this exciting event.

story:
For the Lulz by Ben Ferber

The blogosphere watches in horror as a hacktivist, a phreaker, and a cyberterrorist wage war on each other for money, for revenge, and for the lulz. A true-to-life net-noir that asks: Can a hashtag change your life? #forthelulz @ForTheLulzShow
 
This new play by Ben Ferber is an unapologetic look at internet culture with all its flaws and glory, blurring the lines between our web-ready public and our private lives. The play focuses on the intersections of four netizens: Fay, a technology and culture blogger; poof, a cyber terrorist; MrJ, a grey hat hacktivist; and Gale, an ex-con college professor. After a major hacking spree that cripples most social media websites, Fay seeks to uncover the identity of the internet criminal know as "poof." But as poof reminds us, "Those who dig deep get buried."
 
People today are comfortable on the internet. When the internet first became a household possibility, people were concerned about contracting viruses, and kept their personal information close and private. Today, people tell 500 of their Facebook friends the exact location of the Starbucks where they just got their coffee. For the Lulz tears away our security blanket and shows us just how fragile our idea of privacy on the internet truly is. What makes For the Lulz truly terrifying is just how much is taken from true stories and actual headlines--this play is not a morality tale or horror story. This is real life. This is the internet.
 
And yet here we are, asking for money, over the internet. #lulz #oops?
 
Horn&Ivory Productions' For the Lulz by Ben Ferber will premiere in the inaugural season of Portland Stage Studio Rep this February. Studio Rep is an excellent opportunity for a young company like ourselves to showcase new and interesting work.

Horn&Ivory Productions

Horn&Ivory Productions is focused on producing new work and recontextualized classics. We seek not to entertain or cajole, but to push the limits of theatrical mode and storytelling. 
 
Todd Brian Backus, Shannon Stockwell, and Ella Wrenn came together after spending a year at Portland Stage participating in their internship program from 2011 to 2012. When they all found themselves remaining in the Portland area after their internships concluded, they decided to continue exploring their love of theatre through creating their own company. Horn&Ivory focuses on producing new work and recontextualized classics, especially concentrating on the unrealistic and fantastical.
 
Horn&Ivory is thrilled that 'For the Lulz' is their first production, and is extremely excited to be exploring the strange potential that the realm of the intangible internet provides.

Meet the Team

Caroline O'Connor - Gale
Shannon Stockwell - poof
Eric Worthley - MrJ
Ella Wrenn - Fay

Todd Brian Backus - Director
Ben Ferber - Playwright
Emily Kenny - Lighting Designer
Adam Matta - Props Artisan
Sam Rapaport - Sound Designer
Donald Smith - Scenic Designer
Shannon Stockwell - Dramaturg
Chelsea Wischerth - Stage Manager

How You Can Help

Your contributions will go directly toward aiding our limited budget. With your help, we will be able to afford:

  • more sophisticated costumes
  • paint and supplies for our set
  • stipends for our cast and crew
  • aid for our playwright, Ben Ferber's, launch For the Lulz past this initial production
  • specialized prop laptops that will be created for the purposes of this show
  • advertising through posters and ad space

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute right now, but still want to help? Here are some things you can do:

  • Help us spread the word! Tweet @ForTheLulzShow, or join the event on Facebook!
  • Come to the show! We like having butts in seats, and full houses are great!

story:
The short of it:

We are VILLAINS - a group of young theatre artists dedicated to examining our culture by staging old stories in new contexts.  Our next project is OCEAN KINGDOM - the story of Shakespeare's Pericles getting lost in other stories - an immersive and visceral audience experience.  The show will go up this March - but only with your help.

We need to raise $5000 to cover our production costs and performance space rental - or else OCEAN KINGDOM might not become a reality.  So we're turning to you, our strongest supporters, so ask for contributions.  In return, we are offering some awesome perks, including free tickets and drink vouchers.  With your help, we can create a thought-provoking show and jump-start a unique and sustainable performance company.

Check out our page below for more details!  Thank you for your support.

The long of it:

WHAT IS VILLAINS PERFORMANCE?

VILLAINS is a group of young theatre artists under the artistic direction of Douglas Eacho in Brooklyn, New York.  Our mission is to examine the world we live in through the lens of misplaced stories.  We steal old plays, yank them out of their traditional contexts, and turn them into spectacular, unsettling experiences that make us think about our culture - and how it could be better. We are committed to making sustainable theatre by building a repertory of work, using and re-using found objects, texts and spaces.

We invite you to read more about us on our website.

 

WHAT IS OCEAN KINGDOM?

OCEAN KINGDOM is a theatrical mash-up.  Imagine a Girl Talk CD, made from popular plays instead of popular songs, and one man living through them who would very much like it all to stop.  That man is Pericles, from that Shakespeare shipwreck play that nobody's read.  The culture he drowns in is our own.  Can he escape to another world? 

Featuring cheerleaders, a live DJ, multiple stages, plenty of beer, and glo-tape. Dress for a rave, watch out for the Splash Zone, and don't let one man's anguish spoil your fun.

Ocean Kingdom will run March 21-30, 2013 at Magic FutureBox, a beautiful warehouse theatre in Sunset Park, and the perfect creative home for OCEAN KINGDOM.

 

WHERE'S THE MONEY GOING?

Your donation will help us create sustainable, economical theatre by purchasing:

The most affordable perfomance space money can buy.

  • Magic FutureBox is bigger and more flexible than any space in Manhattan - at one quarter of the cost.

An effective and minimal production design.

  • The majority of our set, lights, costumes and props will be found objects - from Magic FutureBox, our closets and props warehouses.
  • We will still need to purchase some items - some wood to build a few platforms, some material for costumes, and, of course, glo-tape.  But, our minimalistic production aesthetic means we won't be purchasing much, so we can keep costs down.
  • What we do use, we will re-use: Your donation will fund several future productions, rather than just this one.

Small stipends for our artists.

  • Artists are the most sustainable aspect of theatre.  Rather than paying for an elaborate set that will be torn down and thrown away, we will pay our artists so they can come back and make more meaningful art that you want to see.

Your donation will also help us keep ticket prices down to $15, so that our work will be affordable and accessible.

We would be happy to provide you with a detailed breakdown of our budget.  Please e-mail us at villainsperformance@gmail.com.

 

WHY VILLAINS?

We've done this before - we can do it again.

  • Last time, it was cutting Hamlet down to an hour and performing it for one audience member at a time.  Stand and Unfold Yourself, which premiered at Brown University in 2011, was innovative, gripping, and highly praised by the community.  We are ready to take it to the next level with OCEAN KINGDOM.
  • Be sure to check out our previous work on our website!

Your donation goes beyond OCEAN KINGDOM.

  • Your donation will help us get VILLAINS off the ground, jump-starting a unique company with a sustainable model.

We can't do it without you.

  • This is a fixed funding campaign.  We must raise $5000 by March 4 at midnight, or else we get nothing.  This means we would have to scale down even more, raise our ticket prices and pray that we make up what we spent in the box office - which, as recent college graduates, is an investment none of us can afford to make.

We need YOUR help to fully realize OCEAN KINGDOM, and to get VILLAINS up and running.  We appreciate your support, and we want thank you - Check out our perks on the right!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Please share this page with your friends using the links above!

  • One of the most helpful things you can do is write your friends a personal e-mail about why they should support our project.
  • Or, share us on facebook!

Want to volunteer?  We need house managers and people to help us build!  E-mail us at villainsperformance@gmail.com.

We want to hear from you!  Questions?  Thoughts?  Ideas?  E-mail us at villainsperformance@gmail.com!

 

Thank you for your support.

--VILLAINS

 

 **NEW!**

Please welcome to the cast of OCEAN KINGDOM:

Dennis Kozee, Pericles
Anna Smeragliuolo, Marina
Jamie Bock
Ted Cava*
Gabe Gonzales
Ellie Shepley
Virginia Logan
Frank Paiva
Emma Thorne
Chris Tyler


Doug Eacho, Director/Artistic Director of VILLAINS Performance
Ellen Shadburn, PM/Executive Director of VILLAINS Performance
Leandro Zaneti, Line Producer
Meredith Mosbacher, Movement Coordinator
Danielle Baskin, Set Design
David Sexton, Light Design
Mike Irish, DJ/Sound Design
Suzan Eraslan, Costume Design

*These actors are appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

Equity Approved Showcase

 

Video directed and edited by Ted Cava, featuring Ted Cava, Douglas Eacho, Meredith Mosbacher and Ellen Shaburn.

 **NEW!**
Please welcome to the cast of OCEAN KINGDOM:
Dennis Kozee, Pericles Anna Smeragliuolo, Marina Jamie Bock Ted Cava* Gabe Gonzales Ellie Shepley Virginia Logan Frank Paiva Emma Thorne Chris Tyler
 Doug Eacho, Director/Artistic Director of VILLAINS Performance Ellen Shadburn, PM/Executive Director of VILLAINS Performance Leandro Zaneti, Line Producer Meredith Mosbacher, Movement Coordinator Danielle Baskin, Set Design David Sexton, Light Design Mike Irish, DJ/Sound Design Suzan Eraslan, Costume Design *These actors are appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association Equity Approved Showcase
 
Video directed and edited by Ted Cava, featuring Ted Cava, Douglas Eacho, Meredith Mosbacher and Ellen Shaburn.

story:
Short Summary

My name is John "Baton" Mitchell; I am a former National and World Champion baton twirler and currently a National Twirling Judge. Due to my mother's breast
cancer diagnoses three years ago, I along with a close friend went into
action to create a movement that would erase cancer. TWIRLING for the CURE
is that movement. Bottom line, WE NEED YOU please help us make a difference!

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need - $5,000 for the Production Crew and
         distribution of the PSA to go national.
  • The unique perks for you are: 1) Saving a life 2)
         Giving Hope 3) Providing endless support 
  • If we do not reach our goal, the PSA will not be able
         to: 1) Reach as many people nationally. 2) Provide the hope needed to
         survive (specifically the Grandmothers, Mothers, Sisters, Wives,
         Friends and Families going through the disease. 3) Assist in the
         effort to inform the public with new and unique performance visional
         regarding breast cancer awareness.

 

The Impact

Your contribution will establish make goal to be a national movement a reality. 

  • In the past three years, $5,500 was donated to the
         Susan G. Komen Foundation
  • Since the start of the Twirling for the Cure Campaign,
         at least 10 women have been diagnosed with breast cancer but your support
         can help us support those specific families in a 1:1 basis
  • Your support will create a ripple effect that will
         establish outcomes that are both financial and personal resulting in more
         corporate and individual gifting supporters.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Please get the word out by passing the Twirling for the
         Cure movement to friends via Facebook, Tweeter, Instagram, LinkedIn
         and any other social media networks.

  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

  • Tell a friend about how to help save a life by becoming
         part of the conversation.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
In 2008, I was contacted by the administration at Saint Paul's School in Harlem. They asked me and a few of my colleagues within the professional theatre industry, if we would do them the huge favor of starting a small after school theater program. It had never been attempted in this specific institution before, but they said the kids were expressing a real interest. Feeling intrigued and moved by the fact that these kids had little to no opportunity to express themselves creatively through theater, we accepted-- asking nothing in return.

The program started on a rainy Thursday afternoon. A few shy kids and a handful of concerned parents approached the small stage built into the corner of the gym. What was this new "theater thing?" We demonstrated a some theatrical games, and the kids began interacting with each other. Soon their shy expressions turned into laughter and joy, and the parents stopped being concerned and started participating.

A few weeks later the program was up and running. We staged a few Christmas songs and poems at the school's Annual Christmas Party, and. the show was a great success! We immediately began developing the curriculum for the following season, and after that, the program grew and grew--but so did our needs.

Today, almost five years later, the number of kids participating in the program has tripled and more are arriving. However, the school continues to experience deep financial trouble and has no additional resources to provide things as simple as costumes or props, or supply the demand for needed teachers. Securing teachers has proved to be especially difficult in today's economy, and it has become increasingly challenging to find teachers who can give of their time for free.  

Recently we touched base with a group of exceptional artists and educators who are more then willing to help us fully realize a theater program at St. Paul's, but we still need financial resources. We have found willing designers to help provide performances with set design, costumes, and music. Also, since our performances suffering acoustically from the placement of the theater in the school gym (with its large crowds of parents, relatives, and school teachers), we have located a sound technician who will manage and provide speakers and microphones. 

We're ready!!! But the kids need your help!! Your support will give the kids at St. Paul's the program they deserve with properly staged shows and enough teachers to accept anyone who wants to participate, have fun, and be creative. So far, this little program that started on a rainy Thursday afternoon has helped kids create friendships, fight bullies, work as a team, and rediscover the simple joy of a round of Hide and Seek in the times of tablets and smartphones. 

Please take a moment to watch our video….the kids are definitely more convincing that we’ll ever be!

Will you help us make their dreams come true?? No amount is too small.

Thank you….from the bottom of our hearts!

Sincerely,

Francesco Campari

Artistic director

What your donations will provide:

- Pay the teachers and educators for a longer period of time

- Pay a sound technician

- Rent speakers & microphones 

- Pay a set designer for the materials they need

- Find appropriate costumes

- Relieve the parents from paying this out of their own pockets

- Stage more then one show a year

- a full scholarship for the most meritable student to take part in the TRES ARTIS NEXT GENERATION kids theater program (www.tresartis.com)

story:
My name is Rebekah Brown and I recently graduated with my MFA in Dance from Mills College in Oakland, CA. I have been selected to present a piece for the Mills Dance Alumni Show, Ebb + Flow, on February 7, 2014. I am working with fellow dancers Sarah Shouse, Sophie Stanley, and Shannon Stubblefield on a piece entitled Boots. The video above is just a little taste of what we are working on!


As alumni, we are all trying to succeed in the dance world. Being able to present work here is wonderful! But there is no funding from outside sources, which is why I am asking YOU! If you choose to contribute, you will not only be helping fund this specific piece, but you will also be encouraging and enabling the great dancers of the future.


My goal for this campaign is $600. That money will go towards: paying the dancers for their time and energy, costumes, props, and renting studio space. Everyone who contributes $25 or more will receive a free DVD of the piece. If you contribute $100, you will receive a free ticket to the show! $150 and you receive two tickets! Contribute $250 and you will receive a special pair of boots PLUS two tickets to the show!


Even if we don't reach our goal, we will still receive the portion of money we do raise. However, that's not going to happen, right? SO LET'S RAISE SOME MONEY!


Contributing to the making of this piece is not a one-time gift. This piece is only the beginning of a series of dancin' boots! Your contribution can only increase the longevity of our performances. 


I know it's right after the holidays. But if you can't contribute right now, that's ok! There's still ways to help. Help us spread the word about our campaign and about the upcoming show on February 7! You can even use the Indiegogo share tools for easy-peasy sharing. 


THANKS FOR YOUR HELP!

story:
The Vision

When I travel the world my goal is to spread joy through movement and circus arts.

Ever since I embarked on my first world tour in 2007, I've been inspired to bring flow and circus equipment to kids in need. Last year I visited schools in Bali and this last Christmas I delivered toys to orphanages. This year Im going to study in India and bring toys to gift to children in need. 

My vision is to bring flow and circus arts to kids around the world. 

I hope to improve the lives of others while working on my own personal growth. 

With your help, I will bring the dream of creative physical expression to children on the streets, schools, and orphanages of India while traveling from Goa to Rishikesh studying Yoga and meditation.

Your contribution creates children's laughter. 

You support kids shifting their bodies through space as they learn to express themselves through movement with toys such as Hulu-hoops, poi, juggling equipment and other circus props. Your funds teach children how to interact with the world through joyous physicality, dance, and circus arts. 

Together we create something greater than I could alone!

Where I am going? 

February 14 - I will arrive Goa, spending 10 days working with children from orphanages to the streets. I am meeting 4 other circus artists in Mumbai (who happen to be in India at the same time) and a videographer Joseph Trivigno who is the founder of The Musical Circus and creator of a documentary called Stuck in Katmandu/A Journey to the Valley of Flowers, that was filmed at the same orphanage we are visiting. 

We will bring toys to the Nag Orphanage.

February 24  - We will fly to Nepal and work with the Nag Orphanage, who hosts over 500 kids. We will also work with the local government school. We will spend a few days playing, performing for the children, and delivering tons of circus equipment, all while documenting the experience and the joy it brings to the children. 

Feb 28 - I fly to Rishikesh and participate in an International Yoga Convention followed by a yoga teacher training at the Sattva center outside of  Rishikesh. The owner of the program also works with local school groups in the area, allowing me to continue my work with the children. 

About the Film

Sometimes in life we are blessed enough to leave our comfort zone and adventure into the unknown; in the film "Stuck in Kathmandu" a young american traveler (Briana Kai) sets out on a journey to bring her grandfather's ashes to the magical Valley of Flowers in India. Along the way she gets stranded in Kathmandu, Nepal. The hault in her journey allows her to deepen the exploration of Nepalese culture, and find hidden treasures of truth with in her own being reflected the beauty of the people, the land, and the ancient wisdom of Nepal's most sacred sites.
One of the most profound moments in the film, is the time spent with the NAG school, and the incredible spirits of the Nepali children. The NAG, Nawa Asha Griha, Home of New Hopes, is a home for street children, where kids from the poorest conditions can find a home, a nourishing meal, an education, and a chance at a brighter future. Founded twenty years ago by Nicole Thakuri-Wick, starting with six kids in her living room, now accomodating and supporting over 500 children.
It is truly a blessing and an inspiration, to see the bright spirits of these once downtrodden children. The smiles, the laughter, the love and the sense of family is what is remembered most after spending time at the NAG school, and just as the sun rises each day, there is a chance to create each and everyone of our lives and rise up to our fullest embodiment of who we are. For the children of Nepal, NAG is like the sun, shining light into the dark, bringing new life, nourishing, and inspiring them to grow into their unlimited, highest potential.



What will the donations be used for?

Your contribution will help fund this trip.

The donations will allow me to bring a larger number of toys to India, allow me to visit more orphanages, off set travel costs, baggage fees, daily expenses, and make it possible for me to dedicate more time in India to work for the betterment of children. 

What do you get in return?

Besides the satisfaction of knowing underprivileged children will be getting your gift of flow, you'll also receive some wonderful gifts of your own!

~ For donations of $50, you'll receive a hand written thank you post card from India!

~ For donations of $100, you'll receive a group aerial stretch and strength class for you and two of your friends.

~ For donations of $200 you'll receive three private  flow classes of your choice, either poi, hoop, staff or double staff!  (plus you can bring a friend or two, if you want)

~ For donations of $300 you'll receive three private aerial classes of your choice, on either silks or lyra!  (you can also bring a friend or two, if you want)

The Impact

Children are the future.

What they learn now turns into the building blocks of how they will treat themselves and others when they grow up. Children who have physical outlets, toys that allow them to develop a conscious connection to their bodies, are children that will be ready to tackle the problems of the future.

This isn't the first project I've spearheaded to bring laughter to kids.

This one is the next step.

This is bigger.

Please help me make a larger impact on my quest to bring light and laughter to at risk kids around the world.

Other ways you can help!

If you can't donate money, time helping me craft the equipment, or already made props or toys!

Spread the word to your friends, collect child sized Hulu-hoops, or pass around a donation box for old flow toys.

Every little bit helps and I appreciate you supporting me in this vision.

story:
Iona's Story

My daughter,  Iona Makota, is a 13 year old 8th grader in Houston, Texas.  She started dancing at around 3yrs old in the aisles at my performances.  lol.  She was literally stealing the show at 3!  Dance has always been be her lifelong dream and now she has the opportunity to study at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater the summer of 2015. Currently attending The Movement Lab,  under the direction of Kevin Ferguson, Iona has a rigid schedule of Ballet, Modern, Jazz, Improv, Dunham, and Pointe classes. As a little girl she's studied West African, South African, Brazillian and took Hip Hop classes. A few of her teachers have been Alseny Soumah, Dandha da Hora, Mabiba Baegne, Dimakatso Hampton, Lauren Anderson, Youssouff Koubassa, Michael Paul Appleman, Mouminatou Camara, Lori Amare and Jennifer Sommers. Dance is very close to her heart, and she hopes to make it her profession. 
Outside of dance, Iona spends her time dancing.  Yes, dancing.  She also enjoys reading, drumming, roller skating, watching movies, and listening to music. She's taken flute, violin, marimba and piano lessons, and hopes to have music accompany her along the way to becoming a better artist.

The Goal

Ultimately, Iona would love to dance with a professional company.  In addition, her future desire is to open a dance studio for underprivileged children. Believing that dance is the manifestation of the soul. And everyone should have the opportunity to express themselves! 

The tuition for the 6-week Alvin Ailey program is $2675, and the Ailey School estimates additional costs of $ 4916 for housing, meals and other living expenses, for a total of $7366. With transportation to New York, required dance clothes and related costs, we expect the total cost to be $8,000. We are able to pay a portion of these costs, and Iona Makota is contributing money from her winter dance job this year, but we still need to raise $4800. Our goal is $5000 ($5000 - 4% fee to Indiegogo = $4800)

We are doing all we can, including approaching local businesses for donations and selling wares at the S.H.A.P.E Community Center's HARAMBEE MARKET (1st Saturday of every month).

Each donation, regardless of the amount,  gets us closer to our goal!   So, please give according to your ability. We appreciate each and every gift. AND, don't forget to check out the perks Iona is offering!

If we do not reach our goal completely, the money will still be used toward Iona attending Ailey, we just really wanted to avoid selling our car.

If we exceed our goal, we will donate any funds over the goal to SHAPE Community Center, a non-profit organization offering Self Help for All People Everywhere. SHAPE offers a safe haven and high quality arts programming for children in Third Ward Houston, and ensures that no child is turned away due to financial constraints. So, please give generously!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone is not able to donate,  but EVERYONE can help Iona by making some major noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo “share” tools. Spread the word to all of your friends and family -- anyone who may want help a talented, young hardworking dancer achieve her dream!  Thank you!

And that's all there is to it.

family -- anyone who may want help a talented, young hardworking dancer achieve
her dream!  Thank you!And that's all there is to it.

story:
Adrienne and I are current Tisch students, co-directing a production of Dog Sees God. After meeting in a directing class over the summer, we decided to team up and put on a show together. We chose Dog Sees God because it deals with the most important challenge young adults face: finding an identity. Whether we search for ourselves in the people we hang out with, the clothing we wear, or the parties we go to, we all eventually come to a sense of self and realize that who we are isn't defined by the events of our past. Throughout the play, we follow these characters on their journeys toward their own identities, watching their ups and downs, wins and losses. A modern take on the children's Peanuts cartoons, our show brings Bert V. Royal's 90s drama into the present day, exploring themes from first love to teen suicide.

CAST

CB: Felix Jones
CB's Sister: Julia Lennon
Van: Omri Kadim
Matt: Justin Arnold
Beethoven: John Pope
Marcy: Margaret McMeans
Tricia: Elizabeth Cappuccino
Van's Sister: Samantha Bilinkas

We need $1000 to cover fees for rights, to rent space, and to pay for props and costumes. Any amount is greatly appreciated, and please spread the word!

story:
I've always dreamed of putting on my own cabaret show and now it's finally happening! But as a poor starving artist in New York City, there is a lot I need to pay for to make this possible.  I'm looking for a little support from my friends and family to help make this show a reality.

"Dating in the city is tough. And with Valentine's Day fast approaching, this single twenty something finds dating even tougher! Join Katie Bland for a fun celebration of love (or lack thereof)--Single Straight Males get half off the cover charge!"

The show will be about my romantic experiences as a naive idealist living in New York City.  Full of funny stories, some heartbreaking ones, and a happy ending or two.  Songs will include some of my favorites from Joni Mitchell, Carner and Gregor, and even Rogers and Hammerstein.

Katie Bland: They're In Love, Where Am I?  will perform Monday February 11th, 2013 at 7:00 PM at the Duplex Cabaret Theatre.  It's gauranteed to be a night of laughter and a few sentimental tears, and maybe a few phone numbers at the end of the night!

Funding will go towards paying the accompanist, my show's director, promotional materials, and the videographer.  And it's YOU who can make this posisble.

story:
The Play

Conscious Inertia is a new play by Brett Evan Solomon that explores the many ways that faith can be lost and found. A new variation on the biblical flood, it takes place in a dark and dreary city where it seems that the world is coming to an end. The city's inhabitants try to figure out what to do when they're standing at what could be the end of the world. And even if they figure it out, how will they keep going?

Cast:

Jared- Christopher Smith
Lamech- Jonathan Daniel Schenk
Noah- Chandon Sethi
Adair- Caitlin Kenyon
Mary- Meghan Ray

Crew:

Playwright- Brett Evan Solomon
Director- James McDermott
Assistant Director- Sebastian Leroy Pray
Producer- Caitlin Kenyon
Stage Manager- Rebecca Rein
Assistant Stage Manager- Jennifer Matelski

Dramaturge- Andrew Jones

Set Designer- Brittany Balfour
Lighting Designer- Ash Zeitler
Lighting Team- Nick Sciretta, Kevin Downing
Sound Designer- Kevin Downing

Props Master- Carson Polan-Volpe
Costume Designer- Jessica DeMartino 

Costuming Team- Iliana Paris, Marissa Martin
Choreographer- Arden Winant
Make-Up Artist- Beth Phelan
Front of House- Laurie King
Posters- Lynne Barcenas

Tell Me More...

Hello and welcome! My name is Caitlin Kenyon and I am both the Producer and playing the role of Adair in Gratify Theatre Works production of Conscious Inertia. I am currently a Junior at Purchase College double majoring in Theater and Performance and Arts Management. But enough about me, let’s get to the important people here.

Gratify Theatre Works is a collective of theatre makers who began their journey at Purchase College. We are a group of artists who took a look at the opportunities for young adults with theatre degrees and concluded that our best chance of moving forward was to pave our own path. While Gratify is still young, since our starting point of only 6 members we can now proudly boast 20 members and are continuing to see growth and opportunity arise every day. While gratify has hosted 4 play readings since its establishment, Conscious Inertia well be our first official production. We are looking to roll in with a bang and with the assistance of a strong cast, incredible playwright, fantastic director, and an extensive and powerful artistic team it seems there is only one thing missing: the funds to make this show a reality. 

What We Need

When it comes to relaying where the money you are donating is going I thought it would be easiest to create a pie chart of how the $2,000 would be divided if we reach our goal:

When it comes to most of our projects categories, the budget is relatively small.

  • 4% ($80) will go to Indiegogo.
  • 22% ($420) will go to marketing and the prizes for you, our wonderful donors!
  • 12% ($250) will go to props such as cigarettes, umbrellas, diner accessories, etc.
  • 12% ($250) will go to costuming.
  • 50% ($1000) will go to the set design of the production. Our show takes place on a New York City street corner, in a church, and in a diner but consists of no set changes. This means that our set will have to be very big and very detailed and it even features multiple stories in order to accommodate for all that is needed. 

Any money we make over this $2,000 goal will go towards making the set for the show even more elaborate and detailed.  

Another great way to help us out is just by simply sharing this page with your friends and family. The more voices we can get the better our chances are at making our dream a reality!

Conscious Inertia Moving Forward

In the minds of Gratify Theatre Works, Conscious Inertia is only taking its first steps into the theatre community. Being that many of our company members and fans are located on the Purchase College campus, we thought it would be the best choice as a collective to put this show up in a place with our largest fan pool. In the future, we would like to bring this show into a much wider community and make it an even bigger production than it already is. Conscious Inertia may be Gratify Theatre Works first official production, but we are planning to roll in with a bang! Thank you so much for your incredible support and don't forget to share this page with all of your friends!

Check out our website: http://www.gratifytheatreworks.com/

Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/gratifytheatreworks

Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/GRATIFY_THEATRE

Follow us on Instagram: http://instagram.com/gratifytheatreworks


Special Thanks to Jonathan Daniel Schenk for making our Indiegogo video!

story:
Fire & Ice Theatre

The 2014 Fire & Ice Theatre Farm Exchange is our inaugural workshop designed for artists from different parts of the world to meet and collaborate in the beautiful, remote setting of volcanic Hawaii. For seven days, we will practice self-reflection, artistic freedom, environmental stewardship, and intercultural dialogue, in hopes of finding new discoveries about ourselves, our world, and our art.  This workshop includes psychophysical acting, ensemble-devised theatre, meditation, yoga, land cultivation, and community outreach.  

We intend to host bi-yearly workshops, performances, and ongoing trainings in Hawaii and Iceland, building bridges between these two island cultures.

From January 6th to 12th, we will have 7 artists gather at Polestar Gardens, a 20-acre farm and intentional community on the Big Island of Hawaii. The theme of the workshop is "Na Leo o ka Aina" (Voices of the Land), in which we will explore myths and histories of the various cultures represented in our ensemble.  The ensemble will train together and research the host community, facilitate theater workshops with youth at the Hawaii Academy of Arts & Science (HAAS), and collaborate on a final performance (or Open Rehearsal). Gloria has close ties with both Polestar Gardens, where she used to practice yoga, and with HAAS charter school, where she used to teach grades 7-12. Polestar consistently hosts HAAS students on their farm for service projects.

The Founders and Directors of Fire & Ice are Gloria Baraquio from Hawaii and Hrefna Larusdottir from Iceland. Gloria is a yoga teacher, actor, writer, producer, singer, and dancer who currently lives in Los Angeles, California.  Hrefna is a performance artist, director, physical theater trainer, and mother who currently resides in Boulder, Colorado. At Naropa University, they practiced together in Grotowski acting, Roy Hart voice technique, Somatics, Viewpoints, Meditation, and Yoga.

We believe that theater is the place to celebrate relationships, explore truth, and delve into the multiplicities of human existence. We believe that nature can inspire raw, organic artistic expression. We believe that self-reflection and spiritual practice cultivate authentic, meaningful art.  We believe that art is meant to be shared and experienced through different lenses.  We envision a world of honest, fully-expressed beings living in balance with nature and society.

Fire & Ice is really our dream, and we need YOU to help us manifest it!

What We Need

Our expenses for this year's Theatre Farm Exchange: $5,456.00

We expect about $3,000 to come in from grants and participant fees, so $2,500 or more from this campaign will help us cover flights and ground transportation. Any extra will go  towards lodging, then meals, production costs, incidentals, and artist fees.

The Impact

  1. We are greening the planet.
  2. We are connecting cultures and communities.
  3. We are crossing disciplines.
  4. We are exchanging knowledge with the youth.
  5. We are evolving ourselves through self-reflection and self-expression.

Other Ways You Can Help

  1. Please tell your friends about us and this awesome project!
  2. Please share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, email, and every other social media tool of your choice!
  3. Send us good loving energy:)

story:
Short Summary

Help bring the Thistle to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in August 2014!

Olga Mokhovaya, a well known Russian Theater actress (Jesus Christ Super Star Russian production), with the composer Leonid Golovko, wrote the Thistle, an original musical that is a love story and love for Scotland. Written, directed and produced in Moscow and sung in Russian, the Thistle tells the story of the English conquer of Scotland.  

Emotive, Emotional and Compelling! 

The Thistle is invited to perform at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe New Town Theater as a marquee performance of 23 shows for a full festival run.

Support for the Thistle will be of interest to Scottish nationals and descendants; and soft hearts with a love of big musical theater. Capture and feel a rich love story about Scotland that is surprisingly accurate from an outsider's view!  

The plot is shaped like an old medieval parable centered around the ‘Hero’ that carries the collective image of the true freestyle proud Scot with an independent mind and a strong character who tills his land, trusts his friends and knows how to enjoy life.

And at a time when the brave Scots face the unbearable and are captured by the English, it appears that for the sake of his native land, the Hero is ready to fight to the end and to sacrifice all that is dear to him. The Thistle is a nationalist story of the brave and independent spirit of Scotland, standing ready to fight to the death.  The Thistle tells this amazing story through a 90 minute performance of 18 original songs sung from the heart.

The Thistle is not only a national symbol of Scotland, it is also the Hero's alter ego, representing his irrepressible free spirit and loyalty to his country. The sacred and precious plant of the Scots becomes irrelevant, annoying and completely unnecessary weed in the ‘perfect English rose garden’.

The Hero and Thistle is infinitely representative of the natural beauty of Scotland, its heroic legends, its poet and the great love of the Scots. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise $30,000.

Our cast and crew is 19 strong and we ask for your generous support to help bring the Thistle to life in Edinburgh. Your support will help fund our production; specifically the creation of our CD Master of the lyrics and score; our travel costs to Edinburgh for one month and the set design including Super Script sub-titles in English.

All contributors will receive a personal Thank You Letter from the Cast & Crew! 

All contributions of $25. or more will receive a signed copy of the Thistle CD!

All contributions of $125. or more will receive 2 tickets to one performance of the Thistle in Edinburgh!

All contributions of $500. or more will receive 2 tickets the Opening Night of the Thistle in Edinburgh including complimentary hospitality and Cast Meet/Greet following the performance!

The Impact

The Thistle is an extraordinary story about Scotland from the vantage of a Russian born and bred script that is longing to be told internationally. First performed in Moscow in 2013, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe marks its international debut in a unique year - with the Scottish National referendum taking place just two months later. 

The Thistle expects to receive significant media and press exposure given its story; the uniqueness and excitement of a Russian Theater Group bringing it to life and the plain fact that the script is very, very good. 

Our campaign is based on the premise that every single dollar helps, particularly an international act with a great musical and all the added expenses to be in Edinburgh that go along with it. Your support will help bring the Thistle to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe (the largest arts festival in the world); and each and every dollar raised will be cherished, protected and used wisely like a fine wee dram should be. 

Our Cast has more than 100 years experience in Russian theater, music and television and for all us, the Thistle represents the once in a lifetime opportunity to perform internationally!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help to bring the Thistle to Edinburgh with your donation today. We invite you to 'like' our Facebook page; and to help spread the great news of a Russian Theater Company on its way to Edinburgh with a story about Scotland !

story:
Hey people!

We are Sarah Lawrence College's improv team Feral Christine! We just won the National College Improv Tournament's New York regionals and are competing in the nationals in Chicago on March 14th! Unfortunately, getting 15 people from New York to Chicago is a pretty costly ordeal so we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

Pretty much the two major things we are looking for help with is 

a. Transportation 

and

b. Housing

We've decided to take our own cars and drive to Chicago, so we're looking at a lot of money on gas, an estimated $800. The rest of the money will go towards finding housing for all of us. We've got some really great prizes if you donate, spread the word! 


About Us

We are a 15 person improv and sketch comedy group based at Sarah Lawrence College. We perform both on campus and in other venues such as Hampshire College, UMass Amherst, New York University, and the Del Close Marathon in New York City. We also organized the Sarah Lawrence Comedy Festival in 2013 which featured workshops taught by established performers form the Upright Citizens Brigade and Magnet Theater. We love playing together and other cool stuff like pizza and Law and Order. We're honored to be performing at the National College Improv Tournament!

About the Tournament

The College Improv Tournament is an annual competition held in Chicago that takes 16 of the best college teams in America and pits them against each other for collegiate improvisational supremacy. We'll be performing in the national competition round on March 14, 2015 at Chicago's Vittum Theater. Feral Christine is so far the only team this year that has never competed previously and has made it to the nationals, so this is a huge opportunity for us and our school.

story:
Qui sommes-nous?

Les Productions du Sixième Art sont constituées de jeunes professionnels qui partagent une passion pour les arts de la scène, plus particulièrement pour la comédie musicale. Composée de musiciens, de chanteurs, de danseurs,  de comédiens et d’acteurs culturels, l’équipe de production se veut innovatrice en offrant aux Québécois la chance de découvrir et d’apprécier cet art plutôt méconnu, en produisant complètement en français. Tout ceci dans le but de perdurer à travers les années et de permettre à plusieurs générations d’artistes de se produire sur la scène québécoise.

Mission

— Faire rayonner et rendre accessible la comédie musicale dans la ville de Québec, en offrant à ses habitants la possibilité de découvrir de grandes productions de partout à travers le monde, entièrement adaptées en français;

— Offrir un tremplin à de jeunes professionnels du milieu des arts de la scène, accomplis ou en devenir, en leur offrant une expérience concrète et enrichissante encadrée par des professionnels expérimentés du milieu;

— Encourager le développement et l’accomplissement professionnel en stimulant l’emploi dans le milieu des arts et de la culture, et ce, dans différents domaines tels que le théâtre, le chant, la danse, la musique, la mise en scène, la production et autres.

Le Chanteur de noces

Résumé

Robbie, jeune chanteur et musicien, fait carrière en tant que chanteur de noces. En peine d’amour, il se lie d’amitié avec Julia, une collègue de travail pour qui il développera des sentiments amoureux au cours de la pièce. Malheureusement, l’élue de son cœur est déjà fiancée à un jeune homme riche et ambitieux. Robbie tentera donc de conquérir le cœur de Julia et de la convaincre qu’il est bel et bien l’homme de sa vie.

Ce dont nous avons besoin

Il nous manque encore 1000 $ pour payer la location des équipements techniques et nos décors et costumes. C’est une production d’envergure qui demande beaucoup d’éléments. Grâce à vous, nous pourrons vous en mettre plein la vue avec de l’équipement de qualité et un visuel à vous couper le souffle!

Votre impact

Grâce à ce tout premier projet, les Productions du Sixième Art comptent s’implanter à long terme dans le monde des arts de la scène à Québec. Cette production n’est que le début d’une aventure où pourront participer chaque année une vingtaine d’artistes amateurs et près d’une dizaine de professionnels du milieu des arts et de la culture. En plus d’offrir un tremplin à ces jeunes artistes et professionnels, nous offrons aussi en primeur à tous les habitants de la Capitale la possibilité de voir de grandes comédies musicales de partout à travers le monde entièrement adaptées en français. Et tout cela grâce à vous!

N’oubliez pas que même si vous ne pouvez pas nous aider financièrement, vous pouvez partager notre événement et aimer notre page Facebook à www.facebook.com/ProductionsSixiemeArt

story:
Hi! We're Thespionage Theatre Company

Thespionage is Philly's first Pay-What-You-Can (PWYC) theatre company and one of the first PWYC theatre companies in the United States that produces new plays. We're an ensemble of ultra-creative individuals with a common goal of making theatre inclusive and accessible to everyone. At Thespionage you name the price for every show you see and no one is ever turned away for lack of funds. 

Our mission is to create original, accessible performances that bring together city, artist and audience — and in the words of Montell Jordan, this is how we to do it:

Every season Thespionage solicits plays from local writers and all submissions are read and considered by our team. We accept submissions in all genres and are open to all residents of Philadelphia and the surrounding area. There is no entry fee to submit and writers are welcome to send as many plays as they'd like. Once a selection is made our ensemble works together with the playwright to develop their show from the ground up. This gives the playwright the opportunity to nurture a new play from conception to production and allows local performers to develop new characters in an environment that's supportive, playful and kind.  

In addition, Thespionage produces high energy Thespionage Originals throughout the year. Thespionage Originals are conceptualized, written and performed by our ensemble and proceeds from Originals help fund the productions by local writers.  Upcoming Originals like The Playoffs: A 10-Minute Play Battle Royale and Are You Afraid of the Bar: A Theatrical Pub Crawl keep our performances fresh and provide even more PWYC performances for our supporters.

In the spirit of making theatre accessible and supporting local talent, Thespionage also plans to reach the community by broadcasting live performances and posting recordings and short video sketches online. So, even if you can't make it to our performances, you can still follow us on the web.

The Thespionage community has grown exponentially over the past year and the talented volunteers are eager to provide the community with exciting, engaging theatrical experiences.

(Find out more about our ensemble members through their bios:  http://thespionage.com/meet-our-ensemble.html

(Here’s a glimpse of our  plans for the 2015 season:  http://thespionage.com/coming-soon-about-us.html)

(Here’s a highlight real from a 2014 performance done in the round, in a night club:  https://youtu.be/Y2qvxAPp6CU <-- Look out! Contains adult themes, guys!


What We Need & Beyond!
As a start-up theatre company, funding is limited to our supporters, typically friends, family and friends of family/friends. Opportunities for grants and sponsors become more readily available after two years of production. Your support for our second season in 2015 is critical for the success of Thespionage as it will bridge the gap between a start-up and an established company eligible for grants and sponsorship. We invite everyone to be a friend of Thespionage and volunteer to create original theatre.  We want you to share in our mission and make PWYC theatre a permanent reality in Philadelphia. Together, we can build something great and share it together for years to come.

The Thespionage Impact

Thespionage's planned 2015 season includes the production of Far Away Oranges, the work of a Pennsylvania Playwright Vicki Haller Graff. The production of unpublished plays such as this brings attention to the works of local playwrights and fosters their ability to publish their works and advance in their profession.

Thespionage Originals will feature our Ensemble, a talented group of more than 20 local performance artists and provide them the opportunity to perform for the community and showcase their abilities.

PWYC theatre will bring theatre to working families who might find it difficult to otherwise attend alternative venues in Philadelphia. Thespionage will bring together the artistic community in a way that has never been done before by being open to everyone and relying purely upon the generosity of its supporters.


We're up for the Challenge

Our biggest hurdle is running out of money before we reach our 3rd birthday. We became operational January 2014.  Come January 2016-17, our increased eligibility for grant money and sponsorship will give us other fundraising avenues to pursue.  Until then, our funds come from you:  our friends, our families, and our audience. 

We are confident in our ability to produce compelling original theater on a tight budget.  We are here to take risks and meet challenges.  In our first year, concerns arose in our search for affordable venues.  We viewed this as an opportunity to revise our perspective, to create new solutions, and to build new framework in which to perform theater.  We hope that our ability to adapt, survive and thrive in challenging circumstances will resonate with you, and that your support will sustain us in our early years.

Our next challenge is the size of the task which we are undertaking.  Last year, we produced one original work in two separate, unusual venues giving 15+ local artists the chance to work on their craft by acting, building properties and sets, designing light, sound and costumes.  We did all this and launched our company on a $3000 budget.  In 2015, we aim use the knowledge gained from our experiences to produce one original work by a Pennsylvania writer, as well as two original works co-written by members of our Thespionage ensemble.  Our plan for this year also includes utilizing the talents of at least 40+ local artists and performing in new venues, including the streets, parks and parking lots of Philadelphia.  We plan to accomplishing this with a budget of $5000.  We are ambitious, and we plan on growing and adapting while still meeting our proposed goals.

   

Sharing is Caring & Other Ways to Help

Spread Word of Our Cause.

Share Thespionage’s plans via Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, email, and word of mouth. You have more power than you think.  If you look to the lefthand side of this window, you can see a column of shortcuts to share this page.  When you share our name with your endorsement, you lend a little of your strength to us.  Thank you!  

Volunteer.

Contact us here:  http://thespionage.com/contact.html if you want to volunteer your time instead of your money.  We know everyone’s time is valuable, and we’re sincerely grateful.

Follow us.

https://www.facebook.com/Thespionage

http://instagram.com/thespionagephl

https://twitter.com/thespionagephl  

http://thespionage.com/

Featured ensemble members (in order of appearance): Rob Tomlinson, Tommy Foy, Amanda Lynch, Harry Watermeier, Heather Chonoles, Jarrett Thompson, Cris Welti, Shannon Turner, Chris Kober, Wesley Fenza, Paul Rahter, Frank Ermillio, Lesley Berkowitz, Meredith Murray, Andrew Deitch, John Bonner, Trevor Cahill and Emily Orton Bonner to see their full bios visit: http://www.thespionage.com/meet-our-ensemble.html

story:
Summary:

Who are you?

The Aeneid Theatre Company is a new student theatre company devoted to independently producing upstanding non-musical plays at USC.  We are absolutely thrilled to kick off our second season with Peter Shaffer's Equus. 

What's that?

Equus is one of the late Peter Shaffer's most well-known plays, along with Amadeus, and shares an account of a brilliant psychiatrist's attempt to treat a 17 year-old boy who has blinded six horses with a metal spike. This whirlwind of a piece of theatre deals with the psychiatrist's doubts about his profession and common conventions of "normalcy" that he contends with as he delves further and further into the mind of a disturbed youth. As the audience delves further and further into the mystery of the boy's motivations, a heinous and incomprehensible act becomes one with a little more clarity, and we are forced to ask ourselves what it means to "treat" someone and whether or not the small defense mechanisms and insecurities of every day, mundane life may not be so different from those afflicting the "diseased."

So what's the Indiegogo page for?

The next step of this very important process involves an equally important person: You. Because we are a student organization, we don't have the funding and support that other, long-standing production companies possess. We need a little more assistance to get our company off the ground and onto the stage, and contributors like you can make all the difference in the world.

With your help, ATC can make a real impact within the USC theatre community for all the students involved.

What We Need & What You Get

Where does the money go?

The production team has spent a lot of time carefully creating a budget for the production. The budget is broken down between the costs of scenic design, costuming, venue fees, and other essentials for producing the show. All money raised will go directly to funding these essential costs of production. 

The Impact

How does this help in the big picture?

While USC has amazing student organizations devoted to producing a wide variety of theatre, including musicals, new works, and even sketch comedy. However, USC doesn't have the best track record when it comes to regularly producing great non-musical plays, so we at ATC have taken it upon ourselves to fill that niche. In order for this company to thrive and continue expanding the diversity of the theatrical scene here at USC, we need your help. Every dollar raised helps us reach that goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

What if I'm totally, 100% broke?

If you don't have a couple dollars to spare right now, that's okay! You can still help in other ways. Most importantly, you can share this page on all your social media profiles and help spread the word to as many people as possible! And of course, please come to our show! 

USC's Massman Theatre  
1029 Childs Way, Los Angeles, CA 90089
October 6th - 7pm
October 7th - 7pm, 11pm
October 8th - 2:30pm, 8pm
October 9th - 2:30pm
