story:
The Harvest

DUELS will be produced by amador/stokes at 12th Ave Arts in Seattle for four weekends, Aug 18 - Sep 11, 2016. The play will feature the acting talents of Marianna de Fazio, Daniel Christensen, and Carter Rodriquez, the direction of José Amador, and the writing of Nick Stokes.

Our experienced team includes Craig Bradshaw (co-producer), Amy LaZerte (costume design), Tess Malone (light design), Michael James Adam (sound design), Silas James (scene design), and more to come.

In the surreally absurd tragedy DUELS, Irene gardens and lives with John and Juan killing each other again and again and again.

DUELS bleeds vegetable juice, smashes tomatoes, smears blackberries, and recedes from suburban now to rural then, when John was Irene’s investor husband, Juan was her Latino gardener, and the shooting began.

DUELS speaks Spanish and English, like many people.

DUELS will use as much produce from Stokes's and the team's garden as is possible. We are gardening for art.

[Both Aimée and Kasia have had to step away from the production, but we are thrilled to welcome Marianna and Silas!]

The Seeds

With our current team, amador/stokes produced a twenty-minute chunk of DUELS (Orange) at On the Boards Northwest New Works Festival 2013. Building from that experience to a full production has been the goal from the beginning, and DUELS is about to come to fruition. We got our hands dirty, loved, brandished carrots, and died. Now we dig deeper.

Both Amador and Stokes have successfully produced their work in the not-so-distant past, Amador especially with his solo performances such as the multiple incarnations of "El Hijo Prodigo" and Stokes with his plays "The Sound We Make" and "Whiteout" at Old City Hall in Tacoma.

DUELS has also received staged readings with Northwest Playwrights Alliance at Seattle Rep and at the erstwhile Open Circle Theater. The first draft of DUELS was written in 2008 while Stokes was in residence at Artist Trust's Camano Island Residency. Many people have worked to make it what it will be.

We are asking you, too, to help us make it happen.

Daniel Christensen, Aimée Bruneau, Carter Rodriquez, OtB NWNW '13, photo by Tim Summers.

The Hands

José Amador is an actor, director and writer of plays, sketch, screenplays along with various musings on the Arts. The latter could be read in the digital pages of The Seattle Star, a reader-supported online journal for which he is a co-founder, contributor and editor. In 2014 at Annex Theater, he directed "Black Like Us" by Rachel Atkins, which won the Gregory Award for New Play.

Nick Stokes writes plays, fictions, nothings, arrangements, pieces of prose, and others. He is the author of the novel Affair. Among other explorations, he recently completed an immersive anti-choose-your-own-adventure novel. He's been making theater in the PNW since 2006; sometimes he packs mules in the wilderness of Montana; he's sorta at nickstokes.net.

Marianna de Fazio was a 3-year company member of The International Theatre Vienna, before moving to Seattle. She received her MFA from the University of Washington’s Professional Actor Training Program. Because of her time abroad, Marianna speaks German and incorporates her love of other culture, travel and language into her acting, voice work and accent coaching. (www.mariannadefazio.com)

Daniel Christensen is just so very grateful.  You can find him at thecoffeetable.tv, if you’ve a taste for sci-fi indy comedy.  Thanks to all, especially Alison. 

Carter Rodriquez is an actor, director, musician, and visual artist who has worked on many of Seattle’s stages performing contemporary, classical and original works of theatre. He is grateful to you for supporting the arts.

Thank you to Craig Bradshaw, Amy LaZerte, Tess Malone, and all who have worked on Duels in addition to our team members, including: Aimée Bruneau, Evan Tucker, Erin Kraft, Amy Love, Shawn Law, Lenore Bensinger, Jason Harber, Johanna Horowitz, Patrick Scott, Mike Tilton, Dan Harvey, and Antoinette Michelle.

Economy

We are asking for $10,000, which will be budgeted as follows:

  • rent: $4050
  • stipends for actors (3): $1500
  • stipends for designers (6): $950 (set $200, sound $200, lights $200, costume $200, props $75, effects $75)
  • stipend for stage manager: $500
  • materials: $1000 (set $500, costumes $300, props $100, effects $100)
  • graphic design: $200
  • publicity person stipend: $150
  • publicity (posters, distribution, programs) $325
  • liability insurance (contract required): $325
  • indiegogo (5%) + credit card / paypal (3-5%) + award shipping: $1000

If we make our goal, ticket sales (beyond comps and perk award tickets), an estimate for which is broken down below, will go to other possible incurred costs (such as crop failure, front-of-house and board operator coverage, locust devastation, postcards, dust bowl conditions, rehearsal rentals, unseasonable monsoons, award shipping from unexpected nationwide support), then to compensate the producers equal to the actors, after which the money will be spread equally among all team members, actors, and designers, like we are communal gardeners. In the current projection the bonus for all team members would be a modest $100 IF no extra expenses are incurred.

Projected ticket sales:

  • 11 ticketed shows * 20 new sales per show = 220 tickets
  • Priced so that with fees, $20 full admission and $10 student, industry, etc.
  • Coming to $18.35 full, and $8.70 discount list price at Brown Paper Tickets
  • If sales are 50/50 full and discount, then average ticket list price is $13.525
  • 220 tickets * $13.525 = $2975.50 income
  • Minus Seattle Admission Tax: $302.78 (5% of full price of all attendees, projecting 30/night)
  • Net projected ticket income: $2672.72

Digging Again, or Shooting a Dead Man

DUELS digs below realism/naturalism. The play is tactile, messy, and sensual. It is imagery and emotion. At the same time, it is lyrical; it employs language; it is poetic. Sometimes it knows what it means. Spanish is used in the play; comprehension is possible but unnecessary as we approach the fundamental, the original duel, the first love made and broken.

As a repetition of a duel and love triangle that goes backward to the first duel, DUELS is partly a response to linearity and progress, giving heed to a repeated sow/harvest cycle. The play tells a story outside the typical narrative construct by twisting and stretching and perhaps momentarily revitalizing the tired convention of the love triangle. And by presenting a reverse chronology. And by repeating the central repeatings.

DUELS is comical and tragic and topical in its imagery of real estate development and its circling around economic lack, abundance, and the using of people. Capitalism and insatiability consume. The migrant plight competes for light and nutrients: put down roots, be economically successful, live an American life, find one's place.

Are independence and self-sufficiency the goals?

Many Hands

Joins us in bringing DUELS to life by Donating, Sharing, and Spreading the Word!

Image by Omar Willey.
story_txt:
The Harvest


DUELS will be produced by amador/stokes at 12th Ave Arts in Seattle for four weekends, Aug 18 - Sep 11, 2016. The play will feature the acting talents of Marianna de Fazio, Daniel Christensen, and Carter Rodriquez, the direction of José Amador, and the writing of Nick Stokes.
Our experienced team includes Craig Bradshaw (co-producer), Amy LaZerte (costume design), Tess Malone (light design), Michael James Adam (sound design), Silas James (scene design), and more to come.
In the surreally absurd tragedy DUELS, Irene gardens and lives with John and Juan killing
each other again and again and again. 
DUELS bleeds
vegetable juice, smashes tomatoes, smears blackberries, and recedes from
suburban now to rural then, when John was Irene’s investor husband, Juan
was her Latino gardener, and the shooting began.
DUELS speaks Spanish and English, like many people.
DUELS will use as much produce from Stokes's and the team's garden as is possible. We are gardening for art. 
[Both Aimée and Kasia have had to step away from the production, but we are thrilled to welcome Marianna and Silas!]

The Seeds
With our current team, amador/stokes produced a twenty-minute chunk of 
DUELS (Orange) at On the Boards Northwest New Works Festival 2013. Building 
from that experience to a full production has been the goal from the 
beginning, and DUELS is about to come to fruition. We got our hands dirty, loved, brandished carrots, and died. Now we dig deeper.
Both Amador and Stokes have successfully produced their work in the not-so-distant past, Amador 
especially with his solo performances such as the multiple incarnations 
of "El Hijo Prodigo" and Stokes with his plays "The Sound We Make" and 
"Whiteout" at Old City Hall in Tacoma. 
DUELS has also received staged readings with Northwest Playwrights Alliance at Seattle Rep and at the erstwhile Open Circle Theater. The first draft of DUELS was written in 2008 while Stokes was in residence at Artist Trust's Camano Island Residency. Many people have worked to make it what it will be.
 
  We are asking you, too, to help us make it happen.


Daniel Christensen, Aimée Bruneau, Carter Rodriquez, OtB NWNW '13, photo by Tim Summers.
  

The Hands


José
Amador is an actor, director and writer of plays, sketch, screenplays along
with various musings on the Arts. The latter could be read in the digital pages
of The Seattle Star, a reader-supported online journal for which he is a
co-founder, contributor and editor. In 2014 at Annex Theater, he directed "Black Like Us" by Rachel Atkins, which won the Gregory Award for New Play.
Nick
Stokes writes plays, fictions, nothings, arrangements, pieces of prose, 
and
others. He is the author of the novel Affair. Among other explorations, 
he recently completed an immersive anti-choose-your-own-adventure
novel. He's been making theater in the PNW since 
2006; sometimes he packs mules in the wilderness of Montana; he's sorta at nickstokes.net.
Marianna de Fazio was a 3-year 
company member of The International Theatre Vienna, before moving to 
Seattle. She received her MFA from the University 
of Washington’s Professional Actor Training Program. Because of her 
time abroad, Marianna speaks German and incorporates her love of other 
culture, travel and language into her acting, voice work and accent 
coaching. (www.mariannadefazio.com)
Daniel Christensen is just so very
grateful.  You can find him at thecoffeetable.tv, if you’ve a taste for
sci-fi indy comedy.  Thanks to all, especially Alison.  
Carter Rodriquez is an actor, director, musician, and visual
artist who has worked on many of Seattle’s stages performing contemporary,
classical and original works of theatre. He is grateful to you for supporting
the arts.
Thank you to Craig Bradshaw, Amy LaZerte, Tess Malone, and all who have worked on Duels in addition to our 
team members, including: Aimée Bruneau, Evan Tucker, Erin Kraft, Amy Love, Shawn Law, 
Lenore Bensinger, Jason Harber, Johanna Horowitz, Patrick Scott, Mike 
Tilton, Dan Harvey, and Antoinette Michelle.

Economy
We are asking for $10,000, which will be budgeted as follows:

rent: $4050
stipends for actors (3): $1500
stipends for designers (6): $950 (set $200, sound $200, lights $200, costume $200, props $75, effects $75)
stipend for stage manager: $500
materials: $1000 (set $500, costumes $300, props $100, effects $100)

graphic design: $200 
publicity person stipend: $150
publicity (posters, distribution, programs) $325
liability insurance (contract required): $325

indiegogo (5%) + credit card / paypal (3-5%) + award shipping: $1000

If we make our goal, ticket sales (beyond comps and perk award 
tickets), an estimate for which is broken down below, will go to other possible 
incurred costs (such as crop failure, front-of-house and board operator coverage, 
locust devastation, postcards, dust bowl conditions, rehearsal rentals, unseasonable monsoons, award shipping from unexpected nationwide support), then to compensate the producers equal to the actors, after which the money will be spread equally among all team 
members, actors, and designers, like we are communal gardeners. In the current projection the bonus for all team members would be a modest $100 IF no extra expenses are incurred.
Projected ticket sales: 


11 ticketed shows * 20 new sales per show = 220 tickets
Priced so that with fees, $20 full admission and $10 student, industry, etc.
Coming to $18.35 full, and $8.70 discount list price at Brown Paper Tickets
If sales are 50/50 full and discount, then average ticket list price is $13.525
220 tickets * $13.525 = $2975.50 income
Minus Seattle Admission Tax: $302.78 (5% of full price of all attendees, projecting 30/night)
Net projected ticket income: $2672.72

Digging Again, or Shooting a Dead Man



DUELS digs below realism/naturalism. The play is tactile,
messy, and sensual. It is imagery and emotion. At the same time, it is lyrical;
it employs language; it is poetic. Sometimes it knows what it means. Spanish is used in the play; comprehension is possible but unnecessary as we approach the fundamental, the
original duel, the first love made and broken.
As a repetition of a duel and love triangle that goes backward
to the first duel, DUELS is partly a response to linearity and progress, giving heed to a repeated sow/harvest cycle. The play
tells a story outside the typical narrative construct by twisting and
stretching and perhaps momentarily revitalizing the tired convention of the
love triangle. And by presenting a reverse chronology. And by repeating the
central repeatings. 
DUELS is comical and tragic and topical in its imagery of real estate development
and its circling around economic lack, abundance, and the using of
people. Capitalism and insatiability consume. The migrant plight competes for light and nutrients: put down roots, be economically successful, live an American life, find one's place. 
Are independence and
self-sufficiency the goals?

Many Hands
Joins us in bringing DUELS to life by Donating, Sharing, and Spreading the Word! 

Image by Omar Willey.

story:
Le Problème is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Le Problème must be made to "Fractured Atlas" only, and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The Project

Le Problème, a play by author and filmmaker François Bégaudeau, premiered in Paris in 2011. Sarah Krasnow saw the production at the Parisian theater Théâtre du Rond Point, and never forgot the impact. She translated it into English in 2013 as a Master's student in Dramaturgy at Yale School of Drama.    

Last spring, Sarah pitched a production of Le Problème to the Araca Project, an Off-Broadway theater festival run by Broadway production company The Araca Group (they did Wicked...ever heard of it?).

The show we envisioned would use Sarah's translation, but it would also have a unique feature: all the actors would be bilingual, and the dialogue would shift between English and French.  Projected supertitles would translate whichever language was being spoken. The Araca board loved the idea and agreed to include Le Problème in the 2015 Araca Project!

This production marks the US PREMIERE of Le Problème, as well as its first appearance in (partial) translation, and we want to do everything we can to ensure its success! We'd love for you to be a part of it.

What We Need

We need your help to get this production up and running! Your contributions will go towards these expenses (any amount helps!):

$10         Fractured Atlas membership for one month (which gives us access to fiscal
                 sponsorship, and lets you make a tax-deductible contribution)

$70         Subscription to Squarespace website builder (see the results at                                         www.leprob.com)

$200      Insurance (in case we lose our grip when assembling a set piece)

$400      Rental fee for projectors (otherwise, no supertitles)

$500       Costume pieces (including Alban’s glasses, Adam’s button-down shirt,                         Julie’s sneakers, and Annie’s overcoat)

$800       Lighting equipment (the play takes place in the evening, not in the dark)

$1000     Set pieces, paint, and lumber (to create the family’s living room -
                   wait till you see the concept!)

$2000    Salaries for our actors (though they're priceless)

We want to make it worth your while! Check out our perks in the right margin.  All contributions get a shout-out on our Facebook page.

Margot Steinberg               Anton Obeid         Christo Jack Rondeau  Mélanie Le Gall
"Annie"                                   "Alban"                   "Adam"                              "Julie"

About the Show

WHEN?        October 7-10th, 8pm
                        Student matinee October 8th, 4pm
                        Matinees October 10th and 11th, 2pm

WHERE?      American Theatre of Actors, 314 West 54th Street, New York, NY

HOW?           Book tickets and view calendar by clicking here - all tickets $15

“I’m going where I’m still desired,” says Annie, explaining to her husband, Alban, and her children, Adam and Julie, why she is leaving them for a man she met at work. Capturing one hour in the life of a family in crisis, Le Problème examines mother, father, son, and daughter as they navigate the responsibilities they have to themselves and each other. When a relationship changes, what is the solution? Or is there even a problem?

About the Playwright:
François Bégaudeau has become well-known in France for his film, Entre les murs (American title: The Class), which won the Palme d'Or at the 2008 Cannes Film Festival.  Before starring in the film, which was adapted from his novel of the same name, Bégaudeau was a punk rock singer in the group Zabriskie Point, a columnist and film critic, and a teacher.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute at this time, we'd still love your support!
  • Visit our website, where you can sign up for our newsletter
  • Share this campaign with anyone who might have an interest in the project
  • Like us on Facebook
  • And of course...come see the show!

MERCI/THANK YOU!

Sarah Krasnow          Sally Shen                  Stephanie Rolland       Hannah Spratt
Co-Producers

story:
Who Are We?

We are Singles Awareness Productions. Founded in Victoria, Canada, we have spread our wings and are now traveling the world! Currently situated in Melbourne, this year we are bringing our 5th Fringe show to the Adelaide Fringe. 

About the Project:
Art of the Eight Limbs 

Written by award winning Canadian playwright Kat Taddei. Directed by renowned Canadian theatre artist Blair Moro. Featuring Australians Emily Jackson and Timothy Smith, and Canadian Stephanie Nikolaidis. Art of the Eight Limbs is a whirlwind piece of theatre: three different eccentrics are torn out of their comfort zones and thrust into a bizarre chain of causally-related events. The piece seeks to find the humanity in even the most absurd of realities.

 For more information about our creative team, check out the bios at the bottom! 

What We Need

Adelaide Fringe is the SECOND BIGGEST Fringe Festival in the WORLD. We are raising money to pay for the marketing costs of this wonderful festival.

If we make it to our goal of $1000, we will be able to buy TWO quarter page slots in local fringe guides, which are seen by massive amounts of visitors to the Adelaide Fringe (2 million last year!).

We will be out marketing/sprooking every night of the festival, but we can't reach everyone. Being able to purchase these ad spaces will help us reach people who never would have heard of our show beforehand. This is particularly important to us as an international company; we don't have the advantage of being established here in Adelaide. 

Thank you all! 

Blair Moro

Singles Awareness Productions

#8Limbs #ADLFringe @SingleAwareProd


The Writer: Kat Taddei

Kat is a writer, stage manager and performer, wrapping up her fourth and final year in the University of Victoria's Creative Writing program. Before she had even memorized the alphabet, Kat would wander around the house "reading" aloud from her mother's Agatha Christie novels (really, just making up stories as she went along). Kat's plays have been produced for Langham Court's ACTivate Festival, Epiphany Theatre's Interplay Festival, UVic's Student Alternative Theatre Company, and Intrepid's brand new queer theatre festival, OUTstages. Most recently, her show Two was awarded Favourite New Play at the 2015 Victoria Fringe Festival. Kat is thrilled to make her international debut as a playwright with Art of the Eight Limbs, especially under the direction of her long-lost friend (and first year 'big buddy' at the Phoenix Theatre), Blair Moro.


Playing the role of White: Stephanie Nikoladis


Stephanie got her start in acting through her first love: dance! She was introduced to the world of musical theatre as a child and took to it right away. She began her training through Arts York, the performing arts division at Unionville High School in Ontario, Canada. During this time she was cast as lead role ‘Darla’ in the independent feature film “Hurt” which was directed and written by Steve DiMarco. DiMarco became something of a mentor to her and helped to nurture her passion and drive for performance. While filming “Hurt” Stephanie met up-and-coming film maker Andrew Martin-Smith and was quickly cast as lead ‘Alice’ in his independent short film “Neverland.”

Stephanie continued her studies in the Phoenix Theatre at the University of Victoria in British Columbia, after which she moved to the Netherlands and became an active member of the International Students Network (ISN) Theatre group. Through this group she co-directed an adapted version of Reginald Rose’s classic play “12 Angry Men” renamed “12 Angry Jurors,” that included a gender diverse cast. She also directed “The Art of the Fugue” and found herself back on stage playing ‘Swift’ in “Words, Words, Words,” both short plays out of David Ives “All in the Timing.”

In her free time she enjoys running, rock climbing, travelling and meeting as many new people as possible.


Playing the role of Blue: Tim Smith


Tim is a recent graduate of the Full Time Program at Sixteenth Street Actors Studio, where he had the privilege of working under the guidance of industry professionals Kerry Armstrong (Lantana, Razzle Dazzle), Karen Davitt (Blue Heelers), Justin Lehman, Jason Raftopoulos, and Kim Krejus. Throughout his time at Sixteenth Street, Tim studied the techniques and methods of Sanford Meisner, Uta Hagen, and Ivana Chubbuck (to name a few), and had the opportunity to work with master teachers Elizabeth Kemp (The Actors Studio, New York) and Carol Rosenfeld (HB Studio, New York). Tim also took two masterclasses in the Chubbuck technique with Anthony Brandon Wong (The Matrix, Little Fish) and studied the Mike Lee method in an intensive workshop with director Rob Marchant.

His time at Flinders Drama Centre (2006-2009) and Sixteenth Street (2014-2015) has given Tim the opportunity to work on a variety of roles for the stage, including Ian from Connor Mcpherson’s Shining City, Danny from Patrick Shanley’s Danny and the Deep Blue Sea and John from David Mamet’s Oleanna. Tim also took pride in tackling roles in new work from Australian playwrights Cerise de Gelder (Just Douglas) and Alex Vickery-Howe (Molly’s Shoes) in the Adelaide Fringe 2009/2011. Tim recently appeared in the short films Dirty Laundry and Last House to Ballarat, and was also seen in several TVC’s, most notably the Bank SA Crimestopper adverts a few years back.

In his free time Tim runs his own photography business, enjoys practicing yoga and is currently developing a webseries based on his experiences with online dating and nightmarish housemates.


Playing the role of Red: Emily Jackson


Emily has attained a Bachelor of Arts (musical theatre) from the University of Ballarat 2011, a Diploma of Dance and Performance from The Dance Factory 2013, and is currently studying a Bachelor of Applied Science/Masters of Speech Pathology at Latrobe University.

Since 2014 Emily has actively been involved in the performing world as a dancer, singer, actor and promotional model. Emily’s main credits include choreographing/dancing in film clips for various Triple J artists, performing in numerous dance floor shows, dance competitions, TVCs, short films and can also be found teaching throughout Melbourne.

In her free time Emily can be found making clay jewellery, practising yoga, eating Nutella and desperately trying to study for Uni.


Directed by: Blair Moro


Blair is a director and actor who has recently landed upon Australia's golden shores. In the short time he has been here he has presented his one man show "The Audience Dies at the End" at both the Sydney and Melbourne Fringe Festivals. Before coming to Australia, Blair worked on over 30 shows between acting, directing, and sound designing. His highlights include running a completely improvised court case in the historical BC Maritime Museum in the 2014 Victoria Fringe, and directing a 1940's vaudevillian show as the final work of his degree at the University of Victoria.

Blair loves to travel: 17 countries visited, 179 to go.

story:
Help us launch our company!

Thyestes is the first production from Derailed Theatre and we need your help to get off the ground!

We are dedicated to making exhilirating theatre which challenges the audience's role within a show. Find us at www.derailedtheatre.com

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise £2000 to cover wages and our production costs - please don't let our actors starve!
  • Treats and perks are available so claim the best ones!
  • Even if we don't reach our goal we will still funnel raised money into wages as our primary concern.

The Impact

We would love to give the world a good smack in the face and shout 'here we are!' - your support will help create a stunning piece of theatre which will allow us to generate interest in the company.

Let's start an artistic revolution: this is the springboard to develop new, bold work to get more people into theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

We value word-of-mouth and the excitement you can generate so please tell your friends!

Aaaaaaand don't forget to hit that share button!

So When's It On?

Oh yes, of course. That would help.

We are running from June 28th - July 10th (excluding Monday 4th)

Tickets can be purchased from the Courtyard Theatre Box Office http://www.thecourtyard.org.uk/whatson/

£12 full, £10 concession
story_txt:
Help us launch our company! Thyestes is the first production from Derailed Theatre and we need your help to get off the ground!
We are dedicated to making exhilirating theatre which challenges the audience's role within a show. Find us at www.derailedtheatre.com   What We Need & What You Get 
We need to raise £2000 to cover wages and our production costs - please don't let our actors starve! Treats and perks are available so claim the best ones! Even if we don't reach our goal we will still funnel raised money into wages as our primary concern.    The Impact We would love to give the world a good smack in the face and shout 'here we are!' - your support will help create a stunning piece of theatre which will allow us to generate interest in the company.
Let's start an artistic revolution: this is the springboard to develop new, bold work to get more people into theatre.

    Other Ways You Can Help We value word-of-mouth and the excitement you can generate so please tell your friends!
Aaaaaaand don't forget to hit that share button!

So When's It On?Oh yes, of course. That would help.We are running from June 28th - July 10th (excluding Monday 4th)
Tickets can be purchased from the Courtyard Theatre Box Office http://www.thecourtyard.org.uk/whatson/
£12 full, £10 concession

story:
Nu Sass Productions is a DC based theatre company that focuses on supporting women in the arts. We do affirmative action hiring for women, and gender blind casting in all plays.

We are currently trying to raise funds to feed the artists involved in the creation of Jean-Paul Sartre's renowned play, No Exit. 

The stipend seems small to many - $100 per artists. We know, it seems small to us too. $100 amounts to basically $1 per man hour being contributed by each artist. We think our actors, producers, designers, and producers are worth millions, and we hope you'll help us raise as much as possible to pay them for their amazing work.

What We Need & What You Get

It's very straightforward: 12 artists, $100 per artist, $1200 to be raised (plus a little extra to cover the platform fees).

We've got a variety of low cost high entertainment perks - all to keep the money going to the artists, and allowing you to participate in the arts. Everything from listing in our programs, to admission to our fandraiser party, to lunch with the production team.

And fear not, even if we don't hit $1500, 100% of the funds raised will go to the artists in an equal split!
What if we go over $1500? The funds will go to the artists in an equal split, and they'll get more than expected, which always makes everyone happy! 

The Impact

In a world full of half million dollar theatre campaigns,it seems impossible to believe that 100 people donating $20 could make the difference for an entire play, and all its artists - But It's Not! 

Literally. 

For less than you spend on a movie and popcorn; for less than you spend on dinner; for less than a night out drinking; for less than your weekly travel expenses YOU can help feed the artists.

More importantly, you're helping ensure the continued growth and success of an independent theatre group, and the independent artists of the DC theatre community. You're helping create a brilliant play, produced by committed female producers, directed by a visionary female director, and featuring meaningful roles for some very talented female actresses (along with all of the amazing men who are helping to bring this project to life). You're helping change the face and voice of theatre, not only in DC but in America.

All for $20 (or more if you're feeling generous)

Risks & Challenges

If we do not raise the $1500 necessary to pay our artists, the difference will come out of the Nu Sass Production Budget. Nu Sass is a developing company, with roughly $5000 to produce with. Basically every project is an all or nothing approach to growth. If the $1500 to pay the artists must come from the Nu Sass budget, it will likely bankrupt the company.

Yup. $1500 is 1/3 of our working budget (and these projects use all of the budget. We never ask you to pay for set or costumes because that's OUR job). We are committed to ensuring our artists get paid and we'd rather see our company die than not pay our artists what we promised. We'd actually rather pay them MORE, but growth is a slow and painful process.

We have plans to produce a fall show, and a free winter musical, as well as a spring production. In order to keep supporting women, and creating more space for new female artists to succeed, we need to have the funds to run. We hope you'll help us do that.

Other Ways You Can Help

If cash donations aren't your style, you can also make tax deductible physical donations to Nu Sass. We are always looking for donated items that can be sold to pay for storage and production costs. 
Likewise, we accept physical donations that support our daily operations, such as set pieces, adobe photo-shop, a mac for light and sound design, or costumes (to name a few!).

OR, you can help us spread the word about the project. Theatre thrives on audiences, so your support helps us keep the play alive! Tickets are on sale now at www.nusass.com. The entire point of theatre is to have an audience, so we would love to have you support us by seeing this amazing show.

story:
ABOUT THE SHOW: A GROUNDBREAKING PRODUCTION!

Icarus Rising, a new dance opera, is an exploration of the story of one man’s attempt to enlighten people about the beauty of freedom. Based on a true story of Lauro de Bosis, an anti-fascist poet, and American actress Ruth Draper, his love and champion, the opera will feature choreography/direction by Sabatino Verlezza and Loretta Fois, music composition by Elliot Sokolov and libretto by Isidore Elias, and will premiere at The Nash Theatre, Somerville, NJ in December 2015.

We are launching our campaign because we need your help in supporting all of the singers, dancers, musicians and collaborators involved in Icarus Rising. A new opera takes a dedicated team…won’t you join our team by contributing to the artistic and production elements of this hugely exciting new venture!

ABOUT THE CREATORS: A FAB FOURSOME!

What brought these four artists together? All four are strongly attracted to the story of Lauro and Ruth…to its love, passion and call to action. It’s time to bring these four together to make something new!

While all four of the show's creators are New York/New Jersey artists that have partnered with each other on numerous projects, this project is the first time they have joined as a team!

Our partnership encompasses music, dance and theatre and brings together the worlds of professional artists, college students and community members. 


WHAT WE’RE DOING

What does it take to make a dance opera? In this case it takes 17 dancers, 10 singers, 2 choreographer/directors, 1 composer, 1 librettist, 1 set and costume designer, and your support! 

In January 2015, Verlezza Dance was awarded a grant from the O’Donnell Green Music and Dance Foundation to compose and choreograph new opera, and in May we were awarded a small grant from Somerset County Cultural and Heritage Commission.

After assembling an awesome and talented cast, we workshoped three scenes of the opera at The Nash Theatre in April 2015.

During the summer we auditioned more dancers, members of Caritas Chamber Chorale joined our cast as vocalists, and we began the rehearsal process.

Our cast continues rehearsals during the fall season, getting ready for the opera premiere on December 1st & 2nd at the Nash Theatre, Raritan Valley Community College, Somerville, NJ.

WHAT YOU CAN DO

Your funds will help produce an overall more immersive theatrical experience; providing original costumes, set design, and props. Most importantly, your generosity goes directly to artist fees for the dancers and singers for all their hard work, dedication and artistry. These artists have given their time and talent to the belief in this work and have trusted the process of creating something from nothing…a new work of art!

Spread the word by sharing our campaign with anyone who would be interested in our mission on Facebook, Instagram, and Indiegogo. 

  • Follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Verlezza-Dance/157483970940558
  • Follow us on Instagram: https://instagram.com/icarus_dance_opera/
  • Come to the shows and join in the performance experience with us! 

With your donation, you will not only reaffirm and support that unique category of collaboration in the fields of music, dance and theatre, but you will be part of providing an artful experience that inspires the desire for freedom for all people.

All donations are fully tax deductible. For more information please feel free to contact us with questions. Verlezza Dance non-profit status made possible by Carlino Corporation. Tax ID 11-3069702. 

THE IMPACT

You can be a part of it from the very beginning and help tell the story.

By helping to bring this work to life, you become a part of a unique theatrical experience where the sister arts of dance, theatre and music are joined, a part of the timeless story of democracy and freedom.

Thank you for your consideration and support to bring Icarus Rising to the stage!

story:
Who We Are

Hello, we’re Silent Faces Theatre! Formed at Goldsmiths University in 2015, we’re a devising company specialising in physical political fooling. As an integrated company of disabled and non-disabled performers, we’re proud to make work that explores the unique possibilities that arise from this collaboration and challenge the assumption that such work is limited in its potential.

We’re incredibly proud to be part of The Pleasance programme with our five-star debut show ‘Follow Suit’ for this year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival, but we need your help!

The Show

‘Follow Suit’ is a madcap frenzy of physical comedy with political bite. 

Welcome to a workplace where ominous authoritarian lightbulbs seemingly dictate your work ethic and profit surges are announced by a voice on high. As four office clowns attempt to find greater and greater distractions from their predicament, Silent Faces discover what very real skeletons could be hiding in the stationery cupboards of some of our largest corporations.

Our debut production gives a darkly comic take on the chaotic world of high finance.

“The failings of big business are exposed without a word of polemic in this subtle, hilarious and ultimately shocking exposé of the world of high finance”

(★★★★★ Everything Theatre)

Follow Suit is a bold discussion and comment on corporate responsibility. In a world where culture is underfunded and big names like BP and Nestle attempt to placate their moral wrongdoings by offering to fund artists’ work, we decided to challenge the responsibilities these corporations shirk, as well as our own conscience and responsibility as consumers. With ‘Follow Suit’, we seek to shake up our audience and make them question the real human consequences of doing big business. As theatremakers, clowns and physical performers, the company was also excited by the prospect of tackling such a massive issue through such an unlikely medium. We successfully smash together tomfoolery and politics with Mr Bean-esque mishaps and tightly synchronised choreography. ‘Follow Suit’ is serious and stupid in equal measure.

 

But Why Edinburgh?

As a young company, Edinburgh Fringe is the greatest platform to get our work seen by huge and varied audiences! Furthermore, the experimental atmosphere that the festival engenders holds a great appeal for us – our work is abstract and, whilst it has been completed, remains a constant work in progress as any devised piece often does. We want to meet new audiences, fellow artists and share our work!

Whilst ‘Follow Suit’ does not discuss issues of disability, the entire process by which it was devised was shaped and affected by the various needs of our company members. The piece is highly physical and certain parts have had to be adapted and tailored to cast members’ needs. In our practice we are proud to explore the unique possibilities that arise from working with the combination of both disabled and non-disabled artists. We are particularly passionate about current ongoing debates surrounding invisible disabilities, including long-term mental health conditions. Our practice is specifically tailored to allow for a supportive, cathartic and rewarding environment for our artists.

We love what we do and feel that it is important that other people affected by disabilities have a chance to see people like them on stage, creating and performing great work.

Through taking our work to one of the world’s largest stages, we hope to show our audiences how impressive the work of an integrated company can be and be part of promoting this diversity within the industry.

 

...It Could Be Risky! 

There is a massive financial risk undertaken by the company in committing to this venture - we are fully prepared to make little or no profit on our investment. However, we could not be more passionate about this show, its message and our position as an integrated company. We believe that the project could be highly beneficial to audiences and to our personal development and are confident that the show has the potential do very well.

 

So, How Can You Help?

We are looking to raise £3000 to bring 'Follow Suit' to Edinburgh in 2017. This sum makes up only a third of our projected expenditure before any wage for our cast and crew. The sum that we raise through your donations will go towards costs including venue hire, marketing, publicity, cast accommodation and travel.

Any donation you can spare, no matter how big or small will help us on our journey to the Fringe. Please check out the gifts and rewards we've got on offer!

We also have the generous support of Goldsmiths University Theatre and Performance department, the New Diorama and The Workshop, Vauxhall in the form of in-kind and greatly discounted rehearsal space. This time and support is invaluable to us as a company as we mount the show for Edinburgh and go through our final stages of development and rehearsal.

We have previously been supported by StopGap and the Integrated Fringe (iF) bursary for Brighton Fringe. We hope to keep building these connections and support, with the aim of becoming self-sufficient and profitable in the next few years.

We totally understand that times is ‘ard and money is tight, so you can also help us by a simple mention on Twitter or Facebook, sharing with those who you think could help or even grabbing a ticket to see the show in Edinburgh!

Thank you for your ongoing support

Silent Faces

xxx

P.S A really easy (and cost-free) way to support us is to sign up to easyfundraising using our unique link.

It's really simple, all you have to do is:
1. Go to https://www.easyfundraising.org.uk/invite/AV3O1N and join for free. 

2. Every time you shop online go to easyfundraising, find the site you want and start shopping

3. When you check out Silent Faces Theatre gets a donation for no extra cost whatsoever!

The shops and sites give easyfundraising a percentage of what you spend and they turn that into a donation, it’s that easy. There’s no catch or hidden charges!

We also get an automatic £1 for every person who signs up with our unique link: http://www.easyfundraising.org.uk/invite/AV3O1N

It couldn't be easier! Spread the word x

When you check out Silent Faces Theatre gets a donation for no extra cost whatsoever!The shops and sites give easyfundraising a percentage of what you spend and they turn that into a donation, it’s that easy. story:
ABOUT GUNNAR:

Gunnar Montana is a Philadelphia-based choreographer and performance artist who's work has appeared in festivals across the region, including the Philadelphia FringeArts Festival and ThinkFest, as well as in several venues across the City.
Infusing movement and visual arts, Gunnar's work refuses to be defined. His artistry as a whole is an array of visual art installations, prop-based choreography, set design, costume design, transformation of atmosphere, and innovative movement, concepts, and ideas.  Gunnar attended The University of the Arts, graduating in 2011 with a BFA in Modern Dance Performance and a profound interest in choreography and creative movement. 

 

MERCHANDISE:

The NEW! Official Gunnar Montana T-Shirt: 

Get the official "GM" Tee! 

 Sizes: Small, Medium, Large, and X-Large 

Unisex Triblend Short-Sleeve T-Shirt

International Shipping Included 

_________________________________________________________

The Official Gunnar Montana Sticker Set:

Get the Gunnar Montana Sticker Set!

Includes 6 circular stickers, size 3"x3". 

*PLUS! THE NEW SECRET SURPRISE "WROUGHTLAND" STICKER!

International shipping included.

_________________________________________________________

Gunnar Montana Show Prints:

Get the Gunnar Montana Show Prints!

Includes 5 signed prints, size 5" x 7" 

*PLUS: THE NEW SECRET SURPRISE "WROUGHTLAND" PRINT!

Chronicle the evolution of Gunnar Montana's work over the course of three years. These prints were specially designed and created by Gunnar to represent and capture the essence of his past five productions.

International shipping included.

________________________________________________________

Gunnar Montana Commemorative Show Posters:

Get the Gunnar Montana Commemorative Show Posters!

Includes 6 mini posters, size 9.5" x 7.5" 

*PLUS: THE NEW "WROUGHTLAND" AND "KINK HAÜS" MINI POSTERS!

Chronicle the evolution of Gunnar Montana's work over the course of four years with these mini show posters! 

International shipping included.

 

RECENT WORK:

"NEVER ENOUGH" premieres one July 11th! New Short Dance Film in collaboration with Venture Filmworks. Directed by Gunnar Montana and starring Jennifer Jones.

For more recent works visit the Gunnar Montana WEBSITE or INSTAGRAM profile. 

 

Common Questions: 

How Will I Make Arrangements For My Perks?
Shortly after making your contribution to Gunnar Montana's Wroughtland campaign, a member of Gunnar's team will contact you to make arrangements to have your merchandise and benefits shipped, and/or your backstage tour scheduled.  

How Soon Will The Perks Be Shipped?

The team at Gunnar Montana Productions is committed to getting swag in your hands within 30 days of your contribution.  We want you to enjoy your perks as soon as possible! 

Where Do I Go With More Questions?

If you have any question or concern, please send us an email at mrgunnarmontana@gmail.com and we will answer as soon as possible!

If you like our project but you can't contribute, please consider 
sharing it using the share buttons under the video with your friends and family. 

This will help us to spread the word! Thank you!

THE NEW SECRET SURPRISE "WROUGHTLAND" STICKER!International shipping included._________________________________________________________Gunnar Montana Show Prints:Get the Gunnar Montana Show Prints!Includes 5 signed prints, size 5" x 7" *PLUS: THE NEW SECRET SURPRISE "WROUGHTLAND" PRINT!Chronicle the evolution of Gunnar Montana's work over the course of three years. These prints were specially designed and created by Gunnar to represent and capture the essence of his past five productions.International shipping included.________________________________________________________Gunnar Montana Commemorative Show Posters:Get the Gunnar Montana Commemorative Show Posters!Includes 6 mini posters, size 9.5" x 7.5" *PLUS: THE NEW "WROUGHTLAND" AND "KINK HAÜS" MINI POSTERS!Chronicle the evolution of Gunnar Montana's work over the course of four years with these mini show posters! International shipping included. RECENT WORK:"NEVER ENOUGH" premieres one July 11th! New Short Dance Film in collaboration with Venture Filmworks. Directed by Gunnar Montana and starring Jennifer Jones.For more recent works visit the Gunnar Montana WEBSITE or INSTAGRAM profile.  Common Questions: How Will I Make Arrangements For My Perks?Shortly after making your contribution to Gunnar Montana's Wroughtland campaign, a member of Gunnar's team will contact you to make arrangements to have your merchandise and benefits shipped, and/or your backstage tour scheduled.  How Soon Will The Perks Be Shipped?The team at Gunnar Montana Productions is committed to getting swag in your hands within 30 days of your contribution.  We want you to enjoy your perks as soon as possible! Where Do I Go With More Questions?If you have any question or concern, please send us an email at mrgunnarmontana@gmail.com and we will answer as soon as possible!If you like our project but you can't contribute, please consider sharing it using the share buttons under the video with your friends and family. This will help us to spread the word! Thank you!

story:
Overview

Pop Punk High is a new musical written by and for everyone who grew up singing and screaming along to blink-182, Sum 41, Green Day, Good Charlotte, Fall Out Boy, Dashboard Confessional, Taking Back Sunday, Jimmy Eat World, and so many more angsty, angsty pop punk bands of the early to mid 2000’s. Somewhere in between parody and loving tribute with a big dose of nostalgia.

Pop Punk High is a takedown of your favorite high school movies and music of yesteryear, but it’s so much more than that – it’s an exploration of the ridiculous tropes and prevailing mindsets that dominated so much of the pop punk landscape, and seeks to understand why amazing female-identifying pop punk performers like Hayley Williams and Laura Jane Grace are often downplayed or forgotten. It’s an incisive critique of the absurd depths of masculinity and “not giving a fuck” that pop punk performers tried to model, and how those attitudes informed a whole generation of listeners. And it’s also the only musical in the world featuring the singing ghost of Avril Lavigne.

CLICK HERE TO HEAR THE TRACK "MY LIFE SUCKS" performed by Ben Lapidus in Pop Punk High.

What are people saying about Pop Punk High? Here are some snippets from our reviews of our previous run at the PIT Loft:

 

“Musically, the show hits the parody nail directly on the head. If the lyrics weren't so damned funny, you could easily mistake these tracks for an actual Blink 182 album.”

 

“What Cook and his crew have created here is explosively good.”

 

“I left this show and immediately wanted to watch it again.”

 

“[The] one-liners are savage, [the] dialogue is to both kill and die for, and [the] understanding of the pop-punk milieu is doctorate grade. I haven't laughed this much at the PIT since the first time I saw Puffs there… and look where that show ended up.”

All quotes from Thomas Burns Scully writing for Popdust.

 

Who We Are

Felicia Lobo, Director

Felicia Lobo is a Brooklyn based director who specializes in horror and fantastical theatre. Recent projects include High School Coven (Corkscrew Festival), Suburban Nightmare (workshop with Insomnium Theatre Company), Wunderkammer (reading with Pipeline Theatre Company), BB's Inferno (PIT Striker), and Rubiella: A Ghost Story (Pipeline Theatre Company). Outside of her theatre work, Felicia is the front woman of QWAM, a local punk band. BFA: NYU Tisch Drama. www.FeliciaLobo.com

Ben Lapidus, Writer/Audio Designer/Band Leader

Ben Lapidus is a songwriter, performer, and sound engineer based in NYC. He stars in and wrote the music/lyrics for Pop Punk High – A Pop Punk Musical. He is the lead singer/songwriter for the the alternative band Ambler, and the skate-punk band Kill Your Friends. His company Lapidus Audio creates original music and sound for film and stage. Ben holds a BFA in Recorded Music from the The Clive Davis Institute at NYU Tisch.

Anderson Cook, Writer/Producer

Anderson Cook is a playwright and lyricist.  Anderson’s musicals co-written (book & lyrics) with Amanda D'Archangelis  include The Disembodied Hand That Fisted Everyone to Death - the Musical!,  produced at the PIT, the Reckless Theatre, and the Boston Conservatory, and Blatantly Blaine, which was listed as one of the "Best Things to See This Week" by Time Out NY.  The Disembodied Hand… will appear at Dad’s Garage in Atlanta and Morta Hassen Theatrics in Stockholm, Sweden, next season. He and Amanda are the winners of the 2017 NMI New Voices Contest, sponsored by Walt Disney Imagineering. His plays include Curiosity Box, Dog Murder Variations, The Origen of Love, and The Roof Play. They have been seen at venues such as the Lee Strasburg Institute, Dixon Place, the San Diego Fringe, the Secret Theatre, and more.

He holds a BFA in Dramatic Writing from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, where he studied under Lucas Hnath, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, Peter Parnell, Nicky Silver, and Suzan-Lori Parks. He is in his second year of pursuing an MFA in Dramatic Writing from Carnegie Mellon University under Rob Handel.

Anderson is currently working on a commissioned musical adaptation of young adult novel FAT KID RULES THE WORLD with Amanda D'Archangelis and Ben Lapidus, as well as a commissioned original play from producer Brian Spector and Keaka Productions.

Carly Oscar, General Manager

Carly Oscar is a New York based creative with a passion for producing and performing comedy in all mediums. She's worked as a producer on thirteen short films, five indie music videos, and two theatrical productions including The Disembodied Hand That Fisted Everyone To Death - the Musical! (The PIT, Reckless Theatre) for which she was an original cast member. Over the past year she's worked for the Weinstein Company, The New Yorker, and Late Night with Seth Meyers. Outside of school, she works with HeadGum Podcast Network and is a member of the Producer's Guild of America student program. She is currently in her senior year at NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts completing a BFA in Film & Television Production.

What We Need

There’s no beating around the bush – Pop Punk High is absolutely crazy. From an 18-foot expanding fake phallus, to magical skateboards, and a strong affinity for obscenity, the show never ceases to shock and delight. Written by a former pop punk local celebrity and directed by the frontwoman of Queen With a Megaphone, an active punk band in New York City, the show has deep roots in a love for pop punk culture and all that it entails.

 

We’ve had two previous runs with this show in theatre spaces that precluded us from presenting the show as we really wanted; with a live, loud, legit, pop punk band. We’ve found the perfect venue at the Parkside Lounge, a historic one-hundred-and-six year old bar on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that has seen thousands of bands of all stripes come through as well as four theatre pieces that have been reviewed by the New York Times. We hope to be the fifth, but in order to do so, we need your help.

 

We need money in order to build sets, props, pay our cast and crew and design teams, and pay for the venue. A full breakdown of our budget can be viewed below. At this point, our production team cumulatively has over ten independently-produced shows under our belt, so we are confident in our ability to effectively and efficiently use all the money raised to make the show the best it can be while still making sure everyone working on the project is compensated fairly. This show will be performing weekly for eight weeks, and this budget is the absolute barebones that we need in order to create a successful production.

 

 

If you can donate, every little bit helps! We have tons of high-quality, awesome merchandise to receive as a perk. If not, you can help us by sending the link to our opening number to one of your friends and telling them that you absolutely have to go see this awesome new pop punk musical about all your favorite things from middle school!

 

Thanks so much, and god bless pop punk.

story:
WHO WE ARE?

We are young group of theatre makers from Zimbabwe, South Africa, Sweden and U.S. who are interested in telling untold stories and presenting performances that question mainstream norms in our society. We strive for artistic excellence through hard and believe in the strength of collaboration and cultural exchange by bringing together our diverse artistic experiences to produce exciting, thought provoking theatre.

In this project, we are working as a collaborative, towards our goal – to open up dialogue about race and gender relations by presenting a theatrical performance a diverse audience at the Harare International Festival of the Arts (HIFA) in May 2017. HIFA is a 6-day annual festival in Harare, Zimbabwe that showcases the very best of local, regional and international arts and culture.


WHY THE INCIDENT?

The Incident is a poignant theatrical performance about whether you are ready to stand up for your values when the stakes are raised. Are we prepared to and can we change our behaviors in order to understand others? The play makes the audience reflect over how we are shaped by our experiences including cultural and ethnic backgrounds, and how it influences how we see the world and how we treat people that are different from us.
 

IMPACT

We believe that theatre can be a vehicle for dialogue and social change. Through the play, we want to open-up a dialogue about race and gender relations - an important topic that people often find it difficult to talk about. We will have post-show discussions after each performance and ask for feedback from the audience on the topics raised in the performance. HIFA is the highlight of the Zimbabwean arts scene and we are looking forward to bringing this highly relevant performance to the Zimbabwean and international audience. Taking this performance to HIFA is an opportunity for us to showcase our work and get feedback from the audience so that we improve the performance and continue to perform it in other locations.


WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

It takes a community of artists (writer, dramaturg, project manager, director, actors, light & sound designer, costume designers, stage manager, etc.) to put up a good production and we are currently looking for funds to cover transport, rehearsal space and accommodation for our team during our 3-week long rehearsal period. While we have got some funding we really need your support to be able to bring this relevant production to the HIFA Festival in Zimbabwe in May, 2017. Your contribution will go the fundamental administration and production costs.

If you contribute:

$US10 – You will receive free weekly updates to your e-mail from the production (voluntary)
$US20 – Your name will appear in the ‘thank you’ section on our website and social media (voluntary)
$US50 – All of the above + You will get thank you message from the Artistic Team and your your name will appear in the production program
$US100 -  All of the above + You will get personal message from the Artistic Team and your name will appear in the production program and on our website and social media.
$US500 – All of the above + A free copy of a recording of the performance

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We understand that not everyone is able to donate. However, you can still contribute by:

  • Sharing our campaign on Social Media, Facebook and Instagram and by word of mouth to your friends, family and anyone you think might be interested in supporting us
  • Being an audience member at one of our shows
  • Use the #hashtag #TheIncident #HIFA2017

story:
Welcome to Cabaret Sauvignon’s Campaign for “The Mysterious A Cappella Murder Cabaret!”

Cabaret Sauvignon is a Jersey City based, all female a cappella group, and this spring we took our act to a new level:We created a REAL SHOW!!

What is "The Mysterious A Cappella Murder Cabaret?"

In this reality-theater tale, four female vocalists meet in fierce competition...surmount backstage backstabs…form the a cappella group Cabaret Sauvignon…and allegedly MURDER their manager!!!

And our "Murder Cabaret" was just accepted into the Midtown International Theatre Festival!!! 

Thursday, July 30th at 8 PM : https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe/10017473

Sunday, August 2nd at 1 PM : https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe.c/10012324 

at The Davenport Theatre Black Box Stage 

354 West 45th Street between 8th & 9th Ave

Starring Alexandra Pflaster as Rose Catavino, Amanda Levie as Ruby Cabernet, Amy Elise as Shiraz Chelois and Elena Zazanis as Roussanne Rhone.

Why Do We Need to Raise Funds?

To bring our Murder Cabaret to life, we need $2000 to cover:

  • Director
  • Wireless Microphones
  • Wardrobe
  • Props
  • Sheet Music, Tracks & Sound Effects
  • Transportation
  • Marketing Materials

And while the Midtown International Theatre Festival will present the first run of “The Mysterious A Cappella Murder Cabaret,” the majority of this funding will be invested in reusable assets for future performances on the long horizon, e.g. microphones, wardrobe, props, etc.

Who Are We?

For over two years, Cabaret Sauvignon has been covering your favorite tunes from Doo Wop to Miley Cyrus, often singing them at the same time! In addition to performing at restaurants, bars and private parties, we do tons of fundraisers and outreach for arts organizations, schools and nursing homes…we even performed to benefit pediatric cancer research in the Toshiba building – you know, where the ball drops every New Year’s Eve!!

Thank You

We really appreciate your interest, and we hope you can contribute to our campaign financially and/or by putting out the word about “The Mysterious A Cappella Murder Cabaret” to as many people, in as many forms and as frequently as possible. Indiegogo’s share tools make it easy so if you have a sec, you can buzz about it right now!

story:
Who is  The New Renaissance Theatre Company, and what is The Unrehearsed Shakespeare Project?

The New Renaissance Theatre Company is a 501(c)(3) non-profit whose mission is to illuminate the joy and passion captured in the best of live theatre by connecting the classic to the contemporary through ensemble-based development and performance.

It is our goal to create an artistic home for an ensemble of actors and theatre craftsmen. It all begins with The Unrehearsed Shakespeare Project.

USP is dedicated to performing the works of William Shakespeare using the unrehearsed cue script technique in order to expose our community to unique productions that bring the audience and performers together in a way that only theatre can. The unrehearsed cue script technique is based upon the working conditions of Shakespeare's own company, our research and our experience in performing and producing plays using this historically informed practice.

For the past two years, we have toured single productions to parks around the Pittsburgh area, where communities do not always have easy access to quality, free, professional live theatre. This year we are expanding our tour to include two free plays and we are adding at least two new venues!

Announcing our cast for 
A Midsommer Nights Dreame & The Tragedie of Romeo and Juliet
Nick Benninger, Nick Bernstein, Missy Graf, Alyssa LaVacca, Tonya Lynn, Zach Romah, Adam Rutledge, Samantha Sloma, Katie Trupiano, Nick Waller
Directors: Elizabeth Ruelas, Andy Kirtland
Stage Manager: Charlene Jacka
Fight Direction: Tonya Lynn, Adam Rutledge

Notice we don't say who is playing which role. That is because our actors receive several tracks of roles for each play, and we change who performs which roles from show to show. It's always fresh for our audience and our cast!

What can we do with your money?
Did we mention that these performances are FREE? We are asking for $2,000 to help produce this tour. With this help we will be able to:

  • PAY OUR ACTORS
  • COVER THE COST OF TRAVEL AND TRANSPORTATION
  • BUILD OR BUY COSTUMES AND PROPS that can withstand the rigors of touring


What do you get out of it?
The chance to experience advantages and adventures of this unique performance technique first hand, and know that you made it happen. Some levels of giving afford you the chance to do this in style with a reserved place and tasty treats for a performance. Other levels of giving offer the opportunity to receive cue scripts, the tools that our actors use in the preparation and performance of their roles. Your gift could bring us to you for a private performance, or your generosity could sponsor a workshop for a Pittsburgh area school!

Growing and growing...
We acknowledge that we are challenging ourselves by continuing to expand. Our tours have grown for the last two seasons, from two performances of The Comedie of Errors in one park in 2014, to six performances of Much adoe about Nothing  including two performances in Baltimore, MD in 2015. This year we are growing even further by adding a second show and at least two more venues.
Our short history shows that we are able to handle expansion. NRTC's leadership has displayed the ability to tour this type of production successfully. We are able to make connections with organizations that help us get the word out and introduce NRTC to new audiences.

Other ways you can help:
If you are unable to donate directly to our campaign, please help us spread the word about out tour. You are our best advertising! Please use the Indiegogo share tools to tell your friends about this campaign. And most importantly: come out and see a performance with your friends and family!

This year we are expanding our tour to include two free plays and we are adding at least two new venues!Announcing our cast for 
A Midsommer Nights Dreame & The Tragedie of Romeo and Juliet
Nick Benninger, Nick Bernstein, Missy Graf, Alyssa LaVacca, Tonya Lynn, Zach Romah, Adam Rutledge, Samantha Sloma, Katie Trupiano, Nick WallerDirectors: Elizabeth Ruelas, Andy KirtlandStage Manager: Charlene JackaFight Direction: Tonya Lynn, Adam RutledgeNotice we don't say who is playing which role. That is because our actors receive several tracks of roles for each play, and we change who performs which roles from show to show. It's always fresh for our audience and our cast!What can we do with your money?Did we mention that these performances are FREE? We are asking for $2,000 to help produce this tour. With this help we will be able to:
PAY OUR ACTORS
COVER THE COST OF TRAVEL AND TRANSPORTATION
BUILD OR BUY COSTUMES AND PROPS that can withstand the rigors of touring


What do you get out of it?The chance to experience advantages and adventures of this unique performance technique first hand, and know that you made it happen. Some levels of giving afford you the chance to do this in style with a reserved place and tasty treats for a performance. Other levels of giving offer the opportunity to receive cue scripts, the tools that our actors use in the preparation and performance of their roles. Your gift could bring us to you for a private performance, or your generosity could sponsor a workshop for a Pittsburgh area school!
Growing and growing...
We acknowledge that we are challenging ourselves by continuing to expand. Our tours have grown for the last two seasons, from two performances of The Comedie of Errors in one park in 2014, to six performances of Much adoe about Nothing  including two performances in Baltimore, MD in 2015. This year we are growing even further by adding a second show and at least two more venues.Our short history shows that we are able to handle expansion. NRTC's leadership has displayed the ability to tour this type of production successfully. We are able to make connections with organizations that help us get the word out and introduce NRTC to new audiences.Other ways you can help:If you are unable to donate directly to our campaign, please help us spread the word about out tour. You are our best advertising! Please use the Indiegogo share tools to tell your friends about this campaign. And most importantly: come out and see a performance with your friends and family!

story:
This exhilarating multimedia showcase highlights the lives and gifts of Katherine Dunham and Paul Robeson. A truly original theatrical experience for Black History month 2017 created and produced by four collaborating independent artists committed to progressive political theater. The creative team includes Chiquita Camille (Katherine Dunham), Julius Hollingsworth (Paul Robeson), Robert Gonzalez (stage manger), and Rico Speight (producer/director/writer). We have worked together before on previous Off Broadway productions, and in this campaign, we have decided to take destiny into our own hands and do something crazy (in a good way)!  In this campaign we are reaching out to family, friends and comrades for support to make this idea come alive. We have an amazing location with its own significant pedigree: the Gene Frankel Theatre (GFT) in New York’s East Village has a history of political theatrical performances. Established in 1949 by actor/director Gene Frankel, the GFT premiered Jean Genet's "The Blacks" in New York in 1961 starring James Earl Jones and Cicely Tyson.
 

What We NEED : 

Our immediate goal is $14,000 to pay upfront expenses to mount the play for one week in February 2017.  We are working on a shoe-string budget and whatever we raise in this campaign will pay for sets, lights, costumes, audio-visuals, music, actors’ salaries, fees for the creative team, and publicity. We have already raised $5,000 to pay for the theater. 

 

Why do We NEED YOU? 

Because every single ounce of your support will carry us across the miles from here to opening night. You can support us by making a generous pledge to our campaign.  You can also help us spread the word! Please share this link with all of your friends!! Please like our campaign and send us encouraging comments.  Ask questions!  Buy tickets now and come see any one of our nine shows! We cannot do this without you!

story:
THE COMPANY
My name is Franklin L. West. I have served as Managing Director of Redbone Entertainment and Development for over twenty years. Our dual objective has been to create productions that entertain and inspire while providing platforms and opportunities for legendary performers and emerging artists to continually challenge their talents and energies, creating a unique environment that offers growth for all.

                                                 THE PROPERTY
                                                   "Just One Bite"
 An adaptation of the biblical creation set in the musical rhymes of a new    generation.

                                                        Summary
I AM, the greatest MC of all time raps out a new world. Creating the garden, Adam and Eve, a three headed snake and a talking tree. Pleased with the masterpiece of Eden. I am gives Adam and Eve all that it offers except the tree of knowledge and it's fruit. Unfortunately they are seduced by the snake and decide to ignore the one and only command. Defiantly they eat the precious fruit of good and evil. I AM sends Adam and Eve into the future of the world they have created. They go on a whirlwind journey to find the five earthly truths and two heavenly truths of life...

                                                         THE GOAL
To produce theatrical showcase (2 performances only) with finished script, music scored with arrangements, complete cast, full costumes, Backdrops (Sets), choreography, staging and blocking in a venue that possesses multi-media capability.

                                                          THE PLAN

The book and lyrics were created and developed as a rock concert to attract the interest and talent of performing/recording artists of the music industry to the lead roles. New arrangements will blend hot rocking chords with flirtatious melodies.
Costumes by Pauline Barker and wardrobe and jewelry by Phil Harris for leads will be designed in celebration of the ever evolving  energies of the rock experience.

                                                  WHERE ARE WE NOW
Four years of hard work and constant attention has produced a finished script, twenty story boards (By hand), completed lyrics and music, (Which is presently being arranged with great emphasis on past and present musical trends that enjoyed both massive popularity and huge commercial success), one third of the costumes have been delivered and one of five hand painted backdrops has been delivered (Eden) and the second(Club Desire) is in the works

VISIT: reboneentertainment.biz  TO VIEW COSTUMES VIDEO, LISTEN TO SOUNDTRACK AND LEARN MORE ABOUT THE PRODUCTION


                                                         WHAT IS NEEDED
THEATER  (2 days)                                                                                 15,000
Tech crew                                                                                                    5,000
Stage Director                                                                                            5,000
Lead Performers (3)                                                                                 9,000
2nd Leads (3)                                                                                             4,500
3rd Leads (6)                                                                                              6,000
Production Stage Manager                                                                     3,000
Production assistant                                                                                 1,000


 MUSIC DIRECTOR                                                                                   3,000
Musicians                                                                                                    5,000
ARRANGER                                                                                                 7,500

LIGHTING DESIGNER                                                                              3,000
Artist fir backdrops                                                                                   5,000
Art projectionist                                                                                         1,000

CHOREOGRAPHER                                                                                  5,000
Choreography/staging supervisor                                                        2,000
Singers (5)                                                                                                  5,000
Dancers (6)                                                                                                6,000

Costume Designer                                                                                    3,000
Seamstress                                                                                                3,000

PRODUCTION MANAGER                                                                       5,000
Rehearsal Space                                                                                       2,000
Office assistant                                                                                          3,000
Office expenses                                                                                          1,000
Invitations                                                                                                    2,000
Journal layout/print                                                                                  5,000
Gift bags (300)                                                                                          3,000
Video photographer                                                                                  1,000

Reception Rental                                                                                     10,000
Catering                                                                                                       7,000

Miscellaneous                                                                                            5,000
 




All contributions will be used to achieve the highest level of production.

                                                 

  

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
With your help, the Harmonia Opera Company will proudly present the World Premiere of "ECHOES OF THOUSAND CRANES" in NYC on April 12, 2013.

This music and drama is inspired by the true story of Sadako Sasaki.  Sadako, a young Japanese girl, died of leukemia at the age of 12 as a direct result of the atom bomb.  This disease was known in Japan as the atom bomb disease.  She had a dream... to make 1000 Golden Paper Cranes.  Ancient Japanese legend contends whoever folds one thousand origami cranes, will be granted a wish by the gods.  Sadako's wish... to live.  At the time of her death, she had folded 644 cranes.  Her family and friends folded the remainder to make 1000 origami cranes.  Sadako was buried with them.

The script is written by Emiko Iinuma, Founder and President of the Harmonia Opera Company, and the music is provided by Ric Cherwin, Kuni Mikami, and Tsubasa Matsuda.  This opera has been created for the goal of WORLD PEACE AND LOVE.  It is my dream to launch the World Premiere of "ECHOES OF THOUSAND CRANES" in honor of my family. After this world premiere, it is my hope this story will be told as a future production on Broadway, and all over the world.

All funds will be used for production costs.

I will be very grateful if you would help us.  Thank you and I hope you will be a part of the World Premiere of "ECHOES OF THOUSAND CRANES".

 

Emiko Iinuma

Founder and President

Harmonia Opera Conpany

 

The Harmonia Opera Company is the only Japanese Opera Company in the United States.  It’s purpose is to promote artistic bonds between Japan and the U.S.  In 2011 & 2012 Harmonia Opera had "Benefit Fundraising Concerts for Victims of Japan's Earthquake and Tsunami and for 150 Cats & 60 Dogs who lost their owners.

The Harmonia Opera Company is a recipient of:

2011  Grant Award from the NYC Department of Cultural Affairs

2011  5 Gold Stars Award from The Kennedy Center

2010  NJ Legislature Resolution Award from Senator Kevin Toole, and Senator Loretta Weinberg

2008  Foreign Minister's Award from the Japanese Government
