story:
A NIGHT OF DEADLY SERIOUS COMEDIES

Ionesco’s THE FUTURE IS IN EGGS
Pirandello’s SICILIAN LIMES

Directed by Joseph Hendel
Produced by Lauren Rayner Productions

Please help us with finishing funding for these oft-forgot works so we can continue to collaborate for our next show. In the fall we are hoping to apply for a residency for an original horror/satire sketch comedy show written by Joe H. and Alex Mills, a young New York City playwright and actor. You are CRUCIAL to making this happen! 

Check out all of our exciting perks to see how you can be involved: from partying with our artists at the donor celebration on the actual set of the show, to key lime pies, to a night on the town to dinner and show with the producers!

SYNOPSIS
 Eugene Ionesco's The Future is in Eggs and Luigi Pirandello's Sicilian Limes are two forgotten modernist plays that are incredibly relevant in an age of economic scarcity, political pessimism, and cultural disaffection. Through strong improvisational-based acting and a cutting-edge use of technology, this production will unite the stylistically disparate one-acts into a coherent expression of hopeful defiance, one that entertains while simultaneously challenging the audience's perceptions about love, money, and personal fulfillment.
 
WHY WE NEED FUNDS TO MAKE THIS PROJECT HAPPEN
We seek your generous support to help with the following:
 
*Publicity and expanding outreach to the community
*Covering the rental of technical equipment and insurance costs
*Theatre rental cost for 2 weeks
*Materials to realize ambitious set, costumes, lighting, and prop design (over 300 eggs!)
*Creating live-able stipends for our creative artists
*Administrative costs (show photographer, programs, transportation for the set)
 
HOW TO MAKE AN IMPACT

We need one FINAL PUSH to make this project happen so we can successfully open on June 17 and compensate our creative artists! Our current goal is to raise $4,000 by the time we finish our second weekend of the show. The next step for us will be to build on the momentum from this production and mount an ORIGINAL PRODUCTION in the Fall. Please give whatever you can, anything and everything will help us on this journey. 

Donations are being accepted here through IndieGoGo and since this a not-for-profit production and our producer, Lauren Rayner, is a fiscally sponsored project with Fractured Atlas, your donation will be tax-deductible. If you would like to make a donation by check instead of online with a credit card, please make checks payable to ‘Fractured Atlas’ with ‘Lauren Rayner’ in the memo line. Send all checks to Lauren Rayner, 56 Morton St. #3R New York, NY 10014
 
Questions? Feel free to contact > info@laurenrayner.com
 
For more info, check out the official website: www.laurenrayner.com/deadlyseriouscomedies

THE TEAM

The company includes:

Adam Hocherman
Bradley Sumner
Brendan Sokler
Frankie Johnson
Grace Folsom
Joel Malazita
Lisa Hickman
Meaghan Sloane
Skylar Saltz

The creative team includes:

Sound by Nick Engel
Sets by Charlie Gaidica
Lights by Evan Gannon
Costumes by Tara Weber
Props by Drew Vanderburg & Elinor Monroe
Stage Manager, Samantha Gallardo
Assistant Stage Manager, Michelle Kleber
Audio Technology by ADEV Inc.
Directed & Co-Produced by Joseph Hendel
Produced by Lauren Rayner

story:
UPDATE: Thank you so much for your support, everyone! Your contributions, Tweets, Tumblr posts, LiveJournal entries, and other forms of support has been phenomenal, and I am deeply touched by how much this project means to you.

If you'd like to donate but ran out of time, you still have a chance. Just click on this link to contribute directly via the Fractured Atlas website.

I look forward to sharing news and updates for Tulpa, or Anne&Me in 2012. For now, please enjoy the I Am Theatre video I made with Theatre Communications Group (TCG) by heading over to the Gallery tab.

Thank you so, so much.

Part whimsical fantasy, part realist drama, part gothic horror, Tulpa, or Anne&Me tells the story of a lonely artist whose world gets turned upside down when Anne Hathaway crawls out of her TV. As their friendship blossoms, they examine how race impacts the way they understand and relate to each other. At the same time, they struggle to connect across racial barriers to find out who they can really be to one another.


WHY TULPA, OR ANNE&ME?

Earlier this year, I wrote and produced a play called Tulpa, or Anne&Me that debuted at the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity.


Since that first production, friends, family, fellow artists, and audience members have talked about how much Tulpa means to them and asked about whatï¿½s next for Tulpa, or Anne&Me. As an artist, it's wonderful to see how something you created has touched people in deep places and led to powerful moments of growth and healing. I feel a real responsibility to take this piece as far as I can and bring it to as many places as I can where people want and need to see it.


I am raising $3,000 to cover production expenses for the 2012 performance of Tulpa, or Anne&Me in mid-late April 2012. If only 60 people contribute just $50 each, I can reach that goal. If only 60 people contribute just $50 each, Tulpa, or Anne&Me will have another chance to do what it's meant to do -- pave the way for healing and transformation in our lives, relationships, and communities. But no matter how much you choose to give, you will be doing more than putting a story on a stage . . . you will be creating an opportunity to honor of those of us whose lives have been and will be touched by Tulpa, or Anne&Me.


When you make a secure, tax-deductible donation to this project, you will receive a perk depending on the amount you contribute. You can donate it all at once or spread it out over several contributions. It's all based on the total amount you give.


WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

Your generous contribution will go toward production expenses for the April 2012 production of Tulpa, or Anne&Me. This includes things like:

  • paying a stipend to cast and crew
  • renting rehearsal space
  • printing scripts for the cast and crew
  • purchasing materials for the set
  • buying or renting props and costumes
  • marketing, publicity, and advertising
  • a little money set aside for emergency purchases

HOW DID TULPA, OR ANNE&ME GET HERE?

Tulpa, or Anne&Me began as a mental exercise on LiveJournal that tried to imagine new ways to talk about race. What began as snippets of dialogue evolved into a story that soon became a full-length play. The first draft led to a reading at the Cell Theatre's Blackboard Play Reading series, followed by 2 staged readings at WOW Cafe Theater. A brief encounter with Anne Hathaway and a staged reading later, Tulpa, or Anne&Me has made its debut at the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity.


Will you make a contribution and be part of Tulpa's story?


WHAT ELSE CAN YOU DO TO HELP TULPA, OR ANNE&ME?

Spread the word! Share this link with your friends, family, and co-workers. Talk about how much this project means to you and ask them to make a donation. Every little bit helps.
story_txt:
UPDATE: Thank you so much for your support, everyone! Your contributions, Tweets, Tumblr posts, LiveJournal entries, and other forms of support has been phenomenal, and I am deeply touched by how much this project means to you.If you'd like to donate but ran out of time, you still have a chance. Just click on this link to contribute directly via the Fractured Atlas website.I look forward to sharing news and updates for Tulpa, or Anne&Me in 2012. For now, please enjoy the I Am Theatre video I made with Theatre Communications Group (TCG) by heading over to the Gallery tab.Thank you so, so much.
Part whimsical fantasy, part realist drama, part gothic horror, Tulpa, or Anne&Me tells the story of a lonely artist whose world gets turned upside down when Anne Hathaway crawls out of her TV. As their friendship blossoms, they examine how race impacts the way they understand and relate to each other. At the same time, they struggle to connect across racial barriers to find out who they can really be to one another.



WHY TULPA, OR ANNE&ME?
Earlier this year, I wrote and produced a play called Tulpa, or Anne&Me that debuted at the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity.


Since that first production, friends, family, fellow artists, and audience members have talked about how much Tulpa means to them and asked about whatï¿½s next for Tulpa, or Anne&Me. As an artist, it's wonderful to see how something you created has touched people in deep places and led to powerful moments of growth and healing. I feel a real responsibility to take this piece as far as I can and bring it to as many places as I can where people want and need to see it.

I am raising $3,000 to cover production expenses for the 2012 performance of Tulpa, or Anne&Me in mid-late April 2012. If only 60 people contribute just $50 each, I can reach that goal. If only 60 people contribute just $50 each, Tulpa, or Anne&Me will have another chance to do what it's meant to do -- pave the way for healing and transformation in our lives, relationships, and communities. But no matter how much you choose to give, you will be doing more than putting a story on a stage . . . you will be creating an opportunity to honor of those of us whose lives have been and will be touched by Tulpa, or Anne&Me.

When you make a secure, tax-deductible donation to this project, you will receive a perk depending on the amount you contribute. You can donate it all at once or spread it out over several contributions. It's all based on the total amount you give.

WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

Your generous contribution will go toward production expenses for the April 2012 production of Tulpa, or Anne&Me. This includes things like:


paying a stipend to cast and crew
renting rehearsal space
printing scripts for the cast and crew
purchasing materials for the set
buying or renting props and costumes


marketing, publicity, and advertising
a little money set aside for emergency purchases


HOW DID TULPA, OR ANNE&ME GET HERE?

Tulpa, or Anne&Me began as a mental exercise on LiveJournal that tried to imagine new ways to talk about race. What began as snippets of dialogue evolved into a story that soon became a full-length play. The first draft led to a reading at the Cell Theatre's Blackboard Play Reading series, followed by 2 staged readings at WOW Cafe Theater. A brief encounter with Anne Hathaway and a staged reading later, Tulpa, or Anne&Me has made its debut at the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity.

Spread the word! Share this link with your friends, family, and co-workers. Talk about how much this project means to you and ask them to make a donation. Every little bit helps.

story:
Our Indiegogo campaign has now come to an end - however, you can read about Glorious and buy a copy of the project publication: http://www.rajnishah.com/dear-stranger-i-love-you

THANK YOU!

MakingGlorious

From 2009 to 2012, Rajni Shah Projects are creating Glorious - a haunting and unusual new musical that will be completely reinvented for every location, as members of the local community and local musicians work with Rajni and her collaborators to create each event.

As part of this project composers Ben and Max Ringham are creating a musical songbook – a completely new musical score that will be freshly arranged with musical director Suzie Shrubb for local musicians at each location, effectively being re-imagined for each show as Glorious travels across the UK and Europe.

In the meantime, costume designer Lucille Acevedo-Jones is building an intricate and visually awesome costume, incorporating movement and light, and that will quite literally root into the stage.

And throughout the whole process – as we work with local people and local musicians at each location – writer Mary Paterson will be collecting thoughts, souvenirs, images and memories to create the Glorious Storybook, a beautiful professionally-made book creatively documenting the entire Glorious journey.


Why this feels important

 

We’re so excited about this project - and hope you will be too. Glorious is a response to what we’re all feeling these days - fear about the future, a sense that we can’t make a difference, and a horrible feeling that we’ve really screwed up the world once and for all.

Through making Glorious, we wanted to create something really beautiful that a lot of people can be involved with - something that embraces that sense of an unknown future, and that exposes both the fear and the hope of the journey we are making right now as a society.

Gloriouswill be a musical that is defined by the stories of the people who have made it - not just Rajni and her collaborators, but new local musicians and performers who will take part and reshape it each time it's performed. And you can be involved too!


What you can do to help make Glorious great!

With your help we hope to raise funds to complete the music by the preview performance of Glorious on February 26th 2011 as part of NottDance in Nottingham. Glorious will then premiere at the Barbican in London as part of Spill Festival in April 2011, before travelling to eight other UK and European locations until October 2012. Your donation means that Glorious will impact on the greatest number of people, both musicians and residents in each place we perform, as well as our online network of support that makes it possible for people to stay in touch with the project even when we're not in town.

Your support will not only help us create Glorious, but will also make you part of the Glorious community both figuratively and literally – as you gain access to our Glorious People social network where you can watch the making process unfold and contribute your own ideas. If you’re very, very supportive you can even be named in a song! Take a look at the perks on the right for more information.

 

Other ways you can help

 

Please contribute today – we appreciate all donations, and we know you’re giving what you can.

 If you would like to find out more about Glorious or Rajni Shah Projects visit our website or join our Facebook page.And if you live in one of the tour locations – Bristol, Nottingham, London, Newcastle and others to be confirmed soon – or know someone that does, then please get in touch by coming to one of our performances. 

 

Thank you in advance for your support – all contributions will be kindly received and acknowledged in the Glorious Storybook.

Creative Team: Lucille Acevedo-Jones, Lucy Cash, Karen Christopher, Sheila Ghelani, Mary Paterson, Ben & Max Ringham, Rajni Shah and Chahine Yavroyan

Project Director: Helena Suarez

Technical Director: Steve Wald, with Marty Langthorne

Musical Director: Suzie Shrubb

Documentation (film): Becky Edmunds

Producer: Rajni Shah

 

Video images by: Lucille Acevedo-Jones, Magnus Arrevad, Lucy Cash, Theron Schmidt & Manuel Vason

 

Glorious is commissioned by SPILL Festival 2011 at the Barbican, London. Co-commissioned by Live at LICA (Nuffield Theatre Lancaster), Wunderbar festival and InBetween Time Productions

Glorious is supported by Arts Council England, Paul Hamlyn Foundation, Jerwood Charitable Foundation, PRS for Music Foundation, Royal Victoria Hall Foundation and you!

story:
Our Story

Drama of Works presents Leakey's Ladies, a multidisciplinary exploration of three extraordinary women and the apes they followed, loved and fought for. Three short plays have been commissioned and weaved together to highlight Jane Goodall, Dian Fossey and Birute Galdikas's struggles, achievements and relationships as they sought to understand and empathize with their cousins: the chimpanzee, gorilla and orangutan. The text, paired with innovative puppet design, original music and tiered staging will create a landmark theater experience crafted by over 10 professional theater women.


The Impact

The piece will receive its WORLD PREMIERE at Dixon Place in January of 2012, but we need your help to make this happen. We have been so fortunate to have the support of The Jim Henson Foundation and the Puffin Foundation but that was for the over 2-year developmental process. Now we need your help to really bring the full final production to life!


From playwright Erin Courtney: "This play is important now because as our world changes, politically, environmentally, technologically, we need to practice the skills of patient observation in order to "see" what is happening now, understand it, and interact with the world from an informed place."


From playwright Crystal Skillman: "This play is important now because the apes still suffer. The studies have enlightened so many but so many of the mass populace refuses to engage with a sustainable relationship to nature, find our place in it."


From playwright Rachel Hoeffel: "Because the life's work of these three women continues.  People who see this and are compelled by these stories and by the apes can aid in their much needed conservation... Because telling the stories of women in science benefits our culture... Because the stories of of intrepid spirits who break rules, make discoveries, subvert expectations and experience their failures and success with perseverance and passion are compelling and inspiring."

What We Need & What You Get

Every little bit counts...


A piece of really good fake ape fur could run us about $12 a yard, so won't you please donate $25 to get us two? That could be enough for one whole baby ape puppet!

We feel strongly about paying our actors and designers. A donation of $250 will get us well on our way to doing that!

One $500 donation could pay completely for our marketing costs! And really, what's the point of putting up a show if no one comes?!?


We have loads of awesome perks, including discounted tickets to the show, but really the main reward is knowing that you helped a groundbreaking, important piece of theater get off the ground!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you really want to help above and beyond - please spread the word by forwarding this campaign on to your friends, family and neighbors.


Also - COME SEE THE SHOW! Email Gretchen (at gretchen@dramaofworks.com) and get on the mailing list. So, even if you can't help now please come out and support us once we're in the theater!


LEAKEY'S LADIES

Written by:
Erin Courtney (JANE)
Rachel Hoeffel (BIRUTE)
Crystal Skillman (DIAN)

Directed and designed by Gretchen Van Lente
Assistant direction by Molly Kohl
Ape puppets and masks by David Valentine
Original music by Stephanie Richards
Lighting by Jeanette Yew

Sound by Kate Brown

Design assistance by James Walton
Publicity by Lanie Zipoy

WITH:
Meghan Williams as Jane Goodall
Tatiana Pavela as Dian Fossey
Amy Carrigan as Birute Galdikas
Scott Weber as Louis Leakey
Molly Kohl as Kelly

Patrick Shearer as Rod/Bob/Hugo

Puppeteered by Joseph Garner, Emily Hartford, Melissa Mendez and Julia Smith


Preview: January 12th at 7:30pm
$10 in advance, $12 at door
Performances: Fridays & Saturdays Jan 13th - Feb 4th at 7:30pm
$16 in advance, $20 at door
Students/seniors, $12

DIXON PLACE
161A Chrystie Street
http://www.dixonplace.org/

story:
From the original Terror of Church Street and Halloween Horror Nights, the reigning Father of Halloween in Asia, Alan Ostrander and his team of Theatrical Horror Experts are creating Orlando's Newest, Most Fatal Attraction!  Alan and his team have spent the last 13 years creating, designing, and directing the largest Halloween event in Asia -- Ocean Park Halloween Bash.  Now, the FrightMaster is back, home where his roots are, assembling his minions to create the Ultimate Scream Team this Halloween Season!

The Majestic Event Center (MEC) invited AEOStudios (AEO) to build a haunted house on their property.  In the arrangement, MEC administers food and beverage sales and other spaces on the property for event-related functions, while AEO produces and operates the attraction and event merchandising.  The revenue generated stays within their respective group.

We have a home, we have our wicked dreams, but we need you to help us make our Nightmares come true!!!

In order to get what you want, you have to leave a bit of yourself behind....

We are well underway with raising the majority of funding for the event...But, we still have a long way to go!  Here is how you can help be a part of this Frightening project:

  • To continue our progress, we need a total of $35,000.  We hope to raise a quarter of it here.  Monies raised through Indiegogo go towards the initial design and buildout stages and insurance.
  • Perks begin with a $25 sacrifice to us.
  • If we are unable to raise the full amount here, we will continue to honor the perks, and we will continue with other fundraising efforts. 

Why?

Your contribution will make a difference in Orlando in many ways:

  • It's time that Orlando had a Terror On Church Street-esque Haunt that is reasonably priced, with good entertainment value, and is centrally located.
  • Our Ultimate Scream Team has a combined 150 years in event management/creation.
  • Funding will make Nightmares a frightening reality, so we can start creating scary goodness for our guests.
  • As Orlando is a Film/TV/Theatre school hub, the funding we get will help us hire and pay Student Interns, who will be getting real world experience that they won't necessarily get in class.

Risks & Obstacles

A Haunted House usually takes 3-4 years to show a profit, as the budget for the first two years are tied up in equipment, set building and venue costs.  We have taken steps to ensure that monies raised will be used prudently and wisely.

  • Our design and creative team actively share resources and utilize those for the needs of the operation.
  • The minions are THAT passionate and committed to the vision that Alan and the team have, they all agree on the deferred/low/slow compensation concept for their efforts, as it frees up much needed capital for more important things, like building the haunt and getting event insurance. 
  • Through our networks. we have obtained equipment and supplies for free or minimal cost, rather than purchasing outright or renting equipment.
  • Finally, MEC has given us the space to use to build the haunt, free of charge, and is assisting with some support staff and most importantly, marketing through their existing media network.
To put it in perspective:

$1 can get us 100 old-school type flyers (black on basic copy paper)
$5 can get us postage to mail 13 promo postcards, a roll of duct tape, or a bag of hot glue sticks.
$10 pays for a box of nails, a gallon of cheap paint, or 3 cases of water to keep the scare actors hydrated for the night.
$20 pays for a sheet of plywood, or 11 yards of erosion cloth.
$25 pays for printing up tickets or a small fire extinguisher.
$30 can get us 1000 promo postcards printed up.
$50 can help us get snacks to keep the scare actors, the tech crew and the staff going throughout the night.
$100 can get us a basic makeup kit for one makeup artist for the whole month of October or a very basic low-tech CCTV system.
$250 can help us get 5 gallons of flame retardant that we have to spray everything in the house to comply with fire codes.
$500 can help us air a commercial on a non-premium channel for a week.
$1000 can get us a fog machine.
$5000 can help us pay for liability insurance for the entire run of the house.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that people may not be able to afford to give to our pursuit of terror, but here's other ways you can help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign, via relevant social media (ie Facebook and Twitter).
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • And if you want to be personally involved, please let us know! We can use volunteers for things like set building/buildout, support staff, and whatever the spirits think we need.

The Majestic....  A once noble and regal establishment where all the world's elite would gather.  Now, it's a home to a gathering of another kind -- Spirits, Evil, Dementia and Madness!!!  Many a person's worst nightmares and fears,       WAITING FOR YOU!


WE appreciate your help in bringing Terror back to Orlando in the form of Nightmares at the Majestic.


A full prospectus is available upon request by emailing info@gonightmares.com.  Please provide mailing address.

Visit us at:  gonightmares.com

Facebook:  Nightmares at the Majestic

Twitter:  NightmaresHaunt

story:
Short Summary

What is Prom Queens?

Prom Queens is a Rock Musical whose roots are in truth, and whose branches blossom into faerytale. 

The story begins in a Drag Punk Club in NYC, 1999. Anticipation for the new Millennium hangs in the air as 3 girls, Daisey, Tina and Claire prepare backstage for their first major industry showcase. 

Just before stepping out onto the stage they learn they're being signed by a record industry icon, but he's going to replace one of them with his blow up doll girlfriend. 

While singing and dancing their hearts out for the concert they've worked so hard to present, Daisey, Tina and Claire flash back on how they met, what they've overcome, and what they've come to mean to one another. 

The story is funny, poignant, uplifting, and we're learning very relatable even to men, who seemed as genuinely excited by our readings as their female counterparts. 

Most importantly, our show gives everyone, regardless of age, shape, pulchritude, the chance to be Prom Queen/King for a night.

Here's the production  we need the money for: 


Click here to Get Tickets: 


Project History

I'm Dana McCoy, one of Prom Queens' co-founders. This play has a great history already, with story and music written in 1999ish by three friends; myself, Jennifer Schanke Ragland, and Christina Cass Catton.

Those beauties migrated South and sprouted families, meanwhile I wrote another rock musical called "Cube Rat" which was workshopped in NYC and at Edinburgh Fringe. Then I got cast in another Rock Musical called "MoM" which won the NY fringe. and another original musical, Zoe Lewis's "Across The Pond!"

It wasn't until just last Fall, Margaret Van Sant inspired me to pull this baby, "Prom Queens" off mothballs for the Women's International Theater Festival. We only did a reading, but there was momentum, Patty DeLuca came on board to produce, she was not gonna let this thing fade back into the horizon. Besides, people wanted more, they were singing our songs all over town!

So we did some more developed readings this April, and at the last moment my Broadway investor friend couldn't travel up from New York. 

Bad news, right? Dreams dashed, careers crushed, etc. But no. Because to make up for it, he's sending 8 of his Broadway producer friends to see the show in July.

Elation! Joy! The world is right. Right? 

Um...well we're getting there. Now all we have to do is come up with a way to get these people here, put them up for a couple of nights, and figure out a way to pay for it during the busiest part of summer in a resort town. No biggie. We just have to put up a Rock Musical while doing it. These are life's excellent problems. Truly!

I have no idea how, but this is happening. Patty and I have rolled up our sleeves, there's no going back. It's Broadway or Bust; Tony's 2015! We hope you'll come with us.

And that's the story, morning glory!

So much love to anyone who's ever been a part of this or ever will. 

After all, let's admit it, we all wanna be Prom Queens!!!!

xoxoxoxo

Dana McCoy


Who's on the Team?


Rick Murray - Venue Owner - Crown & Anchor is supporting Prom Queens with a warm welcome to the Paramount, where Alan Cummings, Liza Minelli, Sandra Bernhard, Donna McKechnie, Andrea McCardle to name just a very few will be performing this summer.  (I'm going to lick the mic. Shhhhhhh)  For more details or to purchase Prom Queen tickets directly, visit: Crown & Anchor Entertainment


Dana McCoy - Founder, Writer, Queen (Daisey) - Dana McCoy’s songs have topped charts worldwide, she’s toured the US, UK and Europe, and made many television appearances. Her CD, “Taking Shape” was chosen by Billboard as a Top 10 Album of the Year. Presently two songs from this CD are in the Eric Shaeffer Film, “Boy Meets Girl” at festivals internationally. Dana’s performed her plays “Prom Queens” and “Cube Rat” Off Broadway in New York, and is a founding member of the cast of “MoM, A Rock Concert Musical”, winner of Out-standing Musical at the NY International Fringe. Dana directed and acted in two plays developed at the Provincetown Theater, produced by Margaret Van Sant and Ctek Arts at The Dublin Gay Theater Festival, May 2014.


Patty DeLuca - Co-Producer (Tina) - appeared on The History Channel’s show “The Way Things Work” as the professional motorcycle instructor. An original member of Ryan Landry's Space Pussy, a rock band, Patty also has a gallery in Provincetown’s Gallery District called DELUCA Gallery/Peg and Dicks. She is a documentary filmmaker. with films appearing in PIFF Provincetown International Film Festival, New York City Film Festival at The Knitting Factory “What a Drag- a Night of Kings and Queens”, “Kissing”, 30 GREEN. Performed Poetry Slam as The Piece at The Knitting Factory, and at Squeezebox NYC. And continues loving living in Provincetown. 


Heidi Weeks (Claire) studied acting at The Neighborhood Playhouse School of Theatre in New York City and has performed in theaters across Canada, New York City and Los Angeles. Heidi was nominated for a NY Emmy Award for her portrayal of Millicent Barnes in “Mirror Image” for the WSKG TV dramatization, “Twilight Zone Live”. She Co- Founded STAR (Southern Tier Actor’s Read), for which she received a Heart of The Arts award. Heidi recently moved to Provincetown, Massachusetts, where she opened a unique designer resale store; Mabel D. Orr.


Sally Tighe (Lola) has graced the stages of Provincetown, Wellfleet, Brewster, and Chatham for the last 10 years. Some of her most memorable performances have been in: Doubt, Hats- The Musical, The Odd Couple-The Female Version, Arsenic and Old Lace, and A Raisin In The Sun.

LORI ADA JAROSLOW, Additional Writing 

Lori's Broadway credits include: Rizzo in Grease and Tzeitel in Fiddler on the Roof, directed by Jerome Robbins. Jaroslow co-produced and directed the multi award-winning CD series Tell Me a Story which features such actors as Len Cariou, Bryce Dallas Howard and Paula Poundstone. The Road Theatre received an NEA grant in 2011 to produce The Baby Project, an original musical theatre piece written by Lori and composers Fonda Feingold and Noriko Olling which ran at The Road Theatre in Los Angeles in 2012. Lori loves to work on new theatre pieces and thanks Dana McCoy for this opportunity. Ms. Jaroslow is on the board at The Academy for New Musical Theatre/New Musicals Inc. and she is a member of The Road Theatre. For more info please go to www.projectbabymusical.com and  www.loriadajaroslow.com


Michael Steers - Co-DIrector, Lighting Design, recently directed and designed The Provincetown Theater’s Production of Martin Sherman’s BENT. Lighting Design credits include: Streetcar Named Desire (University Players) , God of Carnage, Diff ’rent (Provincetown Theatre Company) The Baltimore Waltz (Animus En-semble, Boston) and the World Premier of Myra Slotnick’s The Weight of Water (NYC/PTown). Mike can be seen in ILLUSIONS, Provincetown’s “longest running drag show” as Hostess and MC Anita Cocktail (You can follow him on twitter @AnitaCocktailPT). 


Sue Goldberg (Bass) has performed in NY and Provincetown’s underground duo Scream Along with Billy. Bass player for Space Pussy, Dirty Blonde, and a plethora of musical theater projects, she is thrilled to be part of Prom Queens and can’t cannot wait to take it to NY.


Daniel Yetnikoff - Guitar, Musical Director. is a musician, composer and singer. A veteran of both the Los Angeles and New York music scenes, Daniel has been working as the musical director of Prom Queens since March,  2014


Jed Chrysler (Drums) Midwestern kid. Drummer for over 35 years. Playing in rock bands in Boston and Milwaukee. Toured Midwest and new England. Several CD and vinyl recordings. Current band The Cordobas Playing instrumental 60s surf on Cape Cod. Drummer for Prom Queens


Peter Tighe - Guitar
Peter is a veteran of Provincetown's music scene and apart from his blazing guitar work in Prom Queens can be heard with his band Y-T if one is lucky some night at Bubala's. 


Gabriel Morton - Guitar, is from New York, NY and Provincetown, MA.  He studied music at a tiny hippie school virtually no one has heard of in Bar Harbor, Maine.  Electric Milk Machine and Electric Organ Discharge were two projects he was involved in before living in Europe. After moving back to Cape Cod in Fall 2012, Gabriel can be heard sweetly serenading or shredding face-melting guitar while playing with The Daggers and Chico as well as other small musical projects such as Jazzercize and Dragger.


Gary Graham - Dress Designer, Poster Illustration Artist, studied painting for a year at Maryland Institute College of Art before transferring to theSchool of the Art Institute of Chicago, to study fashion design. Graham moved to New York City in 1993, where he worked as an assistant designer for J. Morgan Puett. In 1999, Graham launched his eponymous line. Graham was a CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund finalist in 2009. In May 2010 Graham traveled to his alma mater in Chicago to accept the Legend of Fashion Award. He is a member of the Council of Fashion Designers of America.


Mike Potter - Original Wig and Makeup design, is also the original and present day designer of Hedwig’s look. A Delaware native with a college degree in agricultural economics and a minor in art, Potter’s experience ranges from hair and/or makeup for photo shoots, magazine and book covers, concerts and music videos, to live shows with titles like Prom Queens and The Girl With Polka-Dot Eyes, and the movies Kiss Me Guido and Flawless. But he explains, "I’m not a licensed hairdresser or anything, I don’t have any formal training."

K. If you say so, Mike. xoxox


Don Collins - Choreographer/Business Consultant. Don Collins is currently the owner of the John Randall House Inn in Provincetown. Prior to managing this inn he was a national cheerleading choreographer and owner of several cheerleading companies. After the sale of his companies he chose to make his new home Provincetown.


ShelleyJennings - Sound Design

Shelley is a sound designer, live sound engineer, system installer, electrician, and musician. She is currently the sound designer, engineer and technician for the Art House Broadway series, and Art House Concerts, Provincetown. She is partnered with MJAudio of Boston and Cape Cod, and is the technical director for the Art House, Provincetown.


Dan LaDivine - Props, Sound and Lights
What would we do without you Dan, I hope we never have to find out. xoxox


Deborah Peabody - Prom Dress fixer and script support - Deborah is well known in Provincetown for various sorts of needlework and may be remembered as the director of the Provincetown Fringe Festival’s production of NECESSSARY TARGETS  and THE WORDS OF RACHEL CORRIE as well as the UU’s first production of MOST DANGEROUS WOMEN.  She has also acted, directed, danced, sung and sewn for the Provincetown theater.  She delights in living in a town where there is room for everyone to nurture their creativity.  While not headed for Broadway, she’s hoping  PROM QUEENS is!


Paul Russo - Set Dresser, rehearsal photography

Jennifer Shanke Ragland and Christina Cass Catton Inspired and created the story and co-wrote the music with me. They're the core.

What a great and terrible time! Just like in the play. lol. Love you Crissy and Jenn. What the hell would I ever have done without you girls.

Christina Cass Catton  

Christina Cass Catton is a co-creator and director of the original Prom Queens incarnation at the No. Moore Bar in TriBeCa, NYC.  Working with Dana and Jennifer was truly one of the most pivotal and creative times in her life and she is so grateful for those years of crazy fun work.  A Fordham University girl who studied Art History and English, she naturally fell in love with the theatre and now lives in Raleigh, NC with her husband and two darling boys. She continues to freelance write and is focused on children's entertainment.

                                                                                   Jennifer Schanke Ragland

Jennifer Schanke Ragland is a co-creator of Prom Queens and the original Claire.  She studied vocal performance at Temple University and at the Royal Academy of Music in London.  She has performed in New York cabarets at "Don't Tell Mama's" and "Rose's Turn".  She was also a NYC public school teacher for seven years.  Currently, she is married and living in Charlotte, NC, raising two beautiful daughters.

See all the angels and heroes  who've contributed to the script on our Prom Queens facebook page. While there you could like it if you felt like it.  XO 


Featherweight Productions Team                               

Dana McCoy and Patty DeLuca - Queens of Featherweight


Jon Asher - Treasure(r) served as an officer of the Navy during Viet Nam, retired as a director from IBM after 30 years, has grown several mid size and start up IT companies into large, lucrative businesses, and currently serves on the advisory committee of the historic town he calls home in New England.


Mark Sendroff - Legal Advisor for Prom Queens also presently represents the writers, directors and/or choreographers of such original New York productions as “The Book of Mormon”, “Kinky Boots”, “Cinderella”, “Motown”, “Hairspray”, “Newsies”, “The Bridges of Madison County”, “Aladdin”, “Ann”, “Big Fish”, “First Date”, “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical”, and on and on we don't have enough space. 


Will Keyworth - Web Media Designer/Manager

Livin' the dream...I am a driven, goal oriented person, when it comes to my career as a small business owner, yet I make sure to smell the roses along the way. I also work part time jobs that allow me to do what I love to do in my spare time. During the summer, I work on a charter sailboat, and during the winter I work for a large ski corporation in Colorado, all the while managing a web/graphic design business that allows me to work at my own pace. I am an aspiring artist and musician. I love gardening.        


Scot McCoy - Wrangler  has over 18 years of professional information technology management experience. He was a founding member of the fastest growing company on the east coast, “Infinite Computer Solutions” (infinite.com), has built technology centers in Bangalore and Hyderabad, India as well as several in Makati Manila, Philippines, which included secret clearance work for the US Navy, Lockheed Martin and DHS distribution. 

Scot has successfully delivered IT projects to IBM, Capgemini, Verizon, Coke, Warner Brothers, and the states of NY, AR, CA and FL. He's currently CEO of a Media Sharing “start up”,www.ReelMcCoy.TV. , on track to become a major player in online media sharing. It allows regular people and companies to upload and sell videos online. 

A highlight in Scot’s life was receiving a thank you letter from the Secretary of the Navy for services rendered during the “Libyan Crisis.”


Seveda Williams - Special Events Coordinator. Not only is Seveda an even better singer than her Uncle, Luther Vandross, for whom she just accepted a star in Hollywood's Walk of Fame, but she has been a spokesmodel for Divabetics, a disease from which she's in remission. Seveda's got many appearances on Oprah under her belt, and was trusted with the helm of her uncle's empire when he fell ill. Seveda has her degree in communications, and is currently pursuing a career modeling and acting. She is a force to be reckoned with. We're lucky she has time for us. 


James Veatch - Prom Queens Hero

Featherweight Board:

  • George Patterson 
  • Leslie McGrath
  • Albert Podell


What We Need 

Budget covers:  Cast and Band (8 people) rehearsal period and 7 shows. Crew: Director, Lighting Designer, Board Op, Sound Designer, Follow Spot Op, Costumes, Prop Master and Props, Set Designer and Set, Printing, Marketing, Producer Fees, Theater Rent, Insurance, Hair, Make-Up, Travel/Lodgings for NY Producers, just for starters.


What You Get

Our love and genuine appreciation, self esteem from being of service to happy hard working artists who are bringing joy to the world, kisses on your cheek, people who'll visit you when you're old. 

Oh and Money! Lots and lots of money if you have the vision to support us at this level before we're massive. It's like getting in on the ground floor of Starbucks.


What happens if we don't make our financial goal, where does the money go?

If we don't make our goal, we're doing the show anyway. We may just look a little ragged from exhaustion, costumes from the methodist church swap shop, and our shot at Broadway could take a little longer as we couldn't get the producers here. We'll be hitting you up again in a few months when we need money to take the show to them in NY. Probably more expensive, so. Might as well jump in now is what I'm saying.


The Impact, Risks & Challenges

Broadway is one of the highest risk investments out there. It's also got the greatest potential for return on investment. If a show hits it's possible to make a thousand times or more on one's initial investment. But let's be perfectly clear. Theater investment couldn't be higher risk financially. It also couldn't be more rewarding even if you lose your shirt. 

Theater makes the many people creating it and all those attending it smarter, happier, stronger, kinder people. It's experiential, it involves human connection, a thing without which we can't even live. Yeah. I love it. It's in my blood. Can't imagine the world without it, and I'm proud to throw my hat in the ring to try to bring something valuable to it. I think our story has a lot to offer. It lets people know they're ok even if they're imperfect by some made up standards. Our story is for everyday underdogs who shine all the time.

We are unbelievably well positioned for success in the face of staggering odds. We have Broadway professionals confirmed to attend, we're the talk of the town already. So we're not just coming out of left field. And our story and music have stood the test of time, no matter the honing still needed, audiences for all the developmental phases have always leapt to their feet and left singing our songs. 

Enough about what could go wrong, let 's talk about what could go right:


The Possibilities

Prom Queens hits on Broadway (Tonys), is made into a film which becomes a blockbuster (Oscars) so it's turned into a long running musical TV series (Emmys) where we have a chance to make not one, but many hit records (Grammys). Then starts our concert tour! (Like Spinal Tap! YEAH!)

Each of which leads to Prom Queen Dolls, CDs, Tee Shirts, Videos, Concert Tickets, Hats, Tiaras, $$$$$. Just saying. Bank. Bigtime. Conglomerate. Titans of Industry. She keeps a steady gaze.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can support Prom Queens with or without money! The following actions would make a huge difference:

  • Introductions to theater contacts and potential investors
  • "Like" our Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/PromQueensMusical
  • Share this campaign on FB, Twitter, etc.
  • Positively review us by word of mouth or online
  • Check out our Website: http://www.promqueensmusical.com
  • Join our mailing list: http://www.promqueensmusical.com/contact.html
  • Offer your expertise such as legal, technical, IT, design, hands on from sewing to stage managing to carpentry to driving! 

Wanna help? You're IN! xoxox

Short SummaryWhat is Prom Queens?Prom Queens is a Rock Musical whose roots are in truth, and whose branches blossom into faerytale. The story begins in a Drag Punk Club in NYC, 1999. Anticipation for the new Millennium hangs in the air as 3 girls, Daisey, Tina and Claire prepare backstage for their first major industry showcase. Just before stepping out onto the stage they learn they're being signed by a record industry icon, but he's going to replace one of them with his blow up doll girlfriend. While singing and dancing their hearts out for the concert they've worked so hard to present, Daisey, Tina and Claire flash back on how they met, what they've overcome, and what they've come to mean to one another. The story is funny, poignant, uplifting, and we're learning very relatable even to men, who seemed as genuinely excited by our readings as their female counterparts. Most importantly, our show gives everyone, regardless of age, shape, pulchritude, the chance to be Prom Queen/King for a night.Here's the production  we need the money for: 
Click here to Get Tickets:

Right? Um...well we're getting there. Now all we have to do is come up with a way to get these people here, put them up for a couple of nights, and figure out a way to pay for it during the busiest part of summer in a resort town. No biggie. We just have to put up a Rock Musical while doing it. These are life's excellent problems. Truly!I have no idea how, but this is happening. Dana McCoy and Patty DeLuca - Queens of Featherweight


Jon Asher - Treasure(r) served as an officer of the Navy during Viet Nam, retired as a director from IBM after 30 years, has grown several mid size and start up IT companies into large, lucrative businesses, and currently serves on the advisory committee of the historic town he calls home in New England.


Mark Sendroff - Legal Advisor for Prom Queens also presently represents the writers, directors and/or choreographers of such original New York productions as “The Book of Mormon”, “Kinky Boots”, “Cinderella”, “Motown”, “Hairspray”, “Newsies”, “The Bridges of Madison County”, “Aladdin”, “Ann”, “Big Fish”, “First Date”, “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical”, and on and on we don't have enough space. 


Will Keyworth - Web Media Designer/Manager
Livin' the dream...I am a driven, goal oriented person, when it comes to my career as a small business owner, yet I make sure to smell the roses along the way. I also work part time jobs that allow me to do what I love to do in my spare time. During the summer, I work on a charter sailboat, and during the winter I work for a large ski corporation in Colorado, all the while managing a web/graphic design business that allows me to work at my own pace. I am an aspiring artist and musician. I love gardening.        


Scot McCoy - Wrangler  has over 18 years of professional information technology management experience. He was a founding member of the fastest growing company on the east coast, “Infinite Computer Solutions” (infinite.com), has built technology centers in Bangalore and Hyderabad, India as well as several in Makati Manila, Philippines, which included secret clearance work for the US Navy, Lockheed Martin and DHS distribution. 

Scot has successfully delivered IT projects to IBM, Capgemini, Verizon, Coke, Warner Brothers, and the states of NY, AR, CA and FL. He's currently CEO of a Media Sharing “start up”,www.ReelMcCoy.TV. , on track to become a major player in online media sharing. It allows regular people and companies to upload and sell videos online. 
A highlight in Scot’s life was receiving a thank you letter from the Secretary of the Navy for services rendered during the “Libyan Crisis.”


Seveda Williams - Special Events Coordinator. Not only is Seveda an even better singer than her Uncle, Luther Vandross, for whom she just accepted a star in Hollywood's Walk of Fame, but she has been a spokesmodel for Divabetics, a disease from which she's in remission. Seveda's got many appearances on Oprah under her belt, and was trusted with the helm of her uncle's empire when he fell ill. Seveda has her degree in communications, and is currently pursuing a career modeling and acting. She is a force to be reckoned with. We're lucky she has time for us. 


James Veatch - Prom Queens Hero
Featherweight Board:



George Patterson 

Leslie McGrath

Albert Podell




What We Need 

Budget covers:  Cast and Band (8 people) rehearsal period and 7 shows. Crew: Director, Lighting Designer, Board Op, Sound Designer, Follow Spot Op, Costumes, Prop Master and Props, Set Designer and Set, Printing, Marketing, Producer Fees, Theater Rent, Insurance, Hair, Make-Up, Travel/Lodgings for NY Producers, just for starters.

What You Get

Our love and genuine appreciation, self esteem from being of service to happy hard working artists who are bringing joy to the world, kisses on your cheek, people who'll visit you when you're old. 
Oh and Money! Lots and lots of money if you have the vision to support us at this level before we're massive. It's like getting in on the ground floor of Starbucks.



What happens if we don't make our financial goal, where does the money go?If we don't make our goal, we're doing the show anyway. We may just look a little ragged from exhaustion, costumes from the methodist church swap shop, and our shot at Broadway could take a little longer as we couldn't get the producers here. We'll be hitting you up again in a few months when we need money to take the show to them in NY. Probably more expensive, so. Might as well jump in now is what I'm saying.






The Impact, Risks & Challenges







Broadway is one of the highest risk investments out there. It's also got the greatest potential for return on investment. If a show hits it's possible to make a thousand times or more on one's initial investment. But let's be perfectly clear. Theater investment couldn't be higher risk financially. It also couldn't be more rewarding even if you lose your shirt. 
Theater makes the many people creating it and all those attending it smarter, happier, stronger, kinder people. It's experiential, it involves human connection, a thing without which we can't even live. Yeah. I love it. It's in my blood. Can't imagine the world without it, and I'm proud to throw my hat in the ring to try to bring something valuable to it. I think our story has a lot to offer. It lets people know they're ok even if they're imperfect by some made up standards. Our story is for everyday underdogs who shine all the time.
We are unbelievably well positioned for success in the face of staggering odds. We have Broadway professionals confirmed to attend, we're the talk of the town already. So we're not just coming out of left field. And our story and music have stood the test of time, no matter the honing still needed, audiences for all the developmental phases have always leapt to their feet and left singing our songs. 
Enough about what could go wrong, let 's talk about what could go right:


The Possibilities

Prom Queens hits on Broadway (Tonys), is made into a film which becomes a blockbuster (Oscars) so it's turned into a long running musical TV series (Emmys) where we have a chance to make not one, but many hit records (Grammys). Then starts our concert tour! (Like Spinal Tap! YEAH!)
Each of which leads to Prom Queen Dolls, CDs, Tee Shirts, Videos, Concert Tickets, Hats, Tiaras, $$$$$. Just saying. Bank. Bigtime. Conglomerate. Titans of Industry. She keeps a steady gaze.


Other Ways You Can Help






You can support Prom Queens with or without money! The following actions would make a huge difference:


Introductions to theater contacts and potential investors
"Like" our Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/PromQueensMusical
Share this campaign on FB, Twitter, etc.
Positively review us by word of mouth or online
Check out our Website: http://www.promqueensmusical.com
Join our mailing list: http://www.promqueensmusical.com/contact.html

Offer your expertise such as legal, technical, IT, design, hands on from sewing to stage managing to carpentry to driving! 


Wanna help? You're IN! xoxox

story:
The BlakTina 2 Festival is a movement festival of cutting-edge work presented by Licia Perea of the Latina Dance Theater Project (LDTP) and the Bootleg Theater. This is our second year featuring Latina (o) and Black choreographers in one festival based in the greater Los Angeles area, and we will highlight the works of 10 contemporary choreographers.

SAVE THE DATES: September 4th, 5th & 6th, 2014 at Bootleg Theater

The BlakTina Festival is forging new boundaries in the festival scene in L.A. The first BlakTina Festival was a huge success and we are proud to be expanding and growing.This year we are fundraising to match a grant from the Los Angeles Department of Cultural Affairs to pay choreographers for their contribution to the festival. This is a first; last year we produced the festival on a shoestring. We are proud to be able to pay our artists, because they deserve it!!

This  year's choreographers are: Cyrian Reed, Crystal Sepúlveda, Dorcas Roman, Joshua Romero, Marina Magalhães & Allison Gray, Maura Townsend, Michelle Funderburk, Rande Dorn and Sofia Carreras!

Licia Perea of LDTP and Alicia Adams of Bootleg Theater are committed to producing boundary-defying performances born of the diverse cultural and artistic landscape of L.A. Their three-fold plan is to give emerging and mid-career choreographers opportunities to present their work, to create a community and to expand all of our collective audiences.

Why is your contribution so valuable? We produce a one-of-a-kind festival in the L.A. area and need your financial help to match DCA funds to pay participating choreographers. 

HELP US MAKE HISTORY!

Other ways you can help:

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Share this campaign and if you are in LA area, come watch the performances! 

Tickets available at www.bootlegtheater.org

story:
Short Summary

Hi everyone! Vitamin Proof Productions are a new theatre production company and we are putting on a double bill of plays by Stephen Brackenridge. 'Potato Artist' and 'Sandwich' will show in Govanhill Baths on Wednesday March 25th - Saturday 28th as part of the Glasgow International Comedy Festival 2015. Having previously produced 'The Pilot Scheme' in August 2014, we are looking to raise funds for these two new plays.

With 'Sandwich' being set in a dystopian future, funding will ensure the set and costumes look fantastic!

What We Need & What You Get


  • We are looking for £1000 to go towards the cost of set design, costumes, props, travelling expenses and stipends for cast and crew and spreading the word about the shows! 
  • Perks will include genius level 'Thank You' emails, entry into the program as 'Purveyors of Potato Artistry and General Surveyors of Sandwiches', poems and drawings on a subject of contributors choice, signed posters and Flying Penguins goodies! 
  • We will use the money for set design, costumes and props.

The Impact

  • This project means a lot to me as I hope to provide audiences with a thrilling and meaningful (not to mention funny) experience. These plays are relevant to contemporary life and I want to make them the best that they can be with your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign. Tell friends and share the event on social media!

story:
SUMMARY

Welcome to our world! Dennis Deal and Laura Kenyon longtime friends - writers, musicians, actors - have collaborated on a number of theater pieces, but THE LAST DAY OF JUNE is the one that kept nudging, so we finally accepted the challenge. We always loved Kenyon’s character June Cool...what were we waiting for?

Gaining visibility for THE LAST DAY OF JUNE is the purpose of our crowdfunding campaign. We must go after everything available to attract the right investors and producers for our project. The capital to get THE LAST DAY OF JUNE up and running is estimated at $800K, and then tack on another $100K for promotion and a healthy reserve. To get our musical to Off Broadway... it takes a village!

BIOGRAPHIES

Deal & Kenyon

Dennis Deal (music, lyrics, co-author)

Dennis Deal is best known for his award-winning 50's musical send-up, Nite Club Confidential, which he's presented Off Broadway, on London's West End and in Los Angeles with Scott Bakula, Fay DeWitt, Mimi Hines, Barbara Eden, Gary Sandy,   Jim Bailey and the fabulous Laura Kenyon.

Off Broadway, Dennis has arranged musical recreations for CBS LIVE!, directed his own comedy, The Bad and the Horrible and NY Fringe productions of Tri-Sci-Fi and Attack of the 50 Ft. Walt Whitman. He’s also created solo shows for Manhattan Transfer's Cheryl Bentyne, Dreaming of Mister Porter, and for longtime partner-in-sublime-crime, Scott Bakula, An Evening With Scott Bakula at Fords Theater. 

Early on, Dennis arranged over twenty LP's of unrecorded theater music for Ben Bagley's Painted Smiles Records, featuring such notables as Alan Arkin, Nell Carter, Tammy Grimes, Ann Miller, Anthony Perkins, Lynn Redgrave, Chita Rivera, Elaine Stritch & Katharine Hepburn. 

Laura Kenyon (co-author)

Laura Kenyon is a Broadway, Off Broadway, Regional Theater actress, writer and composer. Broadway: Nine, On the Town, Man of La Mancha, She has starred in Damn Yankees, Kiss Me Kate, Oliver, Most Happy Fella, Fiorello, Guys and Dolls, and Dennis Deal’s hit musical, Nite Club Confidential. She embraced the role of Seraphina in the Rose Tattoo and Charles Bushʼs The Allergist’s Wife. 

Laura has collaborated with Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman on many occasions, most recently for NBCʼs Smash! Broadway ʼ68 at La Mama and has recorded Mostly Mercer, Unpublished COLE Porter, the Papermill Playhouse cast album of Follies. Her career began in Hollywood writing and recording with Warren Zevon. She is also a cabaret legend having opened and closed every club on the circuit.

Tom Hooper (set designer)

Tom Hooper’s Broadway credits include Into the Woods, Secret Garden,     Anything Goes, Beauty and the Beast and Starlight Express. Selected commissions include JukeBox Jackie and Broadway ’68 directed by Scott Wittman (La Mama), Flying Karamozovs (BAM), Pascal Rioult (Dance NY) and Sleeping Beauty (NYC Ballet). 

His credits also include The Santa Fe Opera, American Repertory Theatre, American Ballet Theatre, Atlanta Ballet, Arena Stage, Goodspeed Opera House and resident set designer for Alice Spivak’s OnTheRoad Repertory Company.

With 3 Emmy awards for Scenic Art, Tom Hooper’s work has been featured on SMASH, Last Week Tonight with John Oliver, The Nate Berkus Show, Dr.OZ, and Steven Soderbergh’s The Knick. Recent film credits include Martin Scorsese’s The Wolf of Wall Street, Deliver Us From Evil with Eric Bana and Noah.


ENDORSEMENTS

"The first person to ever ask me to do a job, without having to audition, was  DENNIS DEAL, way back in 1985. It's hard to articulate what that means to an actor. That was the beginning of our collaborative process, which 20 years later culminated in the creation of my one-man show! He is the penultimate collaborator, and what he brings to the table creatively is unparalleled. Couple all of that with great taste and style and you have the uniqueness that is DENNIS DEAL!"                 ~SCOTT BAKULA - Actor (Quantum Leap, NCIS-New Orleans)

"LAURA KENYON is bold, brassy, hilarious and someone you’ll never forget being in the same room with. Cancel everything else and go see her!!!"                          ~MICHAEL MUSTO - Cultural Critic

"I was introduced to DENNIS DEAL by Ben Bagley (Producer of The Shoe String Reviews in the 50’s and 60’s) who told Dennis that I was the “perfect star” for his new musical, NITE CLUB CONFIDENTIAL. It provided me with reviews I could’ve only dreamt about. Working with DENNIS DEAL, such a multi-talented man who knew what he wanted, made it all funny, glamorous and even sad in a tongue-in-cheek film noir kinda way!"                                                                                                        ~FAY DeWITT - Actress, Singer(Blue Angel, Bon Soir, Desert Inn, Vegas)

"KENYON is a dangerously brilliant performer. Her dazzling spontaneity as actress/singer/comedienne, can lead her audience from madness to joy, from despair to serenity-to a destination that is somewhere off a cliff and over a rainbow."                                                                                                                       ~CHERYL HARDWICK - SNL Musical Director/Writer

"I’ve know the incomparable DENNIS DEAL since the magnificent performances of the LA run of NITE CLUB CONFIDENTIAL. He’s without question, the brightest, cleverest, most original man I’ve ever worked with. The GREAT and true artist that is LAURA KENYON starred in the Boston run of NITE CLUB CONFIDENTIAL and my own play, DESIRE! I’m still laughing. No, really - I’m still laughing. I’ve heard the CD of THE LAST DAY OF JUNE and it’s anything BUT...it’s the FIRST Day of June!"  ~PAUL COATES - Playwright/Agent

story:
The goal of the project by Nanzikambe Arts is to promote a new generation of 21st-century arts space, easily accessible by all and a cadre of artists and arts leadership that reflect the cultural richness of diverse communities of Malawi. Please visit our website to find out more about us!

The Challenge-The arts and culture are essential elements in a sustainable human development process. Since 2011, we have seen two other performance spaces close due to the economic downturn. We at Nanzikambe Arts are one of the last remaining Arts venues in Malawi and are now under threat, we will have to leave our rented home by the 30th of December. With your support we can make a permanent theatre that we own here in Blantyre.


There are five things your support will allow:

  1. With support from Theatre Konstanz of Germany we are currently acquiring the land for our premises. 
  2. Construct a perimeter wall around our newly acquired premises for our theatre organization (we already have 30,000 bricks for this part of the project).
  3. Move our performance stage from Naperi Township where it currently is to our place in Chimwankhunda Township, one of the townships of the city of Blantyre.
  4. Construct a multi-purpose open plan office block (we already have 30,000 bricks towards this part of the project).
  5. Construct an Arts Café for our patrons (we already have 25,000 bricks towards this initiative).

Nanzikambe Arts philosophy is in line with the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs); the Malawi Growth and Development Strategy (MGDS) II; the Paris Declaration on Aid Efficiency;  and the UNESCO Convention on Cultural Diversity, among other frameworks. Nanzikambe Arts equally subscribes to the notion that culture is intrinsically and intimately linked with creativity - it stimulates inter-cultural dialogue and increases positive identity awareness. Culture also represents market potential and educational value, so it plays a considerable part in the fight against poverty. Moreover, culture acts on behavioral change.

Nanzikambe Arts works with institutions and networks in Malawi and the sub-Saharan Africa that contribute to the flourishing of artists who, in turn, play their socio-societal role in strengthening democracies in Africa. The arts play a vital role in helping to create more just and vibrant societies by inspiring innovation and imagination, encouraging civic dialogue and reflecting the rich diversity of our nations’ changing demographics, unfortunately the world over, even more-so in Africa, many communities, particularly in times of economic downturn, lack affordable facilities where artists and arts organizations can incubate and produce creative works and engage more widely with the public. This is equally true for Malawi.

What your support will help us achieve – We want to create a new generation of arts facilities, artists and arts leadership that are firmly grounded in the area in which people reside and that is a model of artistic innovation, cultural and community collaboration, and social partnership.

(Theatre Lab Training, at our current home in Naperi township Blantyre)

Expected Results - With the realization of this project, Nanzikambe Arts will have its own home and will thus remain sustainable. Artists and those aspiring for arts management roles will have a readily available base where they can rehearse and network and perform to readily available audiences. This is what Malawi needs, more-so now than ever before because the French Cultural Centre and the Goethe Institute closed their doors in 2011 and since then, what we have seen is a downward spiral of artistic excellence due to narrowing arts and cultural spaces. 

This is what the sub-Saharan African region needs. This is what the world needs! 

Your support in this project will help to ensure the future of ‘African Theatre’s warm heart’.

We salute and thank you in anticipation!

demographics, unfortunately the world over, even more-so in Africa, many
communities, particularly in times of economic downturn, lack affordable
facilities where artists and arts organizations can incubate and produce
creative works and engage more widely with the public. This is equally true for
Malawi. 

What your support will help us achieve – We want to create
a new generation of arts facilities, artists and arts leadership that are
firmly grounded in the area in which people reside and that is a model of
artistic innovation, cultural and community collaboration, and social
partnership.

(Theatre Lab Training, at our current home in Naperi township Blantyre)
Expected
Results - With the
realization of this project, Nanzikambe Arts will have its own home and will
thus remain sustainable. Artists and those aspiring for arts management roles
will have a readily available base where they can rehearse and network and
perform to readily available audiences. This is what Malawi needs, more-so now
than ever before because the French Cultural Centre and the Goethe Institute
closed their doors in 2011 and since then, what we have seen is a downward
spiral of artistic excellence due to narrowing arts and cultural spaces. 
This
is what the sub-Saharan African region needs. This is what the world needs! 
Your support in this project will help to ensure the
future of ‘African Theatre’s warm heart’.
We salute and thank you in anticipation!

story:
Who We Are:

Pipedream Theatre Project Society is a not-for-profit musical theatre company based in Vancouver, BC, Canada. We are dedicated to showcasing local talent in modern and challenging musical productions.

What We're Doing:

Coming in June 2015, Pipedream is please to present a brand new show!

An original musical from local writers Gil and Sarah Jaysmith, One Plus One is a timely, intelligent, and funny examination of infertility—a heartbreaking experience that affects more couples than we realize.

Alex and Madison struggle to keep their relationship together as their blinding desire to start a family causes them to lose sight of what they already have. With the unwavering and often-unwanted support of family and friends, can they navigate the greatest challenge they will face together?

With musical influences like Stephen Sondheim, William Finn, and Elvis Costello, One Plus One includes moving ballads, a passionate tango, a show-stopping gospel tornado, and the liveliest song about providing a sperm sample you’ll ever hear.

What We Need:

The complexities of putting on a new work are immense. Development, casting, rehearsals, and our show run are just a part of it.
From sets, to props, to talent, there are so many things we need to get covered, and we need your help.
We are able to raise a high percentage of necessary funds through generous sponsorship, but donations are essential to our success.
Still, we're not asking to get something for nothing. Check out our perks to see what we're offering.

The Impact:

This project is locally written and produced and will be cast/crewed with all local talent. It's a continuing part of the groundswell of talent in this city.

Keeping that momentum going and helping to develop sustained growth in Vancouver theatre is our goal.

Your contribution is an investment in that continued growth.

Other Ways You Can Help:

We're not just looking for money. We need all the help we can get.

We need volunteers for events, are always looking for new members and, of course, people to spread the word!

If you want to contribute, please contact us at info@pipedream.ca

___________________

So, take a look at what we're offering, think about what you're giving to, and help us however you can!
